name: Gillard, Julia, MP
text:
—This bill was introduced into the House on 13 March 2002, and here we are many months later finally debating it. Earlier in the year, the bill was referred to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee for inquiry and report by 15 May 2002. The amendments the government has circulated to this bill arise from the recommendations of that Senate committee, and Labor welcomes those changes. 
I will turn firstly to the contents of the bill. The bill makes the following changes to the Migration Act. First, the bill clarifies the immigration status of non-citizen children born in the migration zone—that is, born on the Australian mainland or born in non-excised parts of Australia. Obviously, children are born in Australia to non-citizens who are here in a variety of circumstances, such as on a tourist visa, a temporary entry visa, a student visa and the like. Children can also be born to non-citizens who are not immigration cleared. This applies to detained persons, including asylum seekers, who have not been taken to be immigration cleared until their claim has been processed and a visa has been issued. 
Under the current Migration Act, there is no specific provision as to the immigration status of a child born in these various circumstances. Conceptually under the act, a child who is born to a person here on a valid visa is not immigration cleared and would not be immigration cleared until separately processed. Clearly, as a matter of practice, there are not separate immigration clearance procedures for newborn babies, and the child is assumed to have the same status as his or her parents. This amendment clarifies this matter by providing that, at the moment of birth, a child is immigration cleared if a parent was immigration cleared on last entry into Australia. Put simply, if a parent is immigration cleared and lawfully here, the child will be seen, by virtue of this amendment and as a matter of law, to be immigration cleared and lawfully here as well. If a child is born to a person who does not hold a substantive visa and who has not been immigration cleared, such as an asylum seeker in detention, this amendment provides that the child is not immigration cleared and the child's immigration status will then be dealt with in a substantive visa application process.
Second, the bill clarifies issues relating to the cancellation of special purpose visas. Special purpose visas are used for classes of individuals, such as aircraft crews, crews of visiting vessels and members of foreign armed forces visiting for the purposes of exercises or training. Given that a person qualifies for a visa because of his or her membership of the relevant class of person, if information comes to light about the undesirability of a particular individual within that class, it is necessary to have a process to cancel the visa and to cancel it expeditiously. Currently, section 33 of the Migration Act provides that the minister may cancel such a visa if it is undesirable for the non-citizen holder to travel to and enter Australia or remain in Australia. The visa ceases to be in effect at the end of the day on which the declaration is made.  
It is not clear under the current act whether or not the rules of natural justice apply to such a cancellation and, consequently, whether the individual has a right to be heard in these circumstances. The bill makes it clear that the rules of natural justice do not apply to such a visa cancellation and that the person involved has no right to be heard. This is a sensible clarification. Australia does not owe hearing rights to non-citizens in such circumstances. In addition, there are considerable logistical difficulties with offering such hearing rights to individuals, such as seafarers who may have deserted vessels. The amendment also provides that the declaration to cancel the visa comes into effect immediately.
Third, the bill deals with restrictions on bridging visa holders for onshore applications for visas. Section 48 of the Migration Act provides that a person who has been in Australia and who has made an application for a visa and been unsuccessful can then apply for only a limited number of visa types. This is obviously to prevent people lodging countless applications specifically to remain in the country. There has been some avoidance of the intent of this provision. Specifically, people are travelling overseas a short distance—for example, to Auckland—and then returning and seeking to make a whole new round of onshore applications. The bill proposes to stop this practice by providing that, for the purposes of this section, a non-citizen holding a bridging visa who leaves and re-enters the migration zone is taken to have been continuously in the migration zone despite that travel. It should be noted that, through the amendments the government has circulated to this bill, there is a clarification that the force of this provision does not prevent a person on a bridging visa from lodging a visa application offshore.
Fourth, the bill deals with the imposition of strict liability for people-smuggling offences. Section 233(1)(a) of the Migration Act makes it an offence punishable by imprisonment for 10 years and/or a fine of 1,000 penalty units to participate in `the bringing or coming to Australia of a non-citizen under circumstances from which it might reasonably have been inferred that the non-citizen intended to enter Australia in contravention of the Migration Act'. The provision says nothing about the state of mind of the accused in relation to the circumstances under which the non-citizen is brought to or comes to Australia.
As part of the post Tampa raft of legislation passed by the parliament in September 2001, the Migration Legislation Amendment (Application of Criminal Code) Act 2001 came into effect. The act added the following third point to the matters that the prosecution has to prove in any prosecution under section 233(1)(a) of the Migration Act:
... the accused was aware of a substantial risk that the non-citizen intended to enter Australia in contravention of the Migration Act and, having regard to the circumstances known to him or her, he or she was not justified in taking that risk.
The application of the criminal code act was not meant to change the nature of offences. The explanatory memorandum of that act stated that the relevant offences would continue to have the same meaning and apply in the same way they did prior to the application of the criminal code. This bill therefore corrects the anomaly which arises because the application of the Criminal Code has had an unintended effect. Prior to the government's amendments, the bill also dealt with the application of strict liability to section 241(1) of the Migration Act, which deals with offences in relation to de facto spouses. This provision is not being proceeded with at this stage, largely as a result of recommendations from the Senate legislation committee. The government has indicated its intention to draft a clearer provision and to include it in future legislation.
Labor supports these changes to the Migration Act and therefore supports this bill. But, given the non-controversial nature of this bill, the principal debate before this House is not about the technical provisions which I have spoken about; it is a debate about children in detention which arises squarely from the amendments that have been circulated by me, which I will move and which the member for Gellibrand, in her capacity as Labor's shadow minister for children and youth, will second at the consideration in detail stage. These amendments, if adopted, would amend the power to detain under the Migration Act so that the government would be compelled to do two things. First, it would be compelled to place unaccompanied children into appropriate foster or community care arrangements rather than hold such children in high-security detention facilities like Woomera, Baxter, Port Hedland, Villawood, Maribyrnong and the like. Second, it would compel the government to rehouse children who are currently here with their families in high-security detention in accommodation like that used for the alternative detention trial at Woomera. 
I think it is necessary to draw the attention of the House to some of the details of that trial. I have seen it. That government trial consists of four ordinary houses in which women and children have been allowed to live—that is, male family members have been excluded. It is a group of four houses on a block. The arrangement is secured in two senses. First, one house is allocated for security staff—that is, it is staffed 24 hours a day by guards who maintain a continuous security presence in the facility. Second, the perimeter of the block around the four houses is secured by a light beam which, if broken, sounds an alarm. In question time yesterday, the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs implied, in my view, that these facilities were not secure. That is simply not the case. On the issue of security, you do not have to take my word for it. It would be better to look at the scoreboard, which shows that no-one has ever absconded from the alternative detention trial at Woomera. That is a situation we can contrast with the Woomera detention facility itself, where absconding has become a matter of routine. So the alternative detention trial houses are secured by guards and a light beam at the perimeter. No-one has ever absconded. That is not true of other high-security facilities like the Woomera facility itself.
It should also be noted that Labor's amendment would compel the government to house whole family groups in this kind of accommodation, including male members such as fathers and brothers. So far, under the government's trial, that has not occurred and the trial has been limited to women and children. As I have said in this House before, and as I have conveyed in writing to all members of this House, there is no credible argument against Labor's amendment. There can be no argument for detaining unaccompanied children in high-security detention. I think we need to remind ourselves in this debate that at one point, under the Howard government, there was an unaccompanied eight-year-old in Woomera. There is no argument for not housing families in accommodation like that of the Woomera alternative detention trial. As I said, I have seen it. The nature of that detention is clearly better for families than being in high-security compounds like Woomera. In truth, no argument about absconding and security exists. Once again, do not take my word for it. That this model would be an adequate way to house families, including fathers and teenage sons, has been endorsed by the minister's own hand-picked Immigration Detention Advisory Group.
Why are these amendments before this House today? This is a further and important step in Labor's yearlong campaign to free children from behind the razor wire. This campaign started on Australia Day, when our leader, Simon Crean, the member for Hotham, called for children to be freed in his Australia Day address. It is a campaign we will continue, and it is a campaign which has already met with some success. Last week in this House the minister for immigration made a major ministerial statement about children in detention. In using the word `major', I am taking a little bit of licence. It was a very lengthy ministerial statement, but when one studied it in detail there were actually three paragraphs that related to the question of children in detention. Nevertheless, those three paragraphs are important. Those important three paragraphs provide that the migration series instructions which guide the work of departmental officials in relation to detention and other matters will be changed so that unaccompanied children are not held in high-security detention facilities. Instead, the standing directive will be to, if possible, move them to foster or community care arrangements. 
The other change contained in the ministerial statement was that the Howard government would seek to negotiate with the South Australian government, the Rann Labor government, to access further housing stock which would enable it to house women and children in accommodation like that used in the Woomera alternative detention trial. Put simply, the ministerial statement last week was about getting unaccompanied children out of detention and about seeking an agreement with the South Australian government to expand the Woomera alternative detention trial, but under the same conditions that that trial is currently used, meaning that it would not include male family members—certainly not adult males, in terms of fathers, and not teenage boys.
Why was that statement made at all? One is entitled to ask that question. The answer is—and this is a matter of public record; any cursory scanning of the newspapers over the past week or so would verify this—that the ministerial statement was made only because it was clear that a number of Liberal moderates had advised the minister for immigration that they would vote for Labor's amendment, which I have outlined today, unless the government moved on the question of children in detention. Amongst the names one sees in the newspaper—and perhaps there are some more Liberal moderates; I do not want to insult anybody by exclusion—are the member for Kooyong, the member for Cook, the member for Hindmarsh and the member for Pearce, who have been seen to run a campaign internally, threatening the minister that he would face the embarrassment of them crossing the floor and voting for Labor's amendment unless he moved on the question of children in detention. That is the only reason the ministerial statement was made last week: because of Labor's campaign to get children out of detention and because of the fact that this amendment was coming up before the parliament.
It is quite clear that Liberal moderates have forced this statement. They have forced it against the better judgment of the minister. The minister on 8 May this year, when asked about relaxing mandatory detention arrangements for women and children—asked about the very thing that he has now done—said this:
You're simply saying to people all you have to do is bring a child with you, turn up in Australia and you have obtained a migration outcome regardless of whether you have an entitlement or not.
—It is still relevant.
—The minister just verified that it is still relevant. What we know, therefore, is that the minister, in his perfect world, would not have made any changes to detention arrangements last week. He would have maintained high-security detention as the model for all comers—unaccompanied children, families with children, women with children and what have you—but he has been forced to move by Liberal moderates who have been shamed into moving by Labor's amendment. The minister has made a ministerial statement and has posited changes in detention arrangements against his better judgment. That is one thing we know about last week's ministerial statement.
The other thing we know about last week's ministerial statement is that it was incredibly rushed. The reason it only contains three paragraphs about the issue the ministerial statement was supposedly about, which is children in detention—in a sea of self-congratulation about its migration policy, there are these three paragraphs about children in detention—is that the government has not as yet come to an arrangement with the South Australian government about access to appropriate housing stock. I have been in this House since 1998; I understand that my period of service in this House pales into insignificance compared with the minister's. But, on the basis of my service in this House, it seems to me that one normally makes a ministerial statement when one has something to announce. It seems to me to follow—not to make too controversial a proposition—that you normally make a ministerial statement when you have something to announce. Minister Ruddock made a ministerial statement to tell us that he was having discussions about something he may or may not be in a position to later announce when he has come to whatever agreement he might come to with the South Australian government. 
So we know about the ministerial statement made last week against Minister Ruddock's better judgment. In terms of timing, it was made last week not because it was ready to go—because the government does not have any operative arrangements with the South Australian government—but because it had to beat into this place today's amendment. The whole thing was about making sure that Liberal moderates did not vote for today's amendment. So that is where we are.
The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs made reference in question time yesterday to Labor using our good offices to assist with discussions with the South Australian government. I assure the House and the minister that, if he requires Labor's assistance to help him with his workload as minister for immigration, we of course stand ready to assist. I have had a number of discussions with the South Australian government about matters related to Woomera, particularly matters related to children in detention. I have met in that regard with the minister for community services and with the minister for education. I am quite willing to keep assisting the minister with striking an appropriate arrangement with the South Australian government. One could not get a better offer of bipartisanship than offering to do the minister's work for him. We will of course in the coming months, if it is necessary, do what we can to assist this minister to put some content into his ministerial statement and to actually get some housing stock which can be used for the purpose that the ministerial statement says it will be used.
On the one hand, the ministerial statement made last week—despite the fact that it was rushed, that it would not have happened if it had not been for Labor's amendment and that it was made against the minister's better judgment—represents a major advance and a major change for this government. It is the first time in many years of pursuing an absolutely inflexible detention model, and of deriding as lunatic and in league with people smugglers anybody who suggested there should be flexibility in the detention model, that the government have taken a step forward and agreed with, or at least partially agreed with, the proposition that it is not a good thing to have unaccompanied children in high-security detention facilities and that it is not a good thing to have children, even in family groups, in high-security detention facilities. 
We welcome last week's ministerial statement as a step forward. It is a major backdown, given where the government have been. It stands against their rhetoric that any change in detention arrangements would be an opening of the floodgates. It stands against their rhetoric criticising, vilifying and branding as lunatic and as being in league with people smugglers anybody, whether they be from Labor or from refugee advocacy groups, who has the temerity to suggest that perhaps there is a better way for our detention arrangements. We welcome that.
The Liberal moderates, who I have no doubt are following this debate closely, need to think again about whether or not they are going to support Labor's amendment. I understand they have done a pretty remarkable thing—that is, they have got the minister for immigration to move on detention arrangements, and I am not underestimating how difficult an internal battle that would have been—but I say to those Liberal moderates: when we come to vote today, have a think about the following. These changes in detention arrangements arise from migration series instructions. They are not law. There is no compulsion. They are a guideline to direct activity. Minister Ruddock was good enough to correspond with me to indicate why he thought my amendment was not right. I have had cause to study that letter quite closely. One of the reasons he thinks his ministerial statement is better, and that my amendment is not appropriate, is that he wants to maintain a fair bit of discretion in this area. He says in his letter to me things like:
Rather than simplifying decision-making processes, as Labor professes to support, your proposed amendments would introduce blanket requirements that would remove my discretion in deciding on the most appropriate place of detention for certain unlawful non-citizens. 
Too right it would; absolutely. That is what it aims to do. It is aims to ensure that, in terms of a compulsion under the law, the minister has no discretion to determine where kids get held. It is not a question of discretion: will I place this unaccompanied eight-year-old in line with the migration series instructions or will I exercise my discretion in some other way? It is supposed to take away that discretion. We want to take away that discretion, because we want to be absolutely certain that there will never again be a time in this country when there will be an unaccompanied eight-year-old in Woomera. That is why we want an amendment to the Migration Act. Minister Ruddock wants to retain some discretion. Why? We know he does not actually believe in the detention changes he announced last week.
—We know why that occurred with the eight-year old. The eight-year-old was with family and the view was that it was quite inappropriate to take the child away from the family.
—I am coming to the question of whole family groups in a minute, Minister, so it is useful that you have raised it with me. This letter verifies that the minister wants to retain some discretion. I ask the Liberal moderates who have fought hard for this change: how certain are you that it is going to be effective when it does not have the force of law? How certain are you that it is going to be effective when the principal argument the minister puts against it is that he still needs some discretion? That is point 1. Point 2, in terms of the Liberal moderates who are going to vote for Labor's amendment, is that our amendment deals with whole family groups. In the interjection from the minister, he indicated that there is an issue about separating families. We do not think you should separate families. Our amendment deals with whole family groups. It does so deliberately.
The member for Lingiari is in the chamber and, with the constituency he represents, he would know this better than I. This nation has learnt, to its very great cost, what one can do if one separates families—and particularly if one separates children from parents—and what even people of goodwill can do unwittingly. A lot of the stolen children generation occurred because people of goodwill acted unwittingly. Not all of them did, but there was a component of that. We know the terrible misery that can be inflicted, generation after generation, if one smashes up family groups. That is why Labor's amendment deals with keeping family groups together.
I would say to Liberal moderates, who are the kind of people who would have shed tears watching the Bringing them home video and reading the Bringing them home report and who would worry about the scar on this nation's soul and on some of its people from the stolen children generation: if you believe, as I do, that a father has a right equal to that of a mother to be with children and that a brother's participation in a family is as important as a sister's then you must support Labor's amendment. The ministerial statement of last week does not give you that; it does not give you whole family groups. It does not put fathers with families. It does not put brothers with families. If you care about that then you need to take the extra step, come in here at voting time and vote for Labor's amendment. I cannot put that point too strongly. It seems to me that everything we know from human experience is that, if you can keep families together, you should.
The Prime Minister is on the record—in quite a different context: over the use of IVF technology for women without partners, and particularly women who are lesbians—as having put the view that his model, his image and his ideal of a family group means having a mother and a father. If he believes that, why would he have a detention policy that does not reflect that? Labor's amendment does. I say to those Liberal moderates, `I know you have already done a lot of work, I know you have done it against opposition, I know that it has been difficult and I know that there has been advance, but there is more work to do, and that work can only be done by voting for Labor's amendment.' This will not end today. Today, in this House, we will support our amendment. I anticipate that even if some Liberal moderates cross the floor we will be defeated. We will support our amendment in the Senate. I anticipate that in the Senate, with the support of the minor parties, we will carry it. We will bring it back to this House and we will support it again.  
So we are saying to Liberal moderates, `Understand this: you are embarking on a path where every few months between now and the next election you will have to decide, as a matter of conscience, yet again, whether or not you are going to support Labor's amendment.' I am sure that the minister will say parts of this bill are urgent, parts of it are vital and they have to be dealt with now. They are largely technical amendments but, if there is any part of this bill that that argument truly applies to, then I will move it as a private member's bill and Labor will vote for it. So if there is any part of it that you need urgently, let me know. I will move it as a private member's bill, Labor will vote for it and you can have it. But you cannot have this bill in total until you vote for Labor's amendment to get children out of detention. You will face that choice routinely over the coming few years. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Mr Randall) adjourned.

name: Randall, Don, MP
text:
—I am pleased to speak on the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002. We know that the purpose of this omnibus bill is to amend the Migration Act 1958. The bill purports to do the following: it changes aspects of the Australian legal regime in relation to visas, it creates the deputy principal member position for the Migration Review Tribunal, it harmonises the Criminal Code and relevant offences under the act, and it makes minor technical amendments. There are six major elements of this bill and I will briefly allude to them before beginning to examine the amendments moved by the Labor Party in relation to the bill.
The first main provision of this bill is the immigration clearance status of non-citizen children born in Australia; the second is the taking of securities; the third is special purpose visas; the fourth is membership of the Migration Review Tribunal; the fifth is Criminal Code harmonisation; and, finally, the sixth major provision is the minor amendments which can be considered in detail. I will return to them later if we have time. As the opposition spokesman in this area has said, basically there is support for this legislation in relation to the major schedules, much of it is good legislation and, as a result, Labor will be supporting this bill except for the amendments they have moved. The amendments moved by the Labor Party are very interesting because they address the very thorny issue, for the Labor Party, of detention. Here comes Mr Baird, one of the major focuses for the opposition spokesman on this area. But I am sure he has a mind of his own.
—I'm damned sure he doesn't agree with you.
—You have not heard what I have had to say yet; it is very interesting that you are a mind-reader. It is very interesting to look at the historical context of the amendments which have been moved by the opposition on the detention of children and on family arrangements. I want to go back to the pre-election period, when I was running for the seat of Canning against the incumbent member. Interestingly, the issue of border protection and security became one of the main focuses of the election. I want to make it clear that I was out doorknocking at that time, and it was pretty evident that the Labor Party initially opposed border protection legislation. The issue of the Tampa certainly focused people's minds on this issue, and then the Labor Party tried to reposition itself. We know that it cost the former leader, Mr Beazley, the election because of the poor decision he made regarding the first raft of border protection legislation. 
The public are smart. They can tell there is an opportunistic shift. When I was out doorknocking, people volunteered their views on this matter quite readily. They could see that the Labor Party were falling in line with the government, largely because the polling was telling the Labor Party where they were going with this. In several debates on radio and in the media with me, my opponent kept making this point, `We are one with the government regarding this matter.' She said, `There is not a cigarette paper's difference between us and the government on this issue of migration.' That included mandatory detention.
The greatest hypocrisy came from the member for Fremantle. The member for Fremantle, this week and last week, has pulled the rug out from under her leader and the opposition spokesman on this issue by saying she cannot support the legislation that will go through today, which the Labor Party has said it will support. The behaviour of the member for Grayndler, the member for Denison and Senator George Campbell—who stood at the back of the press conference clapping—is symptomatic of the endemic rift in the Labor Party on this issue. No matter how much the Labor Party tries to paper over the cracks, it has a big problem—not only with members in the organisation but also with its parliamentary members and their constituencies.
The member for Fremantle's hypocrisy is unbelievable. She was the Premier of Western Australia when mandatory detention—the three strikes legislation—was introduced. She was also the Premier of Western Australia when the Port Hedland detention facility was running. The Port Hedland detention centre was one of the tougher regimes, where people jumped off the roof, with some becoming paraplegics as a result. Where was Carmen Lawrence's conscience then? She has suddenly found a conscience. She is trying to pull the rug out from underneath her leader, and she is doing it with the blessing of a section of the Labor Party. The Labor Party know this, and they are embarrassed about it because they are divided on this issue.
The member for Lalor, the opposition spokesperson on this matter, wants to make some issue about four dissidents on the government side, and she has called them Liberal `moderates'. I do not think anyone wants to be called `moderate' in this world, but it is a term that has been slapped on them by the opposition. With regard to the so-called four `moderates', I was in last week's party room meeting—along with you, Mr Deputy Speaker Lindsay—and it was not raised. The difference between the Liberal Party and the Labor Party on this issue is that, once we have negotiated a position in our party room and in our forum, we stick to it. We do not go out and white-ant our leader or our minister—we speak with one voice.
I guarantee the member for Lalor that, today, not one person will cross the floor. If someone does, I will buy her a $100 lotto Quickpick. That is how confident I am that it will not happen. I wish she would demonstrate her confidence and offer me the same inducement. The bottom line is that, when the Liberal Party act on these issues, we act as one because we are one voice in relation to this. The Australian public want us to do the right thing regarding the integrity of our migration system.
Let us examine some of the elements of the issue. The member for Lalor said she wants two things: to compel the government to foster out unaccompanied children to families, and to provide families—with the exception of males over 18 years of age— with houses outside of detention centres. She went further and said that she would like to see all families repatriated into communities. This again shows the sheer hypocrisy of the Labor Party. Simon Crean has said that the Labor Party believes in detention, yet the watering down of this policy would mean that no-one would end up in detention. If the policy were not to split families, the only people who would be left in detention would be a handful of older men. If you were a creative smuggler, what would you do from now on? You would make sure you smuggled families. It is as simple as that. 
If the Labor Party were in government, smugglers would only need to smuggle families, because the Labor Party would house them in the community, with a marvellous electric beam surrounding Baxter which no-one could cross. If you believe in that sort of security, you believe in the tooth fairy. We know what security is like out there in the electorate at the moment. My office has been broken into five times in the last five weeks. The police got there within 10 minutes, but they were not there when it happened. Where was the security outside Woomera when the people broke out? You can talk about using a magic electric beam for security, but at what cost at the end of the day?
There is a very simple solution to this whole problem, and that is for the Labor Party to expedite our processing of people in detention so that they do not go through the huge raft of court appeals that they do in this country. We have had legislation before which proposed that the Migration Review Tribunal and the Refugee Review Tribunal should be the non-legalistic avenues for appeal and that these people should not be going through every level of court appeal in this country, right through to the High Court, at the taxpayers' expense. If the Labor Party were serious, they would help us tidy up this issue—but they are not serious.
One of the reasons that there is an opportunity to repatriate selected children and families is that there have been no new boat arrivals for well over 12 months. What does that say about the government's policy on this issue? It says that it is working. It is working, and the Australian public know it is working. The problem that the Labor Party have is that they have no credibility on this issue in the electorate. With regard to Simon Crean's leadership and the Labor Party's direction, Paul Kelly, the national affairs editor for the Australian, said in an article yesterday that the Australian people do not believe that the Labor Party can securely manage this country with respect to border protection, the war on terrorism and, particularly, migration and illegal entry. The Labor Party still have not convinced the electorate that they have the will and the wherewithal to protect Australia in this area.
The coy trick that the Labor Party are trying to pull today with these amendments will not stack up with the public because the public know that the Labor Party say one thing in opposition and then another thing in government—one thing before an election and another thing after. The Carmen Lawrences of this world say: `We're with you. We say nothing, we do nothing and we feel ashamed, but we are not going to do anything,' and after the election they break out and say, `No, no, no.' Just to show how genuine they are, before the election former senators Barney Cooney and Jim McKiernan said, `The legislation can go through but, if we happen to win government, we'll change it.' They are not here, but that was the sentiment of the Labor Party at that time—`We'll opportunistically support the government's border protection and migration legislation but, should we become the government, we'll change it all and water it down.'
In my electorate of Canning, I have little or no call on mandatory detention of children and families. In fact, people come up to me and say, `You tell that John Howard and Philip Ruddock that, if they ever back off on this, they have lost me'—this is Mr and Mrs Joe Public in the shopping centres. The public want us to show some resolve on this issue—and as a government we have. One of the reasons that we are here and the opposition are over there on the other side of this parliament is that the Australian people believe us. They believe John Howard and Philip Ruddock. They did not believe Kim Beazley, they do not believe Simon Crean and they do not believe that the Labor Party can run a decent migration program and protect this country. The argument that, through these amendments, the Labor Party can fix the system is just not going to wash with the Australian public. 
Labor have no credibility in the migration debate. They cannot get traction on any issue. When you see the sorts of questions that are thrown up in question time, you know that they are begging for today to finish because they have run out of steam. At the end of the day, they are trying to do a quick soft-shoe shuffle through this legislation to try to appease a number of groups. If you are out there trying to please everyone—which is what the Labor Party are trying to do on this—you will please no-one. You have the opposition spokesman and their leader saying one thing and then you have elements of the party in the lay organisation saying another. Carmen Lawrence says that she will take this legislation to the Labor Party national conference next year and get it overturned—that is how confident she is. Commentators reckon there is a chance she could even become the Labor Party national president over this issue. So where is the Labor Party on this issue? They are not with their political leadership on this. That is the problem Labor have.
The issue of housing families out in the community is something the Australian people just will not wear. The statistics show that, if you allow these people to be housed out in the community and do not send the signal that you are strong on detaining illegal immigrants—and they are illegal immigrants; people who, in most cases, have been assessed and found not to be refugees—they then do not present themselves for removal. We know that that is the case. We know that that has been the case in other countries. We know that, in Britain, when a determination is made and these people live out in the community, they cannot find them—the same as we cannot find the people who escaped from Woomera. Where are all those people? If they were genuine refugees, they would be presenting themselves for assessment. But, no—they evaporate into the community, with the help of some of the socialistic elements of this country. They then become a burden on the community and do not ever give anything back. 
You can see why some of these people should be removed. These are the people who bash guards at Port Hedland. These are the people who, when they get a determination against them, trash their facility—as happened in Christmas Island just the other day. Why would you want these sorts of people as Australian citizens? Compare this with what happened during the war with the Italian prisoners of war who were interned on farms in an area where I was brought up in the wheat belt of Western Australia. They worked and, when they were able, they went back to Italy. Many of them migrated back here and are farmers in that district today. They are the sorts of people we want in this country, not people who are going to trash the joint and act like thugs and criminals. At the end of the day, they have painted themselves into a corner.
In this debate, the minister does have flexibility. You do not think the people who would have been `handpicked'—as the member opposite said—for houses around Woomera were picked through a lottery or something like that, do you? These people would have been screened rather well to ensure that they were appropriate people to be housed outside the facility on a trial basis. The ability of the minister to have some jurisdiction and flexibility in this issue is paramount. You cannot just have a blanket law which says, `Out they all go,' and allow those with dubious status, military training in other countries and that sort of thing to be on the loose in the community.
At the end of the day, it is good that this legislation is being supported by the Labor Party in general. Their amendments are just tokenism because they know the Australian people do not support them. Please, if you really feel so strongly, let us have another election on this, because the sentiment in my electorate tells us that, at the end of the day, they want a government that is actually going to be decisive. Philip Ruddock, the minister, has hero status in my electorate. They say to me, `We just hope that guy doesn't get crook, because he is the sort of person we want to stay in the job because he's doing such a fine job with the integrity of the migration system in this country. We want him to actually stay in the post because we feel secure and comfortable with a government that is actually doing the job'—as our government is. The minister, Philip Ruddock, should be congratulated.

name: Snowdon, Warren, MP
text:
—I rise to speak on the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002. I will come to the member for Canning's contribution in a little while. I will perhaps point out to him some of the erroneous assumptions that underlie his contribution, but I will also point out the absurdity of his contribution.
—I won't be around to answer it.
—It is unfortunate that you will not be around. Just scurry out. The bill is a non-controversial omnibus bill. It seeks to amend and clarify the Migration Act 1958 in five major areas. It clarifies certain visa related matters by providing that a non-citizen child born in Australia is immigration cleared for the purposes of his or her birth entry if at least one of his or her parents is immigration cleared. This provision is backdated to 1 September 1994. The bill ensures that a special purpose visa ceases to be in effect immediately, rather than at the end of the day, if the minister declares it is undesirable for the non-citizen to travel to and enter Australia or remain in Australia, putting it beyond doubt that the rules of natural justice do not apply to the making of such a declaration. It ensures that a non-citizen who leaves and re-enters Australia on a bridging visa that allows such travel is subject to the section 48 bar on further applications. It ensures that certain offence provisions operate as they did prior to the application of the Criminal Code. Lastly, it applies strict liability to an offence against subsection 241(1) of assisting people to falsely appear to be de facto spouses for the purpose of the regulations so that one of them can get a stay visa.
It is not my intention to go through the detail of all of those proposals, because that was adequately done by the shadow minister. I do want to reflect on the Labor Party's amendments because they are, as the shadow minister pointed out, what this debate should be about. Our amendments will ensure that unaccompanied minors must be placed as quickly as possible in community care arrangements as determined by state government child protection agencies and that accompanied minors, with their families, must be placed as quickly as possible in a detention model like the Woomera alternate detention trial. 
I want to comment briefly, if I may, on the contribution of the member for Canning, because he railed against a light beam. Firstly, he clearly does not understand what the Woomera alternate detention trial is—one which the minister foreshadowed in his statement to the parliament last week he was prepared to extend—because the Woomera detention trial provides for women with children to be placed in residential accommodation with perimeter fencing and this beam of light. The beam of light is just that: a beam of light. It does not cause harm. But, clearly, the residents of these facilities understand that, if they cross that beam of light, they have transgressed and they have effectively fled from the accommodation. What the member said, of course, was that this was an absurdity. `Who in their right mind could believe that people would be detained by a beam of light?' That is, in effect, what he said. What he might want to do is inform himself of what the current provisions are in the alternate detention trial at Woomera. He might want to go to the minister and ask him for a briefing on what the alternate detention trial means, what the security requirements are in relation to that detention trial and how well it has worked. Because, as the shadow minister has said, there is not one example of an individual or group attempting to flee from this type of accommodation. That is precisely why the Labor amendments should be supported.
It is worthwhile again stating, as the shadow minister did, that the minister, in responding clearly to backbench concerns about the plight of children in detention, has made it very clear that it is his intention at some point to change the way in which they deal with families in detention. It is worth noting that, on 2 December, the Age reported:
Mr Ruddock is believed to have initially resisted the move because it was impractical, but dropped his objections under pressure from Mr Howard, who is concerned that some MPs may vote for Labor's amendments as a matter of conscience. 
I note that the shadow minister invited those dissident Liberal MPs—the members for Cook, Pearce, Hindmarsh and Kooyong—to sit with us on this side of the chamber later today, when this legislation is voted upon, to support the Labor Party's amendments—to act upon their conscience. Because it is clear, as the shadow minister pointed out, that the protection which is offered by these amendments is legislatively based to be far stronger than those proposals which would be, in effect, a directive to the immigration department.
I note that this `About-face on detention cent-res policy', which is the headline on the Age article of 2 December, named four pro-m-inent people, three of whom are members of this chamber. They are: the member for Kooyong; Mr Pyne, the member for Sturt; Bruce Baird, the member for Cook; and Sen-ator Marise Payne. I am not aware that any of those people have come into this chamber to make a personal explanation to refute this article. So what it says to me is that there is clearly a great deal of concern—as pointed out by the shadow minister—within the Liberal Party, at the highest level of government, about the possibility that people in the Liberal Party might actually act on their conscience. I would say to those people that they ought to take that opportunity to act on their conscience when this legislation is voted upon later this after-noon. I could spend the whole of the time avail-able to me berating the contribution made by the member for Canning, but I will not.
—Christmas is coming; we haven't got enough time.
—That is right; Christmas is coming and we do not have enough time. But I do want to say one thing. The member for Canning railed against the Labor Party for not assisting with expediting the processes dealing with asylum seekers. What the shadow minister has made plain to the minister and the government is that there is a standing offer to facilitate the passage of any legislation which comes into this chamber to facilitate and expedite processing procedures. There has not been one occasion when such measures have been brought into this place that the Labor Party have sought to block them.
I suggest that the member for Canning—and, I presume, other members of the government backbench—actually finds out the detail of what discussions have taken place, what has actually been said by Labor Party members in this chamber and what the Labor Party policy means. It is very clear, from the undertakings which have been given by the shadow minister, that, should the minister come into this place—should he be afraid of supporting our amendment today—with his own proposals to amend his legislation to give effect, in a similar way, to the proposals put forward by the Labor Party then we would support them. But he will not. That is the point that those dissident members, those members with a heart and conscience, within the Liberal Party ought to be contemplating.
Whilst we have heard from the member for Canning and will, no doubt, hear from others about the way in which the community is behind the attitude and policies of the government in relation to detention, frankly, I do not think that the community does support the proposal to keep children behind wire. When the Labor Party took the decision on Australia Day last year—as pointed out by the shadow minister—that we would remove the children from behind wire, there was derision from within the ranks of the Liberal Party. It is now clear that there are people with a conscience in the Liberal Party who accept now that this is a policy which they ought to be supporting and which they would like the Liberal Party to support. It was not just out of some political desire that we were making these statements and it was not because we wanted to win support within the community necessarily—although we believed that the community would support us in removing children from behind wire.
The fact is that it is not an appropriate way to deal with children or their families. There is a range of commentators who are expert in their own right in the emotional and psychological trauma which is caused to children and their families by such detention. For my sins, I am an ex-school teacher. I have to say that one of the joys of being a school teacher is working with young people and seeing them develop and be nourished. It is a great opportunity and it is a great job because you can see people growing. When you know that their families are behind them and giving them support, you can see them flourish in such a way that it gives you a great deal of pride. And they achieve greatness in their own ways. 
What we know about the way in which the government treats children in detention is that it stultifies their growth. It imposes extreme psychological stress upon them and their families. I would like to refer to an article by Rebecca Holmes in the Advertiser on 2 July this year. In this article she quotes Ros Powrie from the Australian Association for Infant Mental Health in relation to the issue of children in detention. She says that parents unable to provide life's essentials felt disempowered. The article says:
“The institutional effect on parents undermines their authority and their ability to care for their children,” Dr Powrie told the inquiry. “They cannot provide for their children's emotional needs when they are in a situation of deprivation themselves.”
This is why the government should be picking up the amendments being proposed by the Labor Party—not because it is politically cute; not because it is, somehow or other, manifestly popular within the community, but because it is the right thing to do.
I am a parent with four children. I cannot imagine any circumstance where I could, with my partner, properly look after our children in the situation which we know detainees are being held in in detention centres around Australia. Some are being held for lengthy periods of time. Any parent, including the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, knows what it means. If you have bought up children and if you have seen what psychological stress children are being placed under in these detention centres, how could you not have pity for them? How could you not seek to find the quickest way possible to end their suffering in terms of the pressures that they are under and the results of that pressure?
I would also like to refer to an article in the Australian on 17 July 2000. The article quotes Chris Sidoti, the federal Human Rights Commissioner. It says:
Detaining refugee children is a gross violation of human rights and “far worse” than mandatory sentencing for juveniles, federal Human Rights Commissioner Chris Sidoti will argue today.
This was in a context in which mandatory sentencing was a topic of hot debate, because mandatory sentencing existed in the Northern Territory. Chris Sidoti was quoted as saying:
“The numbers of children detained, the length of their detention and the fact that they are not accused, let alone convicted, of any crime make the commonwealth's actions in relation to child asylum seekers far worse than that of Western Australia and the Northern Territory in relation to juvenile offenders” ...
That speaks for itself. I am proud to say that, on coming to office last year, one the first actions of the ALP government in the Northern Territory was to end the mandatory detention of juveniles.
I could go on at length about the advice from commentators and professionals about this matter, but I want now to go to the Labor Party's policy. Before I commend that policy to the community, I want to express my deep appreciation to the shadow minister at the table, Julia Gillard, and to the Leader of the Opposition, Simon Crean, for the guts and determination they have shown in developing this policy—a policy which is well accepted by those who know about these things in the wider community, and I will come to those endorsements in a moment. Despite the criticism and the asinine comments from the government and critics within the media, the Labor Party now has a well thought out, cogent policy which provides the way ahead for the treatment of refugees and asylum seekers in Australia. It has only happened because of the shadow minister's diligence—her ability to be able to sit down and talk with and consult communities right around Australia, both inside and outside the Labor Party, and to be able to debate and nurture discussion within the Labor Party about these issues. The shadow minister knows that she and I have disagreed on aspects of this policy on its way through, but, on balance, we have a very good piece of public policy. 
It is true that there are critics, but it is worthwhile pointing out some of the people who endorse the policy of the Labor Party. It also needs to be understood that members of the government, particularly those people who feel concerned about the way in which the government is treating children and their families, should read the Labor Party's policy, particularly those sections of the policy dealing with freeing children and with detention, because the Labor Party makes it very clear that it is committed, via the amendments proposed today, to dealing appropriately and humanely with children and their families.
I want to refer to a document produced by Australians for Just Refugee Programs Inc., entitled `Labor leaves the Government exposed with cruel policies', and then refer to some of the members of this organisation. The document says:
It is a mark of how poor the Government's current programs are, that we acknowledge the following features as enormous improvements: 
That is, features of the Labor Party's policy—
·	A commitment to process 90% of asylum seekers within 90 days, with public scrutiny and review of any detention longer than that.
·	Abolition of the Refugee Review Tribunals, replaced with independent procedures for processing, review and monitoring of conditions.
·	Ending discrimination in the treatment of refugees according to how they arrive, particularly by providing support and security to those currently on temporary protection visas.
·	Ending the Pacific dumping of asylum seekers, and providing central processing on Australian soil, with those achieving refugee status settled in Australia.
·	Taking the pressure off Sydney and promoting refugee resettlement in welcoming regions of Australia.
·	Commitment to use humanitarian aid and international diplomacy to lead the world in reaching lasting solutions, not leaving the western world in worst practice.
·	Commitment to public debate based on fact is not vilification.
·	An end to the punitive and indefinite nature of detention, and setting standards which will be managed by an independent Inspector General.
This is not a cheer squad for the Labor Party. Let me identify some of members of this august organisation: Professor Peter Baume AO, a former member of this chamber and the Hon. Fred Chaney AO, former senator and member of this chamber—both former government ministers; Malcolm Fraser AC, former Liberal Prime Minister; the Hon. Nick Greiner AC, former Liberal Premier of New South Wales; John Hewson AM, former opposition leader in this chamber and a member of the Liberal Party; and Ian Macphee AO, Liberal Party member and former minister. This is not a cheer squad for the Labor Party. This gives light to those people on the government benches who believe that they need the support of other people in order to take a firm stand and follow their conscience and their convictions by supporting the Labor amendments this afternoon. There is support in the wider community for the Labor Party's position. There are a lot of people in the Liberal Party who now support Labor's position, and I invite those people with a conscience within the government to support the Labor amendments when they are voted on this afternoon.

name: Johnson, Michael, MP
text:
—I am delighted to speak on the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002. The previous speaker, the member for Lingiari, talked about the opposition coming up with `a well thought out, cogent policy which provides the way ahead'. One year later they come up with a policy and what happens? A shadow minister resigns from the front bench. That is the quality of the opposition's policy and what it is doing to the opposition. It is a divided opposition that does not know where it is going and, as reflected in the last election, unless it comes up with policies that are widely accepted by the Australian community, they are going to be on that side of the chamber for some time to come. It is a pleasure to speak in the debate on this bill because this issue is important to the people in my electorate of Ryan. It has raised a lot of interest in the community. I have received a lot of calls, letters and correspondence that overwhelmingly support the government's position. That is why at the last election the people of Ryan returned the seat to a Liberal member.  
I want to speak on a few of the provisions of this bill. This bill seeks to clarify visa related issues and to provide that non-citizen children born in Australia are immigration cleared for the purposes of their birth entry. It is important to clarify the immigration status of non-citizen children born in Australia because it has significant implications for a person's entitlements under the act. Another important provision authorises the taking of security for compliance with conditions to be imposed on a visa before a visa is granted. There are also important provisions concerning non-citizens who leave and re-enter Australia while on bridging visas. The section 48 bar will prevent such travel. We do not want the laws of this country abused. The provisions in this bill will play a big part in preventing abuse of certain existing provisions that are meant to limit the class of visa for people applying to come into this country. This bill also deals with the time limits, in terms of immigration clearance, imposed on non-citizens seeking revocation of the automatic cancellation of student visas and ensuring that decisions that do not revoke the cancellation are not reviewable. 
One of the less controversial provisions in the bill is the creation of a deputy principal member position for the Migration Review Tribunal. I would like to think that the opposition supports that provision. It ensures that certain offence provisions operate as they did prior to the commencement of the Criminal Code. There are a couple of technical amendments that bring the bill into line with the Commonwealth Criminal Code of 1995. 
As the Australian people appreciate, the coalition government are very committed to maintaining Australia's immigration program. It is important that we have the confidence of the Australian people in the security and integrity of our immigration program. We are going to run this program in the interests of the people of Australia. It is very important that the people of Australia appreciate that the program that regulates entry into Australia is managed efficiently and that the scarce resources of the Commonwealth government are being applied efficiently so that those who come into this country come in in the proper way, they come in legitimately and they do not abuse the Australian government's and people's reception and welcoming of them. This is a very generous country; it has played a big part in welcoming people. But, at the same time, we clearly have to do this to promote the national interest. The amendments in this bill will enhance the integrity of the act and ensure that certain provisions in the act operate as originally intended. 
One of the important things about legislation is that it should provide certainty. This bill and the amendments therein will contribute to that very strongly. I find it somewhat amusing that members opposite speak with professed authority against this bill, considering that a year ago the people of Australia voted very strongly and decisively to return the government when the opposition were all over the place and had no idea where they stood. The result speaks for itself. This government was returned with the full confidence of the Australian people. It is quite amusing that, one year on, the opposition has come up with a policy that has created more division and more frustration within their party. I know that the shadow minister responsible for this portfolio has a very strong, sincere and genuine interest in the field. I certainly respect her position on it. It is unfortunate that I have to disagree with much of her personal position on this bill. In terms of integrity, I know that she certainly has a very genuine interest in the field. 
It is very important that, when parliaments pass legislation, it is compatible with the national interest, the democratic process and the wishes of the people. It is not a case of pandering to certain special interest groups and lobby groups. What we are about is passing laws that are in the best interests of the country. Clearly, the government are doing that. That is why we were returned to government; that is why we have, and will continue to have, significant representation in the parliament.  
One of the steps the government and Minister Ruddock have taken is the restructuring of the immigration program. This has played an important part in gaining the confidence of the Australian people. We do not want people abusing the process. We do not want rorters coming in here. We do not want people smugglers having significant weight in deciding who comes into this country simply through the payment of money to them. One of the results of this government's migration policies has been the balancing and rebalancing of the economic and social benefits of immigration and the strengthening of our borders. The balance in our immigration intake is very important. 
The Australian public are not to be underestimated. They know where we stand. Decisive, strong policy is expected from the government. Policies that follow that position and are implemented will earn the respect and regard of the public. The government take a strong stand against people who come here illegally and stay illegally. We are talking about not only people who come into this country illegally but also people who come into this country legally and stay illegally. They have an obligation to meet legal requirements. If they come into the country legally then they should stay for the time allowed and not a day longer. If they wish to come in again then they need to fulfil the legal requirements that this parliament has set down.
I want to say a few words about my own background. That is why I have a particular interest in this field and why I am speaking to this bill. Like my colleagues on both sides of the chamber, I know that there are migrants in this parliament. I am one of them. I have been an Australian for over two decades. It is a great privilege to be an Australian. Those of us who are migrants consider it a great privilege to be Australian and to make a contribution to this country in our respective ways. 
This legislation reflects the policy and the philosophy of the government of doing the right thing by this country. It is very important that legislation passed by this parliament reflects the values of this country: tolerance, harmony and a multicultural disposition. This country is very tolerant, welcoming and respectful to individuals who come from different parts of the world, who have different backgrounds and who make a contribution to this country once they come here. But they come here in the proper way. They come here through the front door, compatible with the laws of this country. It is also important to say that those who bide their time and do the right thing—those who apply to come here by following the proper processes—are respected by this parliament when it passes laws compatible with that position.
I take the opportunity to commend the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs. The minister is doing a terrific job in his portfolio, and that can be seen in the community. Last week I had the pleasure of hosting a special morning tea for the minister in the Ryan electorate, at the St Lucia Bowling Club. He was overwhelmed with interest and support at the club. I was absolutely flabbergasted by the response from the community in terms of those who wanted to come along; it was an incredible turnout. Many residents had the opportunity to meet him, to talk to him, to see him in the flesh and to see that he is a very compassionate man who is doing a terrific job for the country and who has an enormous area of responsibility.
I quote one of the members of the bowls club, Mr Wayne George, who put this on the bowls club's web page in response to the minister's visit:
Mr. Ruddock gave the assembled audience the views and reasoning of his Government on several subjects, one being of most interest was that of illegal immigration, detention of illegal immigrants and the prevention of terrorists entering Australia illegally.
The Minister shed his television image and projected himself in a completely different light to which we are accustomed to seeing him. His 30 years in Federal Parliament has turned him into a very articulate orator and he showed himself to be a humorous, warm hearted person, the interests of the citizens of Australia being his prime objective. 
I say that again:
... the interests of the citizens of Australia being his prime objective.
I thank Mr Wayne George for putting that up on the St Lucia bowls club web site and for very kindly letting me know he had done so. He communicated that that had gone out to all the members and the community. I also thank the president of the St Lucia Bowling Club, Mr Ross Humphreys, for the warm hospitality we received.
This bill and its amendments are very important. I certainly encourage those opposite to support it. We pass laws in this country for the national interest, not for minority groups. It is regrettable that in the real world we sometimes have the situation where people are separated from their families but, at the end of the day, this government is about passing laws and regulations that are in the interests of this country and its citizens. This government passes laws and implements policies for the people's benefit but also with an eye to people's feelings and emotions.
One of the important things that the government does is take care of the people who are in detention centres. It is important to look after their basic day-to-day needs, such as food. Safety is paramount: their physical safety and, to a large degree, their emotional and mental safety—as much as is practical. There are also education services. The environment in which they are placed is not a five-star hotel—we all know that—but, at the end of the day, this government is doing what is right for the people of this country. Putting in place policies that may seem, on the face of it, unfortunate is the heavy onus on government. With the minister's heavy portfolio responsibilities, I am sure he has a very personal interest in knowing that his department and this government are regulating and putting in place very important policies that are consistent with the standards of the overwhelming majority of Australians.
The opposition are saying that their views and policies are accepted by the wider community. I would be very surprised if that were so. If they think the latest initiatives that they have come up with match the position of the broader community, then they are not in touch with what the overwhelming majority of our fellow Australians think. It is our job as members of this parliament and the job of the executive and the minister, when we come up with policies, to be in sync with the views of the people of Australia. The government are doing that; that is why we are in government. The opposition have a long way to go. They cannot even come up with policies that keep their frontbench satisfied, as we saw last Thursday with the resignation of a shadow minister. That is a reflection of the opposition's position and the turmoil within—and this is just one area of policy, a very important area. If they want to make progress in this parliament, then they certainly have a lot of work to do. They have to get out and talk to the people of Australia, not just to certain groups that have access to their doors.
That said, I again want to pay tribute to the integrity of the shadow minister. I know that she has a very genuine personal interest in this. Unfortunately, her policy position is not in sync with the overwhelming majority of the Australian people. Just ask the Australian people, shadow minister, and you will get their views. Go out there and talk to them about what they want from government in terms of policy on immigration and people coming into this country. We are a very tolerant and welcoming country. Our history and the track record of our country show that. Many new Australians have become members of this parliament, and that in itself says a lot about the majesty of our democracy and the great country in which we live.

name: Hoare, Kelly, MP
text:
—I appreciate the opportunity to speak on the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002 and I will be taking this opportunity to further expound on areas of migration policy. This particular bill was introduced into the House on 13 March 2002. On 20 March 2002 the Senate referred the bill to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee for inquiry and report by 15 May 2002. The bill makes a number of changes to the Migration Act 1958, and it was determined by that committee that the changes should be fully examined. 
The explanatory memorandum to this bill describes it as an omnibus bill dealing with the following matters. It clarifies certain visa related matters by providing that a non-citizen child born in Australia is immigration cleared for the purposes of his or her birth entry if at least one of his or her parents is immigration cleared. That provision is backdated to 1 September 1994. The bill ensures that a special purpose visa ceases to be in effect immediately rather than at the end of that day if the minister declares that it is undesirable for the non-citizen to travel to, enter or remain in Australia. This provision puts it beyond doubt that the rules of natural justice do not apply to the making of such a declaration. The bill ensures that a non-citizen who leaves and re-enters Australia on a bridging visa that allows such travel is subject to the section 48 bar on further applications. It also deals with ensuring that certain offence provisions operate as they did prior to the application of the Criminal Code, and it apples strict liability to one such offence: an offence against section 241(1) of assisting people to falsely appear to be de facto spouses for the purposes of the regulations so that one spouse can get a stay visa.  
The member for Lalor has detailed the bill quite eloquently. In the member for Lalor's contribution to this debate, she foreshadowed Labor's amendment. We will be insisting on our amendment, which will require that unaccompanied minors be placed as quickly as possible in community care arrangements—as determined by state government child protection agencies—and that accompanied minors with their families be placed as quickly as possible into detention on a model such as the Woomera alternate detention trial. 
The Howard government's claims that asylum seekers threw children overboard were untrue. The Howard government's policies in this area, and in particular the so-called Pacific solution, are no solutions at all. Labor offer the Australian people real solutions in this area. On Australia Day, Labor leader Simon Crean announced that a Labor government would ensure that children were not kept behind razor wire in formal detention centres. In April, Labor agreed to four major steps for Labor in government and, in the meantime, we have urged the government to take these steps as well. The four steps are: to mothball the Woomera Detention Centre, as recommended by the Immigration Detention Advisory Group; to put the public sector back in control of detention centres; to lift the shroud of secrecy and allow media into detention centres; and to enter into a proper time limited safe haven arrangement for asylum seekers from Afghanistan and extend the voluntary repatriation arrangements. 
Members of the government have taken quite some time outlining the difficult processes that the Labor Party has gone through this past year. I join the member for Lingiari in congratulating the shadow minister at the table and Labor leader Simon Crean for coming up with a policy recommendation which is humane, which addresses the concerns a lot of us had and which we are quite comfortable in promoting and supporting in our community. As I said, it was a difficult decision. The member for Ryan talked about consultation, but he is not party to our party discussions and would not know that the shadow minister and all of us in our caucus consulted widely and effectively to come up with Labor's policy, which was announced just last week. 
Last week, on 5 December, the Leader of the Opposition and the member for Lalor released Labor's policy for asylum seekers and refugees. The policy is good. It addresses the treatment of asylum seekers with dignity and the protection of Australia's borders. It also proposes a new processing system. We outlined a number of additional ways refugees will be treated in an Australian way. Labor will run a fast, fair and transparent processing regime that determines 90 per cent of claims in 90 days. Genuine refugees will be quickly identified and released, while failed claimants will be quickly returned. Labor will administer better health checks and ASIO security checks. Those people whose claims have merit and who are ASIO security cleared, health cleared and who pose no risks will be able to live in hostel style accommodation. Labor will create an independent inspector-general of detention who will monitor detention conditions and resolve complaints. Labor will have an expert committee that will review or make recommendations on any case in which a person is detained for more than 90 days. 
There are refugees in Australia who, under current laws, may be here for a lifetime but who will never be eligible for family reunion. Labor will not maintain such a system. Labor will replace this system with a short-term temporary protection visa, after the expiry of which a genuine refugee can access a permanent protection visa. We will facilitate the settling of genuine refugees in parts of Australia where they will be welcome and are needed. Regional communities that want to increase their population through having refugees settle there will be able to do so under Labor's regional settlement plan and will receive targeted resources to assist them. I will be encouraging the release of appropriate funding for infrastructure support so that Lake Macquarie and Newcastle can make good their recent resolutions to welcome refugee families into our local communities. It is essential that migrants have access to health services, English language lessons, orientation services, interpreting and translating services, Job Network information, training assistance, social services, referral services and advice. It is essential that we employ flexible support programs that ensure such services are available where they are needed. We need to encourage local government organisations, non-profit organisations, educational institutions and community groups to establish formal or informal support networks that work in conjunction with government agencies. In other words, we must recognise that regional migration is a win-win situation.
One of the main aspects of Labor's policy is to propose a fairer worldwide system for refugees by having the world adopt one processing system for refugee claims. Under a Labor government, Australia would lead by example to pilot a processing regime which, we will advocate, should be adopted globally. Christmas Island will be the prime asylum seeker processing and detention facility. We will monitor the return of failed asylum seekers—something which my branch members have been calling on the government to do for quite some time. We will increase the funding to the UNHCR to $25 million per annum in order to better assist those who live and often die in refugee camps overseas. We will boost aid to address the issues that cause people to move, such as poverty, natural disasters, conflict and environmental degradation. We will increase aid to countries of first asylum to facilitate the development of a system of return of asylum seekers.
Another proposal in Labor's recently announced policy is to introduce a US style green card to crack down on illegal workers, to ensure that they are not stealing Australian jobs and undermining the pay and conditions of Australian workers. We will smash people-smuggling rings through tougher policing, including stationing more AFP officers in Indonesia, and we will impose harsher penalties for people smugglers. We will focus on eradicating people-trafficking for the purposes of sexual or other exploitation, as well as people-smuggling. We will better protect our airports and seaports. These steps are in addition to our recently announced $600 million Australian coastguard proposal.
I am pleased to have had the opportunity over this past week to inform my constituents of this policy—a policy which I wholeheartedly support. In our policy, Labor vows to provide short-term temporary protection visas which are not ongoing, as they have been over the years.
