Since October 1999, refugee claimants who arrive in Australia without authorisation have been granted not permanent protection visas but three-year temporary protection visas which significantly limit their entitlements to settlement services and other welfare support. Since October 1999, over 7,500 people have been granted a temporary protection visa. They have come predominantly from Afghanistan and Iraq, with smaller groups from Iran, Sri Lanka and other `usual suspect' countries that engage in the persecution of their citizens.
In 2000 the Refugee Council of Australia raised many concerns about temporary protection visas, and since then those concerns have been confirmed. Labor's policy goes a long way to addressing those concerns. The Refugee Council of Australia's concerns about temporary protection visas included the issue of long-term welfare dependency. People who are refugees are desperate to get work and to support their families. Under the restrictions of the temporary protection visa, these people have not been able to do that, including during the regime of detention. The lack of family reunion opportunities under a temporary protection visa was another main concern of the Refugee Council of Australia. As I said, those visas have been ongoing under this government. Labor vow to make temporary protection visas short term and limited. 
We have had endorsements of our policy over the last week or so from Australians for Just Refugee Programs Inc. Howard Glenn, National Director of the A Just Australia campaign, said:
We welcome a policy that shows much greater regard to respect, decency and traditional Australian generosity to those in need, while still advancing Australia's national interests, security and international standing.
The policy is a major shift. It will be welcomed as an improvement by much of the constituency that has come together under our banner. It still suffers from the fear and insecurity in the community that the Government has whipped up—too little compassion and too much sense of threat.
The Brotherhood of St Laurence welcomed the revised ALP policy `as a significant shift towards more humane treatment of vulnerable people that addresses major concerns with current policies'. The Refugee Council of Australia welcomed the announcement of the new ALP refugee policy. David Bitel, President of the Refugee Council, said:
At last we have seen a break away from the bipartisan approach to refugee policy that has stultified creative thinking and has led to the development of policies and practices that have been the subject of considerable criticism from within Australia and internationally.
In outlining and detailing Labor's amendments to this bill to get children out from behind the razor wire, the member for Lalor referred to the minister's and the Prime Minister's backflip on this issue last week, under pressure from the small `l' liberals. To emphasise that backflip, in August, when the Prime Minister was questioned about the proposal of the government's immigration detention advisory group to expand the Woomera alternative detention trial to family groups, he responded: 
We have tried the idea of having them out in the community with their mothers and the reaction has been that they don't want to be separated from their fathers. And if you put the whole family out the danger is they just melt into the community ...
...				...				...
... our view remains that if you go beyond having your mother and children then you do run the risk that people abscond ...
In responding to that statement from the Prime Minister, the member for Lalor said:
The Woomera Alternate Detention Trial consist of four former defence force homes on a block. The perimeter is secured and security personnel are always present in an work from one of the houses. Up to 25 women and children have lived in the other houses.
Labor has been campaigning for six months to get the children out from behind the razor wire by building on and enhancing this trial program.
That is why we will be insisting on our amendment. To reiterate, the amendment that we are moving, supporting and insisting on amends the power to detain under the Migration Act, so that unaccompanied minors must be placed as quickly as possible in the community care arrangements as determined by state government child protection agencies, and accompanied minors with their families must be placed as quickly as possible in a detention model like the Woomera alternative detention trial.
I would like to take just a couple of moments to reflect on refugees and, in particular, on the World Refugee Day for 2002, which focused on women and children. There are approximately 50 million uprooted people around the world—refugees who have sought safety in another country and people displaced within their own country. Between 75 and 80 per cent of them are women and children. The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees cares for about 21.8 million of these people, and around half of them are women and girls.
As this is the last day of the parliament sitting for 2002 and we are talking about refugees, I would like to take the opportunity to urge the Prime Minister and members of the government to take the next month or so to reflect on the ravages of war and on any Australian contribution which may be requested following the weapons inspectors carrying out their operations in Iraq. The majority of people who flee their homes do so because of war, and the proportion of war victims who are civilians has leapt in recent decades from five per cent to over 90 per cent of casualties. Eighty per cent of casualties by small arms are women and children, who far outnumber any military casualties. I ask the Prime Minister to reflect on the fact that, if Australia agrees to support America in a war against Iraq, it is not the Prime Minister's children who will be going, and it is not my children who will be going; it is the children of our constituents, of the people whom we are elected to represent here. We are elected to represent their interests, and I know that the interests of my constituents do not involve sending their children halfway around the world to a war which Australia has no right to be a part of.

name: Gambaro, Teresa, MP
text:
—I also rise to speak in support of the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002. The principal purpose of this omnibus bill is to amend the Migration Act 1958 and, in effect, change some of the aspects of the Australian legal regime with regard to visas and providing greater clarity. In addition, it will create a new position—one that is much needed—for the Migration Review Tribunal: a deputy principal member. It will also remove some of the ambiguities surrounding certain offence provisions. One of the principal areas of change that the bill is directed towards relates to immigration clearance of non-citizen children born in Australia. If a non-citizen enters Australia at a prescribed place or port and provides evidence of their identity and a visa, then that leaves them with the permission of the clearance officer—unless it is directed to an immigration detention—and then that person is said to have immigration clearance. The other instance where a non-citizen can have immigration clearance is when they are initially refused or bypass immigration clearance but are subsequently granted a substantive visa.
Contained within Australian migration legislation is a clear distinction between immigration clearance and entry and, effectively, between non-citizens who are lawful and those who have immigration clearance. Under the migration regulations 1994, a non-citizen's access to a visa can be affected by an immigration clearance. Consequently, having immigration clearance has also had an impact on non-citizens' entitlements as defined under the Migration Act 1958. Immigration clearance affects immigration detention. If an unlawful non-citizen arrives in a migration zone without a visa, they must be detained. A non-citizen with immigration clearance can also be detained if they are likely to evade or not cooperate with immigration officers. It also affects non-citizens' access to visas in relation to rules in safe third countries. As well as the cancellation of visas, it does not apply if the visa holder has a permanent visa and has had immigration clearance.
One of the objectives of this bill is to clarify an anomaly that currently exists between the notion of birth entry and the requirement that entry must be at a port or a prescribed place. This is an area that was raised by the International Commission of Jurists in their submission to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee and revolved around the immigration clearance definition of a child as being covered by the visa of his or her parents when born to a person who is not immigration cleared. A child who is born in Australia but who does not have citizenship is taken to hold the visa on a similar basis to his or her parents. In effect, the birth entry of a non-citizen child appears to offend section 43 of the act as it stands. Therefore, the change proposed for subsection 173(2) would be to state that these non-citizen children are not to be taken by virtue of their birth to have entered Australia in a way that contravenes section 43.
At the outset of my discussion on this bill, I spoke of the change in the membership of the Migration Review Tribunal. The deputy principal member would be placed between the principal member and senior members of the tribunal. Immigration is a very significant feature of the Australian way of life and the way that we live, eat, work and play. The proposed changes as contained in this bill will assist to clarify and provide greater certainty for the volume of people who arrive in this country. In addition, the bill clarifies the circumstances surrounding the birth of children in migration zones and their status as reflected by the visa status of their parents. Another feature of the bill is the harmonisation of the Criminal Code in relation to migration. As the minister stated in his second reading speech: 
Schedule 5 to the bill ensures that certain offence provisions in the act operate as they did prior to the commencement of the Commonwealth Criminal Code.
The act currently contains offences that relate to the unlawful entry of non-citizens. While non-citizens can arrive in Australia without a visa and not commit an offence, it is an offence for a person to be involved in bringing non-citizens into this country. The changes to the act are contained in the bill and they provide a clearer framework in relation to the evidential burden with regard to exceptions to some people for smuggling offences, particularly in relation to the reversed onus of proof and strict liability.
I would like to speak about some of the amendments the opposition intend to move. One of those is an amendment to section 196 of the act and is both quite unnecessary and pretty much nonsensical. Section 196(1) reads: 
An unlawful non-citizen ... must be kept in immigration detention until he or she is: 
(a) removed ...
(b) deported ... or 
(c) granted a visa.
The amendment calls for a further exemption to immigration detention if a person is `(d) released in accordance with section 198'. Section 198 is the removal power. Section 196 already provides for release from immigration detention in these circumstances. They also propose to amend the bill to create a section 197D in relation to unaccompanied minors. That amendment deals with unaccompanied minors, of whom the minister is the guardian, and would require the minister to release them from immigration detention. The minister in this instance would have no discretion as to appropriate welfare arrangements for these children, and it is really important that their welfare considerations be brought into this. They would effectively be barred from consideration for placement in, for example, the Woomera Residential Housing Project, where a close female relative would be caring for them.
Also, amendment 197D is very inconsistent with the framework of the Migration Act—the very act that Labor introduced in 1994. In the act, every non-citizen in mainland Australia must be lawful or held in immigration detention until they are removed or granted a visa. The proposed amendment does not indicate that unaccompanied minors are to be granted a visa, nor when such arrangements are to commence or cease. Within the current legislative framework, the government is already able to make appropriate care arrangements for unaccompanied minors. This amendment is unnecessary. All it does is make the system much more inflexible.
I want to talk about the programs that currently exist. The opposition has talked frequently about placing women and children in alternative arrangements, and that is something that this government has been doing for a very long time. There is no doubt that, after a period of unprecedented boat arrivals in 1999 and 2000, there was a huge and unexpected increase in minors arriving in Australia. The focus of this government's policy has been not only on meeting the day-to-day needs of those minors—their basic needs, such as accommodation, nutritious food, physical and mental health services, and education—but also on practical issues. There have been many cases of unaccompanied minors arriving here, and procedures for handling those arrivals have been improved. On 3 December 2002, the government formally announced that it would be in the best interests of unaccompanied minors that they be transferred to an alternative place of detention in the community or, if eligible, be released on a bridging visa as soon as possible after arriving at a detention centre. Until that occurs, it is essential that unaccompanied minors' needs be assessed and met. The minister is to be praised for the work he has been doing in this area. Long before the Woomera project was announced, many of my colleagues and I on the backbench committee spoke to him frequently about alternative projects for women and children, and I am glad to see that he has taken those up. 
I would like to talk about the policies on unaccompanied minors in immigration detention centres. The government has worked very hard in this area developing a number of policies, and they have been operating since 11 January 2002. The comprehensive policy that was announced deals with the duty of care and the responsibility of detention centre providers and DIMIA managers to unaccompanied minors. It also looks at a whole range of welfare and care issues with unaccompanied minors. This particular policy looks at the transfer and reception of minors, individual management plans, mentoring from within the detainee community and such things as family tracing. It looks at their health and medical treatment, their visa application assistance and legal representation. It has also looked at recent allegations of abuse and neglect, as well as release from detention on bridging visas and alternative places of detention. The government has also been responsible for ensuring that the level of care and conditions be met in caring for unaccompanied minors. It also accepts the policy on unaccompanied minors and alternative places of detention et cetera.
I want speak about some of the very good arrangements that are in place, particularly at the Woomera Residential Housing Project. The minister announced that the government would expand the criteria for the eligibility of women and children who participated in the alternative detention arrangements. This means that women and children may now be eligible for participation in this project while their cases are being considered by the Refugee Review Tribunal or the courts, and that is a very good thing. In terms of places of detention for detainees with special needs, which includes women and children, within the framework of mandatory detention and the Migration Act the government has been doing some very good work in continuing to take innovative approaches to looking after women and children in detention centres. The minister recently released the formal guidelines and they are working well out there in the community.
In the Woomera project, women and children have volunteered to be considered for the alternative detention arrangements trial; they are living in a housing environment within the township. In March 2002, a report on the effectiveness of the trial was conducted and provided to the minister. It found that it was rather costly but that it had been a success. I was very pleased, as a member of that backbench committee and as chair of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration, to see that that trial had been done in Woomera and that it was operating well. The minister has also looked at extending the alternative detention arrangements for women and children, and community consultation will take place in Woomera concerning the expansion of that housing project. He has also spoken to the South Australian government about options for the development of a residential housing project in Port Augusta or Whyalla, and community consultations will take place if agreement in principle is achieved with Premier Rann. It is good to see that those things are happening. The minister is to be applauded for the work he has done on these housing projects, and I am very pleased to see that there is a good possibility that they will be extended.
I know the opposition speak about keeping family units intact, but at the moment I think it would be very difficult to look at the inclusion of fathers in this particular program for security reasons and the increased risk that families would abscond. There is a very real risk of that and there is also the possibility that it would be inappropriate culturally, amongst some detainees, for men to be detained in a residential environment along with unrelated women. It is an issue that really needs to be considered. It is really good to see that some state governments are doing their bit in ensuring that children in detention centres are able to take part in education—but some state governments, unfortunately, are not. It is good to see that a number of children are attending government schools in the community. The minister has had a very active involvement, particularly with the governments of New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia, to ensure that detainee children are able to attend public schools. That is a terrific thing. For many of those detainee children, access to schools in the community will be very beneficial. On 21 November 2002, there were approximately 139 children in detention and 100 of them were of school age. Forty-nine are currently attending government or non-government schools in the community, and that is a good very thing indeed. 
There are states that have been less than cooperative and they have been doing everything they can to ensure that this does not occur. I note that the minister has been working very closely with the South Australian government. It was hoped that they would be cooperative and that some sort of arrangement or memorandum of understanding would take place. But, sadly, the Premier's decision is a great disappointment for those children in the Baxter complex. I have to applaud the minister's work. It is important to note that a number of detainee children are in mainstream schools; it is not a new development for this government. The opposition claim it is something new that they have thought up, but this has been going on since 1998. Some primary school age children have been at Maribyrnong as early as 1998. Some have been attending Catholic schools under local arrangements for detainee children from Curtin detention centre from as early as February 2001. That number increased to 13 children prior to Curtin's closure. Most of the detainee children at Port Hedland commenced at the local Catholic school in April this year. Twelve unaccompanied minors in alternative places of detention, under the care of the South Australian Department of Human Services, attend schools in the community in Adelaide. That is a very good thing to see.
The amendments the opposition are putting up are likely to increase litigation not decrease it, as people will seek to establish that they are unaccompanied minors to enable their mandatory release from detention centres, especially in circumstances where they arrive without documentation. There are many cases where we have had that happen recently. There also does not seem to be a mechanism that will ensure that the child agrees to the placement or that their best interests are considered. There are also legal obligations: to place them in foster care, without qualification, would be inconsistent with the government's obligation to certain unaccompanied minors. The minister would be held increasingly liable for any harm that would occur to a child who was released under section 197D. Again, this relates to the issue of increased litigation. There are also health and security risks. Some of the opposition's policies, particularly regarding their 90-day rules, would be impossible to implement in terms of health checks which are comprehensive and can take a considerable amount of time. Many cases are currently being held up in tribunals because of the difficulty of making sure that we have adequate health checks.
Under this proposed amendment, there is also no clear authority to supervise the removal of children from Australia. Under the proposed amendment to section 197E, there would be a requirement that all family members be accommodated with the child in the same conditions as apply to the Woomera residential project. This would considerably reduce the flexibility under the current legislative framework to address the specific needs of detainees. The government has used a variety of different alternative detention arrangements to tailor the needs of individual families and of individuals, but what the opposition is proposing would introduce a `one size fits all' approach. Clearly, there are families with different circumstances and different needs, and so that would not serve their purposes at all. The proposed amendment to section 197E would become a pull factor by encouraging adults to bring children with them when considering unlawfully entering Australia. The proposed amendment also assumes that the risk of absconding from low-security detention arrangements is the same for all families, whatever their circumstances.
There are some other problems with the proposed amendment. It does not take into account the practical limitations and the high cost of such arrangements if they are to be implemented in Australian cities, nor does it take into account that sufficient appropriate accommodation would be very difficult to identify and find. There would be no distinction between short-term compliance places, many of which are in cities, and longer-term detainees. So there are a number of factors that the opposition really does need to consider and there are a lot of ambiguities. It is also not clear which family members the opposition wants this to extend to. Are the opposition talking about immediate family members? Are the opposition talking about extended family members? That really needs to be considered. I support the government's approach. (Time expired)

name: Ferguson, Martin, MP
text:
—I rise to speak on the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002 and the manner in which it impacts specifically on special purpose visas and the maritime industry. In doing so, I take this opportunity to expose the Howard government's blatant favouritism for foreign ships off our coast and the impact that has on the employment of Australians. Special purpose visas are issued to seafarers on foreign vessels engaged in international voyages. Given the global nature of the trade, that is understood and accepted because this visa type is a practical mechanism to accommodate the international workplace and the movement of seafarers. I argue very rigorously that the original intent of these visas is being subverted to meet the Howard government's short-sighted, ideologically based approach to Australia's shipping policy. The truth of the matter is—and the industry knows this on both the employers' and the workers' side—that the Howard government has a strong preference for foreign ships and foreign workers, to the detriment of Australian workers and their families and to the detriment of our domestic transport task.
As the Minister for Transport and Regional Services and Deputy Prime Minister calls it, this shipping policy is supposedly aimed at liberalising the coastal trade. I argue that it is more aimed at destroying Australian jobs and training opportunities and, in doing so, propping up foreign shipping companies and the unfair competitive advantage given to them by a range of tax measures and the substandard wages and conditions of employment imposed by the operators of these foreign shipping vessels. This is simply a code for a commitment to reduce shipping costs by giving foreign shipping operators major concessions not enjoyed by the Australian shipping industry and not enjoyed by Australian workers and their families. Put simply, the government is misusing a range of legislative instruments as part of this liberalisation strategy. 
The cabotage provisions of the Navigation Act are, without a doubt, being bypassed through the use—or, more correctly, the misuse—of single voyage and continuing voyage permits. As everybody in the shipping industry knows, these permits are historically intended to be used when no Australian ship is available. But that test is loose. It is about integrity and honesty in the application of the historic principle that applied to the issue of single voyage and continuous voyage permits—well-founded and understood principles which have been largely ignored by the Howard government since the 1996 election. This is not my view only: more importantly, independent statistics bear this out beyond any doubt. 
Let us take a few examples of those statistics. Let us place the facts before the House. In 1995-96, 421 single voyage permits were issued. Alternatively, in 1997-98, with a change of government, under the Howard government the number of single voyage permits jumped from 421 to 779. Clearly, this was a policy decision pursued by the Howard government which was aimed at making sure that foreign vessels—with major tax concessions granted by foreign governments, exploiting ordinary seafarers who pursue an international employment opportunity—were being brought in to undermine Australian shipping companies and destroy Australian jobs. As far as I am concerned, that is un-Australian and the Howard government stands condemned.
I also know for a fact that there are serious concerns about the manner in which some of these visas are being issued within the department of immigration. It raises serious issues about failures by the Howard government, under the guise of shipping policy, to pay adequate attention to the all-important issue of checking character, especially in the context of the current major fears about international terrorism. 
Let us move on. We have difficulties not only with single voyage permits but also with what are known as continuing voyage permits. What do the facts show? Prior to 1996 not one continuous voyage permit was issued. In 1999-2000 this jumped to 73 permits. These continuing voyage permits are issued and re-issued for periods of six months. It gets worse—the figures continue to rise. Total cargo moved under single and continuing voyage permits rose by 32 per cent in the year 2000-01. I know, from talking to operators in the transport industry, including the road and rail sectors, that not only is this government policy denying Australian seafarers opportunities for employment; it is undermining employment in the road and rail sectors of the Australian land transport industry. So the policy in terms of employment and all the opportunities that are associated with that, to the great advantage of Australia, has been reduced by the Howard government to one aimed at destroying the Australian shipping industry and the livelihood of workers who have pursued work in that industry for many years, many of whom also operate in regional Australia in land and rail transport.
The operators of these vessels are using the permit system to bypass the requirement to be a licensed ship to operate in the coastal trade in Australia. Let us put it fairly and squarely. This bypassing of security and responsibility in the context of the current major debate about terrorism and so-called border protection is being engineered by the Howard government for vested interests, not in the national interest. The responsibility of this parliament is always to front up to the issue of what is in the nation's best interests.
This takes me to the second critical area. Legislative instruments are being misused and manipulated to suit the Howard shipping policy with respect to immigration law, which is central to the debate before the House this afternoon in the form of the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002. When we come to the issue of migration law, most members on this side of the House understand the importance of character checks and health checks, but for the Howard government the importance of those issues does not extend to its shipping policy. That is a shame, as the shadow minister for immigration and multicultural affairs says. Time and again we see ministers, from the Prime Minister down, stand at the dispatch box and give lectures to the Australian community about the importance of maintaining the integrity of the immigration system in Australia—an orderly process supposedly in the nation's best interests. Why do the nation's best interests not extend to shipping policy in Australia under the Howard government? 
The special purpose visa provisions are being misused—and everyone knows it, including the department of immigration, which unfortunately is not able to stand up to the department of transport—because of the desire by the government to prop up the non-performing minister for transport. Change should occur with respect to the issuing of these visas to foreign crews and foreign ships coming into Australia. I encourage the minister for immigration to take a stand on these issues, because he is prepared to consider change aimed at maintaining the security of the migration system in Australia. There is one fundamental flaw in that system when it goes to the operation of the shipping industry in Australia. Foreign crews do not need to make an application for a special purpose visa, and there is no department record of who they are issued to. We are supposedly so vitally concerned about character and health checks that to get a special purpose visa a foreign crew member merely has to be—surprise, surprise!—on the crew list. This crew list is far more important than a mere list of speakers in a House debate. This crew list of people coming to Australia without proper character checks throws up serious questions about the integrity of the migration system in Australia and, far more importantly at this point, about whether we are bringing in terrorists from overseas who can do damage to Australia's national interests. In this regard I quote an answer to a question on notice from the member for Stirling. In this answer the minister for immigration advised as follows:.  
Provided a crew member is on the crew list of a ship engaged in commercial trade or carriage of passengers that enters Australia at a proclaimed port, the crew member will be taken to hold a Special Purpose Visa.
I should clarify at this point that a special purpose visa gives the holder full access to Australia through that port, through that point of entry. They are free to leave the vessel and they are free to move around in the Australian community. The minister has also advised that crew lists are transmitted to the Australian Customs Service, which supposedly undertakes checking against Customs and DIMIA alert lists.
For the right reasons, because it is in Australia's national interests, the opposition clearly and squarely has strong reservations about that advice. There are serious questions about the checking processes, or the lack of adequate checking processes, for these crew lists. If we are genuinely concerned about taking on the international fight against terrorism and also maintaining our borders, it is about time that this glaring difficulty in the Australian system is fronted up to by the Howard government. National interests must always come before the ideological short-term views of the Howard government in its approach to shipping policy in Australia. Everyone out there knows that the procedures are so open that you could drive a truck through them. The Howard government talks tough on border security when there is an election but will not address obvious flaws, problems and weaknesses, because it does not suit its policy to favour foreign ship operators.
Special purpose visas do not attract a charge. Every other visa category issued has a charge attached but not special purpose visas, because they are a special deal to back up the shipping industry, which is what special purpose visas are about. Special purpose visas are not evidenced as most other visas are and holders are subject to streamlined immigration clearance procedures. A non-citizen can hold a special purpose visa and another substantive visa at the same time. Interestingly, this is not possible with any other visa category. The immigration laws are being undermined to prop up a shipping policy that favours foreign operators over Australian shipping companies and workers. It is not a level playing field.
Foreign seafarers are not subject to all the normal migration processes that apply to other people working in Australia. If a non-citizen wants to come to Australia to work in another domestic industry, such as farming, they must apply for a work visa. The fundamental tests that are applied relate to the skills shortage list: no Australian worker should be available to fill the position; wages and conditions must be in line with the awards system; the applicant must have English language skills; and the employer must undertake training. These tests are part and parcel of bringing in overseas workers, under the right conditions, to be employed in Australia. These are the tests that apply to other industries: why not the Australian shipping industry?
In essence, this is a government that talks tough on border protection but is not acting on maritime security or in Australia's national interests. The risks associated with the situation are real—let us not kid ourselves. In the past three years alone, 177 foreign crew jumped ship in Australia, and the Howard government suggests it is not a problem. Where is the action to stop that in a determined way and close that gaping hole in our border? Over one month ago, the United States' houses of parliament endorsed far-reaching new maritime security provisions, but the Howard government again has sat idle. This is a bit like its lack of attention over the last 12 months to aviation security, but I suppose the announcements of yesterday are better late than never. As I said, we have had the same problem on aviation and airport security. I remind the House that the Audit Office sent a warning shot in respect of aviation security back in 1998. Only yesterday the government acted. Border protection is something you talk about when you are in a little bit of political strife; it is not something you do in the nation's best interests.
The bill before us provides an opportunity to clamp down on special purpose visas in the interests of Australian security, but it has not happened. The government has no credibility on maritime security and the bill confirms that. Instead we have a government that approaches maritime security not on the basis of what is in the nation's best interests but on the basis of an ideological class war, because it is blinded by ideology. When I raised the issue of ship jumpers in the House earlier this week, what was the response from the minister? Not to say, `I'll examine that problem and do something', but merely to resort, as he always does, to union bashing. It is a disgrace. It is time the Howard government stopped tolerating lax immigration laws to prop up a campaign for cheaper shipping costs at the expense of Australian workers and their families. 
In conclusion, I strongly support the amendment to be moved by the shadow minister for immigration, the member for Lalor, with regard to taking children and families out from behind the razor wire. The Leader of the Opposition took the lead on this matter in his Australia Day speech this year. The shadow minister and the Leader of the Opposition are to be congratulated for taking tough decisions based on our national interests by way of the amendment to be moved by the member for Lalor today. I call on the government to take the same approach to maritime security. (Time expired)

name: Hartsuyker, Luke, MP
text:
—I rise in the House today to speak on the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002. This is a very important bill, as throughout our history migrants have contributed to the success of this nation. I note that the member for Ryan mentioned his migrant background, and I would certainly like to commend him on the contribution that he has made to our country, both before entering politics and as a member of the coalition government.
Our migrants have provided a wealth of skills and have created the cultural diversity which we enjoy today. Our migrants have been engineers, builders, chefs, teachers, doctors and farmers. They have contributed to all areas of our society. This government have maintained a balanced migration policy under the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs. The government balance the need for a skilled migration program, a family reunion program and a compassionate immigration program for purposes such as refugee intake.
The government have taken a firm stance on the issue of illegal immigration, and certainly this government have championed the cause for those people who seek to come to this country legally. They have certainly worked very hard to ensure that those who seek to come to this country legally are not disadvantaged at the hands of those who seek to come to the country illegally—those who seek to jump the queue and overtake people who have been waiting for quite some time for the opportunity to come to this wonderful country.
The government have upheld our sovereign right to determine who comes to this country and under what conditions. That is something that has attracted the overwhelming support of the people of Australia. Certainly at the last election they showed at the ballot box their overwhelming endorsement for the current stance of this government: for the idea that people who come to this country legally should have precedence over those who seek to come to the country illegally, and for the idea that this country should have the right to choose who comes to join us and work in this very fine land.
The opposition, by contrast, have flip-flopped repeatedly. They flip and they flop—we never seem to know where they are coming from. They are jumping from one place to another and it is very uncertain, very hard to pin them down—until recently, when something really amazing happened. After a year in opposition they released a policy. Out of that policy void that is the ALP, finally something appeared. Very interesting indeed. They finally released a policy. But what does this policy do? What is the actual effect of this policy? It weakens our stance on people-smuggling. It sends a signal that Australia is going to be open for business and that it is going to be a destination for people smugglers again, under the ALP. It sends a signal that a Labor government would unwind the current government's firm but effective stance on illegal immigration. 
We all know that the member for Fremantle does not support the current policy as espoused by the opposition, and we are not sure about the member for Grayndler. It is a bit of a case of `We heard what he said but we did not know what he meant'. It is a bit unclear where he stands. The very strong and united stance of this government is a stark contrast to the disunity and uncertainty of the opposition. I am sure there are plenty of members opposite who do not support the policy that has been recently released, yet we just do not hear from them. They have been silent, but there is certainly a great degree of uncertainty.
The bill currently before the House makes certain amendments to the Migration Act 1958. The purpose of these amendments is to improve the integrity of the act and to ensure that the act operates as intended. The bill aims to clarify certain visa related matters, to create a deputy principal member position on the Migration Review Tribunal, to remove ambiguity surrounding certain offence provisions and to correct certain technical errors in the act. I would like to consider several of the schedules within the bill at this point.
Schedule 1 to the bill amends the act to clarify the immigration status of non-citizen children born in Australia. Despite what the opposition might say, the interests of children are of paramount importance to Minister Ruddock; and my National Party colleague Larry Anthony, the Minister for Children and Youth Affairs, is very interested in the welfare of children. Schedule 1 gives effect to that concern. Under the proposed changes, these children are taken to have entered Australia at birth. The schedule expressly provides that these non-citizen children are immigration cleared for the purposes of their entry at birth.
It is important to clarify this status, because it has significant implications for a person's entitlements under the Migration Act with regard to their ability to access bridging visas. Under the act, the usual way a visa holder must enter Australia is through a port or on a pre-cleared flight, but obviously the act does not take into account the possibility of people entering Australia by virtue of birth. Schedule 1 puts beyond doubt that any visas taken to have been granted to non-citizen children at birth do not cease to be in effect because of the way these children entered Australia.
Schedule 2 of the bill addresses issues which arose in the Tutugri case, which was heard in the Federal Court. The amendments to schedule 2 clearly authorise the taking of security for compliance with conditions to be imposed on a visa before a visa is granted. Schedule 3 of the bill makes two amendments to the act relating to special purpose visas. The first amendment deals with the cessation of a special purpose visa where the minister has made a declaration that it is undesirable for a person to travel to, enter or remain in Australia. The amendment will allow the minister to specify a time when such a declaration is to take effect. The second amendment in schedule 3 to the bill puts it beyond doubt that the rules of natural justice do not apply to making such a declaration by the minister. 
Schedule 4 to the bill creates a deputy principal member position on the Migration Review Tribunal. Schedule 5 to the bill ensures that certain offence provisions in the act operate as they did prior to the commencement of the Commonwealth Criminal Code.
Schedule 6 to the bill makes several amendments to the act. These amendments, firstly, will prevent non-citizens from evading the intended operation of section 48 by travelling overseas on a bridging visa. Subsection 48(1) of the Migration Act provides that a non-citizen who does not hold a substantive visa and who, after last entering Australia, was refused a visa may only apply for a prescribed class of visa. Currently, a non-citizen who leaves and re-enters Australia on a bridging visa is able to circumvent this bar on subsequent visa applications because, on re-entering Australia, he or she has not had a visa refused after last entering Australia. It should be noted that it was never intended that these bridging visa holders would not be subject to the section 48 bar.
Secondly, schedule 6 to the bill amends the act to clarify that a non-citizen's bridging visa ceases to be in effect the moment his or her substantive visa is cancelled. Schedule 6 to the bill also amends the act to allow a time limit to be imposed on a non-citizen in immigration clearance seeking revocation of an automatic cancellation of his or her student visa. Schedule 6 also clarifies that the decision not to revoke the automatic cancellation of a non-citizen's student visa that is made while a person is in immigration clearance is not merits reviewable. 
I would like to spend a moment talking about the opposition's proposed amendments. I am pleased to note that the opposition has generally supported the bill in its current form. However, I have some difficulty with the opposition's amendments. The degree of support that these amendments have from the opposition seems a bit uncertain. The opposition's position seems a bit unclear: some members are supporting it, but we are not so sure of the position of others, such as the member for Fremantle. The proposed amendments, as I understand them, would cause some considerable complexity with administration of the overall system; they would certainly, I believe, result in increased litigation. After observing the length of time taken with and the great expense to the community of longwinded litigation for asylum seekers, many of whom—in fact, most of whom, it seems—ultimately have their right to stay in Australia revoked, it seems rather peculiar that we would be seeking to make this system more complex rather than simpler and easier to administer.
In summary, I believe that this bill is a good bill. It will enhance the effectiveness of our immigration legislation. I commend the bill to the House.

name: Plibersek, Tanya, MP
text:
—We are here today debating the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002. The length of time this bill has actually taken to make it onto the agenda is curious. This bill was first discussed many months ago. I have been waiting for it to come up for debate again because I have been very eager to hear the shadow minister for immigration introduce the amendments, which she has foreshadowed, about getting children out of detention. It is quite plain that the delay associated with this bill has been due to these very amendments that the shadow minister has foreshadowed.
The government has serious problems in its own ranks with keeping people in line on this issue of children in detention. We saw last week some very moderate announcements—I think rather pathetic announcements—about the changes that the government proposes to make in the area of children in detention. The reason for even these puny changes having been made is that the Prime Minister has found it very hard to keep some of his more compassionate members in line on this issue. We have all heard reports in the media and in the corridors here of people telling the Prime Minister that, if the shadow minister's recommendation that children should be taken out of detention were put, they would be forced to cross the floor and vote for that. That has delayed this legislation and has forced the Prime Minister to act in the small way in which he has, saying that from now on unaccompanied children will not be locked up in desert detention centres and that women and children will be facilitated out of detention centres.
While of course anything is welcome in this area, these measures are incredibly disappointing. I know that those in the Liberal Party who worked for so long to get these small changes were really arguing for a lot more. I presume that they will continue to agitate within the government for greater change because these measures are manifestly inadequate. Certainly, it is important that any unaccompanied children arriving from now on not be held indefinitely in detention centres, as they have been up till now. But we are not seeing a lot of new arrivals at the moment. We still have kids locked up in detention centres, though, and we have to deal with those kids, many of whom have been in detention for many months now. The other part of the policy that is inadequate is that families who have made the traumatic journey to Australia do not deserve to be separated; they deserve to be able to live as a family unit. Indeed, our policy released last week allows family units to stay together—and that is a very important measure.
Mr Deputy Speaker, as you know, our policy is that any unaccompanied children under 14 be placed in the care of foster families as soon as their health checks are complete, and unaccompanied youths between 14 and 18 be released into appropriate community care as soon as their health checks are complete. Unaccompanied children have been a real focus of community concern, and rightly so. The stories about the sorts of psychological and emotional trauma that these children have gone through and the effect that it is having on them have been harrowing. There have been accounts in newspapers about such things as adolescent girls becoming incontinent due to the stress of being in detention while perhaps also caring for younger siblings, and children witnessing others self-harming and, in some cases, harming themselves. All these stories are particularly affecting when we remember that unaccompanied children do not even have their parents to explain to them what is going on, why they are in detention. 
There is of course a real contradiction in the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs being responsible for keeping these kids locked up and also being their legal guardian. You have to ask yourself about the ability and the sincerity of a guardian who thinks it is okay to keep kids locked up in Woomera and also thinks it is okay to have kids, unaccompanied minors, on Manus Island and Nauru, for example. The latest figures I have indicate that there are 38 children on Manus Island and 149 children on Nauru as at October this year, and that about 30 of those were unaccompanied minors. Children living in the harsh environment on Manus Island and Nauru is a horrifying thought. It is horrifying to think that there any children living there at all, but to think of unaccompanied minors living there, trying to eke out an existence for themselves, is really very disturbing. Labor have said that those unaccompanied minors would not be detained. To avoid that conflict of interest I mentioned, we have also said that the children's commissioner we are proposing would be the legal guardian of unaccompanied children. 
The other thing that I think has been very warmly welcomed in Labor's policy is that high-security detention will be used only very briefly on arrival, and that high-security detention for family groups will not be in the desert hellholes at other camps that we hear about. We are talking about detention facilities based on the alternative detention trial at Woomera where families will be able to live in ordinary homes that will be secured at the perimeter and have security presence. 
Children living in those homes will be able to go to school. I think that that is a very important step forward. We know that in some of the detention centres very few of the children are going to school. In fact, even where they have been allowed to go to school, it has often been discouraged by guards who have told children and parents that their children will face racism if they go to the local schools. 
The ability for families to cook their own meals, to have some privacy and to have as normal a family life as possible is vital in keeping these children in the best possible condition psychologically and emotionally. Some of the reports that have come out of the detention centres where ACM has been very strict about things like mealtimes might not seem a lot to a casual observer. However, anyone who has young children knows that they do not eat at set meal times and that they want snacks between meals. And if you are breastfeeding, you cannot eat once at seven o'clock in the morning and not again till lunchtime, then have dinner at five o'clock and have nothing else until seven o'clock again the next morning. You have to eat small, regular meals to keep your milk supply up. This has meant that breastfeeding—which is so important for the health of children and vital in an environment where there are other physical strains on children, particularly on young babies, such as the heat in some of these detention centres—has been discouraged because breastfeeding mothers simply cannot get the calories required to produce breast milk. They are not able to have the regular meals that they need to keep their supply up.
Living in an alternative detention style of accommodation where people have control over their own meal times and what they cook and eat is a very important step in maintaining the health of children. It also provides a more home-like environment in which the detention period can be a lot less stressful. Of course, Labor are talking about making the detention very short whenever we can.  
Children being able to attend the local schools is also very important. Our experience is that the vast majority of people who arrive in Australia in this manner are found to have general claims to refuge. That means that we want to start to make good Australian citizens of these people as soon as we possibly can. That cannot happen without help to learn English. It cannot happen without children being able to go to local schools. It cannot happen without their parents being able to find work as quickly as possible. We have made suggestions that will facilitate all of these things. 
I know that there are many students in my electorate who have watched reports on television of children in detention and have read about them in the newspapers. In particular, students at Newtown Primary School have been speaking to me not just this year but also last year about this very issue: how can they encourage the government to make a difference and allow these children to live in the community? They were very concerned about one of their classmates whose family were temporary protection visa holders in regard to the fees that these children were forced to pay to attend the local public school. I was very impressed by the welcoming attitude of the students, the warmth they showed these kids and the support they wanted to show for their cause. I always think that if adults paid a little bit more attention to how children treated each other in these circumstances, we would probably live in a kinder and gentler world. The benefit that children experience from going into a school environment like that is absolutely incomparable. 
I mentioned earlier the latest figures I had for the number of children in detention on Manus Island and Nauru. In October 2002, a total of 309 children were in detention in Australia. Anyone who has examined this issue would know that those children are suffering to a greater or lesser extent and that the detention environment is not appropriate for them. On Monday, I received a petition from more than 8,500 citizens calling for children to be released from detention. These members of the community have been following this issue and as concerned Australians—some of them parents, some of them not—they want to send a message to the government that children should not be in detention. Some of the reasons are very apparent when we look at the sort of evidence that came out of the Senate inquiry and has come out through the media. There does not seem to be any quality management strategy for immigration detention centres. It is common in other areas like aged care, disability services and family services to put a quality management strategy in place. There seems to be no evidence of that in detention centres.
ACM repeatedly fails to deliver on the contract they have signed with the government. For example, they contract to ensure that children receive an education and people receive adequate nutrition, and to provide a safe environment. In all of these areas, ACM have repeatedly failed to meet their obligations. Yet we have a government that is getting ready to call for tenders for the management of detention facilities in Australia. ACM, of course, will retender to provide those services. Having failed to meet even the low standards included in the contract this time around, I am at an absolute loss as to how ACM intend to meet what the minister says are going to be higher standards in the next contract round. They have not met the standards that exist now; yet we are saying that in our warmer and fuzzier approach next time, they are somehow going to meet those standards. It beggars belief.
Centres should be returned to public management. Labor have said we will do that on returning to government. There needs to be public scrutiny of what is happening in these places. I do not understand, when we are dealing with traumatised people who have made a long and dangerous journey here, why the government does not contract the management of detention centres out—if it must contract them out—to a community services organisation that can just pay some other organisation to provide the security services? We seem to put the emphasis on jailing people and, as a second thought, think about how we are going to feed them, care for them, teach their children and provide all of the human services necessary. Why don't we think first about looking after the people for whom we are responsible once they arrive here? No matter what we think about the way they arrived—we have heard many people from the government talk about `queue jumpers' and all the other pejoratives that they use—we are responsible for their welfare, particularly in the case of children. Why don't we provide for that welfare and think secondarily about the security, instead of placing that at the centre of how we deal with asylum seekers? 
Every few months, there is a story about a child who has been physically or sexually abused in one of these centres. We know that it happens. We know that it has been happening for years. What do we do about it? The minister for immigration is the legal guardian of these children. Yet we had the case on 18 January 2002 where a five-year-old boy detainee in Curtin was allegedly raped by three other detainees. The local doctor was allowed to delay medical examination of the boy for up to a week and the local police apparently said the five-year-old boy had instigated sex with three adult detainees. This is horrifying. What were the outcomes of the obviously unsatisfactory finding by the police? Did DIMIA castigate the police and question their investigation of the case? Did DIMIA contact the officers who investigated the case? We do not know. These centres are managed in a way that is so secretive and so inadequate that questions like this arise constantly. The welfare of the children, whom we as a community are responsible for, is being left in the hands of people who obviously are inadequately policing the standards that they have agreed to.
To conclude, if we accept, as a community, that it is our responsibility to care for children while they are being held in detention, it stuns me that we do not provide even such basic health care as immunisation. The reason that we do not immunise them is because of the cost involved. We are talking about a very small cost to the Australian health budget. Instead of accepting that many of these children will be accepted into Australia as genuine refugees and starting off their health care immediately, we delay it until the last possible moment, hoping that we can get away with not even providing basic health care.
The constant reports of the psychological damage being done to children in detention are disturbing. It is even more disturbing to think that we are not providing the sort of care that they need. Even if the government decides to keep them incarcerated, do we not have a responsibility to start to deal with the damage that we are inflicting on these children? No, there is no measure, ability or desire to do that.
The child protection services in Western Australia found that there are proven cases of maltreatment in centres. What has the minister done to begin to address these problems? If we know that these children have been abused or neglected in detention centres, what are we doing to stop that happening in the future? Is it going to be written into the new contracts that are being negotiated at the moment? We have no information about this. The contracting out means that all of this is enveloped in commercial-in-confidence claims. Thus, I am very pleased that the shadow minister will later have the opportunity to move a substantive amendment to this legislation for getting children out from behind the razor wire. (Time expired)

name: Emerson, Craig, MP
text:
—The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002 bill is a non-controversial omnibus bill and, as a consequence, Labor are quite happy to support it. But we are moving a very substantial amendment relating to children in detention. The amendment—to be moved by the shadow minister for immigration and population, the member for Lalor—would modify the legal power to detain asylum seekers so that children are not held in high-security detention for long periods of time. The amendment would ensure that unaccompanied children are placed in foster or community care arrangements and that families with children will be allowed to live in accommodation like the Woomera alternative detention trial after meeting certain criteria. This amendment is designed to meet the needs of children without endangering the health and security of Australians.  
The amendment was foreshadowed by the shadow immigration minister with members of the government. A number of those members, to their credit, saw great merit in this amendment, to the extent that they expressed grave concerns about any proposition from the government in the party room that it oppose the amendment. As a consequence, the government has been forced to move some small way, and it made an announcement to that effect just the other day. But it is truly sad that the government responded to this amendment not on the basis of any sense of responsibility for children in detention, not on any humanitarian basis, but because it was worried that members of the government might cross the floor. 
It would not be the first time government members crossed the floor. I would encourage those members who are contemplating crossing the floor to do so. The trend was set in 1988 by the current Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, who crossed the floor when a motion was put in this parliament reaffirming bipartisan support for the end of the White Australia Policy and an immigration policy that did not discriminate on race. The Prime Minister, who was then in opposition, voted against that motion, but the current minister for immigration could not bring himself to vote against such a decent motion and therefore crossed the floor and voted with Labor. He was joined by Mr Ian McPhee, the then member for Goldstein, who—for his commitment to a non-discriminatory immigration policy, to the end of the White Australia Policy and to accolades in the motion that were poured on the Holt government for getting rid of the White Australia Policy—got his comeuppance and was disendorsed. He was replaced by the current member for Goldstein from the far right of the Liberal Party, as the so-called wets were cleansed from the Liberal Party—particularly those who voted with Labor in support of an immigration policy that did not discriminate on the basis of race. Others to cross the floor were Steele Hall from South Australia and Peter Baume. Ian Wilson, I am reliably informed, abstained on that day. The point I am making is that on immigration issues, when it comes to decency and to displays of humanitarianism, members of the Liberal Party have crossed the floor and joined Labor. I would urge that they do that again here in consideration of the amendment that the member for Lalor will be moving. 
Who could seriously argue that there is anything other than decency associated with the idea of getting unaccompanied children out of detention? This is the most reasonable, decent amendment that you could imagine in this parliament. Yet we face the spectre of dozens and dozens of government members voting against it. On this occasion I would like to see a true display of bipartisanship such that we did not even need a division, such that everyone on the government side agreed with the position that we will be putting in respect of that amendment. Alas, I fear that that will not be the case; I fear that we will be confronted with the situation where dozens of government members will be voting against an amendment that gets unaccompanied children out from behind the razor wire. 
As we head into Christmas, I hope they contemplate the consequences of doing that—of voting against an amendment that gives new hope to young children locked up behind the razor wire in detention centres in this country. Why wouldn't you support that sort of motion? We will soon find out. I do urge all members to have a look at the debate in 1998, to recognise that it is possible, that the responsible thing for members of the Liberal Party to do is to cross the floor when a question of basic decency is put in this parliament. That question of basic decency will be put in this parliament in this debate.
—I have waited a long time—
—Minister!
—In 30 years I have never seen one of you cross the floor. 
—The minister is defying the chair. 
—I will be looking forward to the immigration minister crossing the floor with us, but I will take my own advice: I will not be holding my breath. I hope he will at least urge some of his colleagues to cross the floor and vote to get children out from behind the razor wire. There are people here on the government side who parade themselves as the wets, who parade themselves as good, kind-hearted people, but they will not cross the floor and join with Labor in getting the children out from behind the razor wire. 
Government members interjecting—
—The member for Dunkley says that he is a good, decent man. Come over and join Labor. Mr Baird should come and join Labor. The education minister parades himself as a great humanitarian. Come and join Labor. The immigration minister should join Labor. I say to Daryl Williams, the Attorney-General: come and join Labor. Come and join Labor, one and all, and get the children out from behind the razor wire.
—Order! It being 2.00 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour and the member will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed. It may be polite of me to inquire of the member for Rankin as to whether or not he had concluded his remarks.
—You couldn't get any better than that, Mr Speaker.

name: Crean, Simon, MP
text:
—This is a government of unbelievable arrogance, and we have seen it on display again not just today but this week. This is a government that has one set of rules for ordinary Australians but another set for the friends of the Prime Minister. In the case of the families in Australia struggling under financial pressure, nothing comes; but in the case of the Prime Minister and his mates, anything goes. We have had the Prime Minister this week saying that we are wasting the time of this parliament in asking serious questions about his relationship with individuals, his code of conduct, and his special interests and those of his friends. He would have this parliament not debate them. He certainly will not answer the questions about them.
The last fortnight has highlighted the special deals that this government and the Prime Minister, in particular, will condone. Conflicts of interest—special interests. Take the Senator Coonan issue. The Prime Minister today in answer to a question—which he did not answer—where I asked whether it was appropriate for a minister responsible for the insurance industry to be pursuing a claim against an insurance company whilst she was a minister and whether it was appropriate for her use the ministerial office and ministerial letterhead argued that it was appropriate. It is totally inappropriate. He has to argue that because the minister herself is compromised again. It was very interesting in his answer that he asked us to consider the totality of Senator Coonan's circumstances.
Let us consider the totality of Senator Coonan's circumstances. We have the Assistant Treasurer of this country, the minister responsible for revenue—that is, taxation—having knowledge of and participating in a complex arrangement designed to avoid capital gains tax and land tax on the family property at Paradise Avenue, Clareville, which has become known in the press as the `Pittwater property'. We know the land tax was avoided because, when the issue arose in the public domain in November, the residential status attaching to the Pittwater property was changed and the outstanding land tax was paid. In other words, the tax was paid only when we raised the issue. If it had not been raised by us, if it had not been raised in the Senate, if it had not been raised by the member for Werriwa, it would never have been paid. This tidy little arrangement in which the minister for taxation was involved and knew of an arrangement that avoided taxation would have gone unnoticed. Yet the Prime Minister comes in here and says, `What's the case against her?' That is the first part of the case. 
The second part of the case against her is the conflict of interest she is involved in. She is the Assistant Treasurer with ministerial responsibilities for insurance, and in that context she has been promoting the notion of mediation as a mechanism for settling insurance claims, among other things. But, seeing that she has promoted mediation as the mechanism for settlement, what do we find? We find that her son and her husband own 100 per cent of a company involved in mediation services. Not only does that company trade in mediation services, it operates from the minister's home. The Prime Minister's code of conduct clearly says that, if decisions are taken that have impact in terms of a minister's family, they should be declared. She declared them subsequently, but it is inappropriate that they were made—totally inappropriate. She divested to her son after it became a public issue. So we have a mediation company and a minister promoting mediation. It is a clear conflict of interest.
The third part of the case against her is the Prime Minister's failure to say that it was inappropriate for her to use her ministerial letterhead or her ministerial office to pursue a claim. This was no ordinary claim. It is true, in the circumstances, that the claim was made before she was a minister, but do you know what happened after she became a minister?
—It was settled.
—It was settled, but the claim went up 500 per cent. It went up from $60,000 to $330,000, and for what? We are only talking about a conservatory, for heaven's sake; a conservatory being built on the home. This was pursued, as we understand it, by the minister on ministerial letterhead. That was totally inappropriate.
Then we have the misleading of the Senate by the senator when she claimed to have no interest in the Pittwater property, when we know that she was listed as the joint developer of that property. She said the property could not be subject to capital gains tax because it was purchased prior to 1985, despite knowing that the house had been constructed in 1994. She tried to tell the House that she had no active interest in promoting the Ipp recommendations on mediation, but an article appeared in the Financial Review in which she claimed credit for promoting that very thing. This government is prepared to condone those sorts of actions and say that we should not have the ability to ask questions about them in this parliament. These questions go to the heart of ministerial responsibility, they go to the heart of the code of conduct and they go to the heart of probity. No-one wants to see conflicts of interest, least of all by ministers in office, yet we have them in spades in the case of this minister.
But it does not stop there. The other thing that has come out this week is about former minister Reith. Let us take this for a conflict of interest and something the Prime Minister is also prepared to condone. Last year, on 29 June, the former minister announced his intention to resign from the parliament at the next election. Ten days later, on 9 July, a contract that had been previously tendered for—for defence procurement operations to the private sector—was cancelled. This was 10 days after the former minister announced his intention not to stand again. Having cancelled the original tender process, he offered $1 million to every new tenderer in the second bid. One of those tenderers, Tenix, he now works for. He was working out his arrangement to work for them even while he was minister. Not only did Tenix get the $1 million; it won the contract.
It won the contract in circumstances that prompted us to pose questions in this parliament as to the circumstances of the change and the original conditions under which the bids were put out. There was no answer from the Prime Minister. Why? Because he was protecting a mate—a mate who protected him before the last election by deliberately withholding the truth from the public about the kids overboard. The Prime Minister owes Peter Reith big-time, and this is an example of where it is being paid out. The same minister retendered another contract earlier in his portfolio for the submarine torpedoes. That contract blew out by $200 million, and the torpedoes do not even fit. We are not supposed to ask questions about that either. The government think that is irrelevant. 
I turn to another issue this week: ethanol. This involves another one of the Prime Minister's mates. Every motorists organisation in this country has been calling for limits on the amount of ethanol that can go into petrol, the manufacturing organisations have called for it, the science around it demonstrates that there are huge risks for motorists, and the Labor Party said months ago that there should be a limit of 10 per cent on the ethanol going into petrol and that it should be disclosed on the petrol bowser. This government has done nothing. Australian motorists are at risk, and the government knows it. But this government is prepared to put a mate of the Prime Minister ahead of the motorists of this country. It is a disgrace. This government says we should not ask questions about these issues. Well, we will, and we will continue to pursue them.
I go to the further arrogance of this government today. We heard the Prime Minister, in answer to a question, say that the Labor Party were prepared to slug middle-income Australia with higher taxes. Give us a break! This is the highest taxing government in the nation's history. We are saying that, in terms of this matter of public importance, this government has no regard for the families of this country but is prepared to look after its mates. Look at what it has done to the families of this country while it has protected the mates I have just gone through. It taxes families at the highest rate they have ever been taxed. Household debt and credit card debt are at record levels. 
There has been a massive decline in bulk-billing. What does the Prime Minister say? He says that he does not know what we are talking about and that there is no problem with bulk-billing. Go and tell that to the thousands of Australians who cannot find a bulk-biller in their town. Go and tell it to them! I read out one example today. There are thousands of them around the country because this government is driving down bulk-billing. Why? Because it does not really believe in Medicare, and if you take bulk-billing out you destroy Medicare. This Prime Minister has always wanted to destroy Medicare, whatever he says. The government is not only taxing the Australian people more and putting them more into debt; it is withdrawing services and making them pay more for them.
The government is also, under the minister sitting at the table, about to embark on a regime to deregulate university fees and put university education beyond the reach of ordinary people. We will oppose it. Just as we will restore bulk-billing, we will ensure that in this country education is available to everyone, not just those who can afford it. We also have the circumstances where families are under pressure because they have to make a choice between being good parents or good employees. They are being forced to work longer in this country. The only developed country in the world where people work longer hours than in Australia is South Korea. That is under this government.
We heard them bragging before about the employment statistics that have come out. Do you know that over the last three years, while something like 680,000 jobs have been created in this country, only 700 of them pay average weekly earnings? No wonder middle-income Australia is being squeezed! The type of economic activity that the government are presiding over is not producing anything other than low-paid jobs, forcing people to be casualised and work longer hours. No wonder they are under pressure. There has to be an end to that, too. That is why we support family-friendly packages built around the notion of paid maternity leave. We will announce those initiatives next year, but we will go further. It is not just a question of supporting working families; we have to support families across the board. For once in this country, we need to have some policies that are actually supporting families, not slugging them. The government have the gall to talk about us putting pressure on families; look what they have done to them.
Another thing we are committed to is making sure that the tax burden does not fall on middle- and low-income Australians, as this government has seen happen. It is allowing tax minimisation schemes for its wealthy mates, while the real pressure in terms of the tax burden falls on middle- and low-income Australia. We are going to have targeted tax cuts that ensure that that pressure is lifted. This is not a government for the families of Australia; it is only for the mates of the Prime Minister. It is a government of arrogance, it is a government that is out of touch and it is a government of double standards. We have exposed those double standards in the last fortnight and we will continue to expose them. The Australian public deserves better, the families of Australia deserve better, and they will only get it under a Labor government. (Time expired)

name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
text:
—I think the basis of today's matter of public importance was given in the first and opening remarks by the Leader of the Opposition at the National Press Club on Tuesday this week, when he said that it had been a pretty tough year.
