He went on the defensive, using a dorothy dixer during the early part of question time, and attacked the arguments that I have just put in this place and that had been published that day in my article in the Sydney Morning Herald. The Treasurer had three main points of attack. The first one was that he disputed my use of the $9.5 billion and $9.7 billion headline cash balance figures for 2004-05 and 2005-06, choosing not to recognise that those figures were net of fiscal drag. If you add Access Economics's fiscal drag figures for those two years of $5 billion and $6.2 billion respectively, you get exactly what the MYEFO forward estimate headline cash surpluses are—$14.5 billion in 2004-05 and $15.9 billion in 2005-06. This is not difficult arithmetic: it is simple addition.
The Treasurer's second complaint was that I had criticised the fall from 142 per cent to 129 per cent in the proportion of average earnings at which the top marginal threshold cuts in. The Treasurer said that it would not be so low had I not imposed a higher top marginal tax threshold. His suggestion that I personally had stopped the top marginal tax rate from being higher is flattering but untrue. The actual tax thresholds in the final ANTS package were the products of a deal between the coalition and the Australian Democrats, in which the Labor Party had no part. The Treasurer's attempt to paint Labor as the party which stopped the changes to the top marginal tax rate are as inaccurate as they are unbelievable. The Howard government made a deal with the Democrats; if the Treasurer in hindsight now sees that as being a mistake, he should take it up with his own party. It has nothing to do with the Labor Party.
I, with the rest of the Labor Party, opposed the government's entire ANTS package, which included an unfair redistribution of income tax and a regressive GST. He did not dispute that the top marginal tax threshold has fallen relative to average earnings, an admission by him that there has been significant bracket creep. The Treasurer's final defence was to suggest that I was advocating indexation of his tax scales. That is a total fabrication by the Treasurer. I do not support indexation of the tax scales, because that would institutionalise the Treasurer's own unfair tax scales. I move:
That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
“whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for:
(1)	imposing the largest tax burden of any Government in Australia's history;
(2)	imposing the highest personal income tax burden on Australians; 
(3)	imposing the highest total income tax burden on Australians;
(4)	planning to hit Australians with an extra $17 billion in bracket creep over the forward estimates years; and
(5)	relying on bracket creep to keep the budget in surplus.”
 (Mr Jenkins)—Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

name: McFarlane, Jann, MP
text:
—I rise in the very early hours of this morning to speak on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) 2002. This bill is one of a number of taxation bills that have been debated in this House during the year. I have a specific interest in some of the provisions of this bill and, therefore, I am keen to speak briefly on them.
This bill deals with three specific areas. The first is concerns about specific exemptions to interest withholding tax. These measures are designed to reduce compliance costs for business. The second issue is the one that I have the most interest in. This deals with capital gains tax exemptions for certain compensation payments. The specific payments deal with compensation for former slaves, forced labourers and certain other victims of the Nazi period in Germany. The final issue covered by this bill is changes to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 that deal with the products of friendly societies.
Compensation for the victims of the Nazi regime is extremely important. I do not need to go into the atrocities committed by the Nazis during their rule of Germany and their conduct during the war. The German Forced Labour Compensation Program was set up under German law to provide compensation to victims. The scheme provides for two types of payments: for personal wrong or injury, including slave or forced labour, and for property damage or loss where relief under other funds is not available. These funds can also be made to relatives of the victim or to the victim's heir. Currently, if such a payment is made to a victim's heir who is not a relative, the payment attracts capital gains tax under section 118-37 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997. This amendment bill extends the current capital gains tax exemption to the victim's heir who is not a relative, in the case of personal wrong or injury payments, and to the former property owner's relative heir in the case of property damage or loss payments. 
The changes are welcome. The people and their families who had their lives destroyed by the Nazis have suffered greatly and thoroughly deserve any compensation they receive. My electorate of Stirling has quite a large Jewish community who still feel the effects of the heinous acts committed against them by the Nazis. Each year since my election in 1998, the Jewish Community Council of WA Inc. has invited me to its annual Holocaust Remembrance Day ceremony. Each year I have been honoured by this invitation. This year the ceremony was held at the Jewish Centre in Yokine. The ceremony is always extremely moving and is a fitting tribute to the millions of innocent people who lost their lives. We must never forget that human rights must always remain central to our democracy. I was moved by a quote on the back of this year's program. It said:
Judaism has 613 commandments; after Auschwitz we have a new one—a prohibition—we are forbidden to give Hitler posthumous victories. This commandment applies not only to Jews, but to all humanity.
This bill also recognises other communities that were persecuted by the Nazis. There were people from Eastern Europe and even Italy who were sent to Germany during the war and forced to work to keep the Nazi war machine running. They also deserve this recognition of their suffering.
I would also like to briefly examine an issue that has been ruining the lives of many of my constituents over the past three years—the government and the ATO's handling of the mass marketed tax effective investment issue. The government today is making some very worthwhile changes to tax legislation. However, its administration of taxation leaves a lot to be desired. We are currently seeing in this House and the other place questions raised about the minister responsible for tax administration's credibility on tax avoidance. This raises serious issues about the right of this minister to administer our tax system. If the minister is found to have engaged in tax avoidance then the Prime Minister should sack her from the ministry and apologise to the tens of thousands of Australians who have been accused of tax avoidance by the ATO in the mass marketed tax effective investment debate. 
I am not going to comment on the individual schemes, as I am not a qualified taxation lawyer. We have a process for dealing with any disputes about taxation rulings, and this is ultimately through the judicial system. All the parties concerned will no doubt respect the decision of the court. However, there is a process prior to the cases being heard in court, and I am concerned that this process was subverted.
I want to raise some serious questions about this government's handling of this whole issue. I do not want to engage in petty political point scoring when I have previously been speaking in this debate about victims of the Holocaust—the victims of that tragedy deserve more than that. However, I wish to make some considered comments about an issue that has cost Australian lives through suicide and has also broken many Australian families. I am sure that the House is aware of the emotional impact that these ATO decisions have made—constituents who have been caught up in this saga have approached us all. I am not going to give a potted history of this issue as I would take up too much of the House's time. (Quorum formed) However, I would like to deal specifically with the conduct of the minister in terms of accountability and what I feel have been heavy-handed tactics by the ATO.
After being approached by constituents in 2000 and 2001 I asked some questions of the Treasurer in mid-2001 on specific issues with regard to the taxpayers charter and some questions on the procedures of the ATO with regard to their processes in issuing reassessments. On 28 June 2001 I asked questions 2773 and 2774. By the time parliament was prorogued I had not received answers to these questions. Earlier in the year I had asked a simple question about the operation of the ATO's taxpayers charter and whether that charter had any legislative force. This question was also not answered. If this had been an issue that was not topical, I might have been a little more accepting that the minister had not answered my questions. However, this issue was hot, dominating both the Prime Minister's and the Treasurer's visits to Western Australia in the lead-up to the federal election in late 2001.
When the 40th Parliament came into existence, I again asked the same questions on 19 February 2002. They were numbered 154, 155 and 156. To date, these questions have not been answered. I have used the processes available to me and have asked the Speaker to write to the Treasurer on a number of occasions, but still have not received any answers. I am curious about why the Treasurer has not answered my questions. What we have here is an accountability issue. Does the Treasurer not want to answer my questions because of the answers he will provide? 
I also asked a question on the composition and operation of the Part IVA Panel at the ATO, and I thank the Treasurer for his answer. This question was also relatively simple. It was an attempt to find out who was on the panel and when it met. The answer, which I received on 11 November, caused me further concerns which centred on accountability. My major concerns were with the informal nature of the panel, the fact that the community representatives were also on the ATO consultancy payroll and that the composition of the panel varied between meetings. This would be considered in many fields as a conflict of interest. In an interview with Jim Hanna from AAP, I was quoted as saying:
How objective are they if their consultants, drawn from the ATO's register, are being paid by the ATO? A community representative is somebody who is an accountant with a peak body or someone who represents a community body.
As the Part IVA Panel was used by the ATO to endorse its decisions on these reassessments, I was concerned that it be accountable and transparent. The panel is neither, yet its decisions have been used by the ATO in arguments put to taxpayers about the decisions made against them. 
I asked another question about the deal offered by the ATO on these schemes. This question dealt with what has been described as the `mail merge mentality' of the ATO in relation to investors. I had numerous calls from constituents who had received the ATO's publicised offer. I asked question No. 363 earlier this year to get information for constituents prior to the closing date of the offer, which, I must add, was extended slightly. My concern was that all investors received an identical letter, with their name, address and the name of their investment as the only differences. This makes a mockery of the taxpayers charter, which states that all taxpayers must be treated individually. 
What also concerned me was that people were being told to accept the offer before a deadline or penalties would apply, yet they were not told exactly how much the offer would cost them. In effect, they were signing up to something without knowing what they were signing and how much it would cost. As well, they were signing their legal rights away. If you applied this scenario to consumer protection in any other industry, mechanisms to protect the consumer would immediately come in. I have never heard of people signing a settlement without knowing what the settlement will be. It was almost as if they were being coerced into signing before the proper processes occurred that exist under law for the settlement of these issues. I received an answer from the Treasurer three months after the offer had closed. So much for accountability.
Without entering into the merits of a test case, which is a completely different issue, I am appalled at the lack of natural justice for these people. They deserve their day in court. If a court finds that they have avoided tax, they should be penalised. However, if a court finds that they have not avoided tax then they have suffered a real injustice. The right to take your issue to court is a fundamental part of our democracy, as is the accountability of the executive. I will conclude my contribution to this debate by saying that this country needs a proper and independent umpire on taxation issues. The measures introduced by this government to create an inspector for taxation do not do this. In reality, the role mirrors that of the Taxation Ombudsman, meaning that it cannot enforce. Let us not undo good legislation by failing on the issue of tax administration. Some real reforms need to be debated in this place and put into action. It is the responsibility of the government to provide the impetus for this.
Although this issue affected many of my constituents, the majority of them live in seats occupied by members opposite. The member for Curtin and the member for Kalgoorlie have in their electorates the largest number of people affected by this issue in Western Australia, yet neither of them has used the House to address or even acknowledge this issue which is hurting so many of their constituents. It is time that those members opposite had the courage to speak up for the people they represent rather than contributing to the silence in this place that pervades from the government benches.
Our tax system is not oppressive; however, our administration of the laws passed by this parliament on taxation matters are hurting people. If they are wrong then they should pay the penalty; however, we must remember that the foundations of our legal system are based on the adage `innocent until proven guilty'. Let us not let our people feel that they are guilty until they have had their day in court. The sooner the government amend the act to make the ATO process clear, open and accountable, the sooner people's faith in the ATO and its system will be restored or strengthened. I call on the government to take this action as a matter of urgency. I also call on the government to support Labor's amendment to this act. I would like to read the amendment into the Hansard. It says:
That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
“whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for:
(1)	imposing the largest tax burden of any Government in Australia's history;
(2)	imposing the highest personal income tax burden on Australians;
(3)	imposing the highest total income tax burden on Australians; 
(4)	planning to hit Australians with an extra $17 billion in bracket creep over the forward estimates years; and
(5)	relying on bracket creep to keep the budget in surplus.”
I call on the government to seriously consider how they are handling their tax system and the burden they are placing on ordinary Australian families. I commend this bill, as amended, to the House.

name: Hatton, Michael, MP
text:
—I wish to associate myself with the arguments advanced by my colleagues who have spoken on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) 2002. I note that no-one from the government has spoken on this bill. I know that the hour is late and the end of the year is actually here, but, if you look at the speaking list, the only reason why this House has not closed down is that people in the opposition are still speaking. It is within our power not to do that. Then nothing would be coming back from the Senate and we would not be proceeding. However, we recognise that we have a duty to the parliament, however pressed we are.
Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) 2002 has three elements. I will deal with two of them in passing and one more substantially, and then I will deal with the amendment put by the shadow assistant treasurer. First, very much in passing, is the question of interest withholding tax exemptions. Essentially, they have been directed towards the attempt pursued, in particular, by the member for North Sydney, at least in rhetoric—we are yet to see how much action there will be. It has been a bold attempt, even whilst we were in government, to set up, in conjunction with the state Labor government, Sydney as one of the key financial capitals of the Asia-Pacific. This bill argues that the changes made here in terms of interest tax exemptions deal with bonds and certain other tax concessions, which are given both overseas and in Australia, essentially on the same basis. The argument is that that will provide a stronger basis for investment within Australia, encourage more overseas investment and provide an incentive for people to draw closer to Australia and make Sydney, and indeed Australia, a stronger financial centre. The actual matters in relation to associates and prohibitions—what they can and cannot do, deemed interest payments and all the rest—I will leave to the aficionados.
I note that chapter 3 of the bill deals with friendly society investment products. We know that friendly societies have always been dealt with in ways that are different from a lot of other entities. That is because of their very nature: they were groups that came together to assist each other mutually. There are a number of plans in relation to students, funerals and so on. A series of changes was made whilst we were in government. The context that is provided for this series is that these changes will be put in place in order to harmonise that with a number of other measures that have already been taken. The member of the opposition who preceded me, the member for Stirling, dealt with that at some length.
The key point of the bill is schedule 2, regarding the capital gains exemption for certain compensation payments. This is a very important measure and it is timely given that the German government has taken action with regard to a compensation program for German forced labour. The genesis of that program is a foundation, set up on 12 August 2000, which has about seven subsets regionally within the German federation. The foundation was set up to provide compensation to former slave and forced labourers and certain other victims of injustices suffered during the National Socialist period. This measure is an extension, and a very belated one, of a series of other measures that were put into place much earlier. German governments in the past have certainly found it difficult to come to terms with their history.
I had a direct and particular association with victims of National Socialist policy as an electorate officer for the former member for Blaxland when he was Treasurer. Two people who came to see me had been in concentration camps. Both of them had suffered enormously before and during the war. Not only had they been forced labourers but because they were Jewish they had been placed along with many others in concentration camps. In fact, we know that six million people of Jewish descent were killed in the concentration camps throughout Germany and in occupied Europe during the war. We know that those who did not suffer annihilation suffered deprivation, starvation, torture, mental and physical cruelty, and the other abominations that were visited upon them in the death camps—the medical practices and experimentations. A vast panoply of evil was visited not only on those two people but on the six million who are remembered. Another 5½ million or so people—gipsies, disabled people, people who were different because of their sexual orientation because homosexuals were marked by the Nazis to be treated in a special way, and people who suffered from dwarfism—were brought into the general description of effectively being non-Aryan and, therefore, were up for dissolution or annihilation. People who survived the death camps need to be dealt with in a particularly civil way and in a way which recognises what they have been through. 
You can never put it past bureaucrats—as hard as they try to do their work in a way that is sensitive—not to get bound up in the existing law. At the time those people came to see me, although we recognised that those payments were compensation payments to former victims of concentration camps—and I think they were free of tax—the problem was that they were not free from being taken into account for the purposes of assessing income for social security payments. These people were of pensionable age and, because a good part of their lives had been spent living and working in Australia as post war migrants, when they got the compensation payments from overseas their pensions were affected.
Decades after these people suffered under National Socialism's brutalities, finally the German government stepped up to the mark and said, `Our forebears were responsible and we are sorry for what our forebears delivered to the Jewish people and to others.' I note in passing that that has not happened in this House with this Prime Minister in relation to the depredations of our forebears to the original inhabitants here, but the German government has done it in relation to Nazism. They finally were able to look at their past and to look it in the face. They have struggled to do that because what happened was so terrible and went to the core of what their society was about. I believe that the Japanese have still not faced up to what they did to China as a fascist militarist state prior to the Second World War, through to what happened during the war.
Those people who suffered most waited decades. I think it took me more than two years to get it through our parliamentary processes while we were in government and to get our departmental officials to recognise the inhumanity of not taking that income into account. It was not normal income; it was compensation for being incarcerated in a concentration camp in either Germany, Poland or the Ukraine. Good social policy and good public policy must necessarily take that into account. More than a decade on, in August 2000, the German government finally took the other action they needed to. They said that compensation should be given not only to those people whose relatives were obliterated, to the tune of six million of Jewish descent, but also to those people from all over occupied Europe who were drawn into Germany's factories to serve the war effort as slave labour, including children aged 14 who had their lives permanently damaged by it. They finally got recognition.
So the changes I helped to put through, when I was working for the former Treasurer, were in regard to not only those who had been in concentration camps but also those who had served as forced labour. We tried to open it up so that they could have payments made to them. In this case, we are taking the further step of saying that, if there is a capital gains tax element for either the victims or their direct relatives, it is right and proper to take that into account. This not only encompasses those people but deals with property loss as a result of racial persecution. We know that millions of dollars were ripped away from people not because they committed any crime but because, in the eye of the fuehrer and his Reich, they were non-Aryan—that is, they were not of what the fuehrer and his Reich considered to be the pure race. They were people defined as polluting the Aryan race. 
Simply by being defined in a certain way, those people designated as being Aryan in National Socialist Germany had the right to loot the possessions of the people they destroyed in the concentration camps. It also gave those designated as Aryan the right to walk into every house, every abode and every factory of every family whose lives had been put to the test and take all that those people had built up through their work for the whole of their lives. We know, finally, more than 50 years on, that the Swiss government has been brought to task for its culpability during the war, which came to light a couple of years ago. It was a neutral country but it actually took the life savings of those people who had been robbed and deposited them in the accounts of Swiss banks and others. Finally, the Swiss government has been forced to pay some compensation.
This government is doing the right thing in taking these measures with regard to capital gains tax exemptions. It was right for the Labor Party, when it was in government, to take measures with regard to people's income as compensation and to say, `It's only right. It's only just. It's only proper. It's only the most minor of concessions to take account of what dreadful depredations were suffered not only by those who died but by those who survived and by those who were their progeny. It is important for those people to be recognised.' (Quorum formed)
Having dealt with the weighty matters, I will go to our amendment and the government's depredations on the Australian public at large. The government are at fault because, despite arguments to the contrary, we know that—even though the Prime Minister has said they may actually advance tax cuts in the future—there is a tax bracket creep of $17 billion which this government want to divert to their own uses rather than putting it back into the pockets of the people into whose pockets it should be put back.
Indeed, we see one-third of an article given over to this in the Sydney Morning Herald. This is not a case of reading a paper; it is utilising it, as I have seen the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and virtually every member of that frontbench do. It is not just something you do for a lark or as recreation; this is about dealing with it in the speech. In Matt Wade's article, `Tax cuts in doubt as billion-dollar prop for budget is exposed', he makes the point that, with the amount of bracket creep that the government is not willing to give back, what we are looking at is not a budget surplus—as we know—but a budget deficit. Why are we looking at that? Because, starting from the position of running absolutely scared in February and March of last year, a minimum of $14 billion was wasted by this government last year to get themselves re-elected. Every one of the groups that they saw, they thought they needed to buy off—the superannuees, those who are otherwise retired, the pensioner groups. There was $14 billion of fiscal profligacy from March through to the end of the year. In fact, some could argue that it is not $14 billion, but $20 billion.
The Treasurer and the Prime Minister want to say, `This government has been perpetually in surplus.' Whilst we were in government, we were in surplus for four years, and they were the first four years of budget surplus in the entire history of the Commonwealth. Despite the fact that the coalition ruled for most of the time since Federation, it was Labor that first brought in surpluses. Drawing on what Labor achieved through the 1980s and 1990s in restructuring this economy and providing that firm foundation, there should have continued to be surpluses. There should have been a real surplus; the Treasurer should not have had to flip over on whether this was a cash or an accrual budget.
Last year, we were dealing with accrual accounting. This year, the budget is on a cash basis because the accrual basis format simply says the budget is in deficit. That is why the Treasurer changed—away from headline counting—to another form of accounting. The reality is very simple and this government cannot move away from it. They want to take back most of the bracket creep; they want to cover their hides for the profligacy of $14 billion to $20 billion spent on buying the last election. They want to try to keep the budget notionally in surplus rather than accept the reality of the deficit not only on an accrual basis but also on a cash basis. The second reading amendment moved by the shadow Assistant Treasurer has my total support. (Time expired)

name: Danby, Michael, MP
text:
—I rise to support the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) 2002. The bill seeks to make a number of minor changes to the Australian taxation law. I want to focus particularly on the section that will amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 which provides a capital gains tax exemption for payments received by Australian taxpayers under the German Forced Labour Compensation Program. This program provides two types of payments: firstly, for personal wrong or injury, including slavery or forced labour; and, secondly, for property damage or loss where relief under other funds is not available. The payments are made to the victim, to a relative of the victim or to the victim's heir.
Currently, the German Forced Labour Compensation Program payments are not subject to income tax. However, they are subject to capital gains tax in certain circumstances. The amendment extends the current capital gains tax exemption to all payments received by Australian residents under the German Forced Labour Compensation Program. There are approximately 4,000 Australians who have claimed payments under this program, and there are probably many more who are entitled to do so but have not—and that is a subject I will return to in a few minutes. Many other countries have offered similar exemptions. The United States Congress passed legislation in May 2001 exempting survivors of the Nazi Final Solution and their heirs from federal taxes on compensation or restitution payments received after 1 January 2000. Such payments are also exempt from tax in Canada, Finland, France, Greece, Hungary, Israel, the Netherlands and the United Kingdom.
We have all heard that there are two certainties in life: death and taxes. There are other certainties that arise out of the taxes part of that—that is, tax avoidance, tax evasion and tax minimisation, sometimes called aggressive tax planning. Whatever it is called, it is aimed at reducing individuals' liability to taxation. The German Forced Labour Compensation Program payments are currently not subject to ordinary income tax, as they are not income according to ordinary concepts. The program is part of the German economic foundation called Remembrance, Responsibility and the Future, which will provide payments to people who performed slave labour during World War II. The German government and German industry are each providing half of the funds for the foundation.
Around $US5 billion has been contributed to the program to compensate those people who were compelled to work in concentration camps, ghettos or other places of incarceration or other people who were forced to work anywhere in Europe under German occupation under conditions resembling imprisonment or extremely harsh living conditions or perform work under a work program in the Nazi `extermination through work' policy. This was a policy where people were given starvation rations, if rations at all, and were literally worked to death, but some people managed to survive this process because it was stopped by the ending of the war. Each person will receive up to $A12,000. Of course, no amount of money can adequately compensate a person for the horrors they have suffered at the hands of the Hitler regime. However, those reparations by the German government and industry are to be welcomed. I would say they are part of the German government's general remembrance of a part of their history and their atonement for the things that happened. This is an interesting contrast with atonement by the Austrian and the Japanese governments for events during the Second World War, which certainly has not reached anywhere near the degree of importance that it has in Germany.
However, the last thing the government should do with this kind of program and with these types of payments is to tax people at their top marginal rate. I have mentioned that there are many people who do not claim these payments. I can think of a close family friend who is now in his late seventies and is very fit and very active in business. As a young 16-year-old he was taken from Hungary to work with thousands of other slave labourers in a copper mine in Yugoslavia. His story of the work that he did and his liberation, like all of these stories, makes an ordinary Australian who has not experienced these terrors feel in awe of people who could go through such things and lead productive lives afterwards. Of course, many of these people reject these payments as `blood money' that can never compensate for what happened to them or their families. 
These payments are currently subject to capital gains tax because of the broad definitions in the capital gains tax provisions. That tax was introduced by the Hawke-Keating governments over the howls of the coalition, particularly of the current Prime Minister, who was then Leader of the Opposition. I might add that it was introduced to eliminate the greatest form of tax evasion available at the time. At this point it is worth noting that it is the current opposition that consistently has improved the tax system. The Australian Labor Party introduced the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax. It was the Australian Labor Party that has attempted and will continue to attempt to simplify the goods and services tax and the business activity statement. Meanwhile, those on the other side of the chamber, who claim to be friends of small business and who, one would have thought, would therefore be responsible for reducing taxes on business, are in fact dumping the tax burden onto middle Australia. The government are the highest taxing government in the nation's history, yet their mates are still getting away with some tax rorts.
The tax system has always made a distinction between income and capital. The distinguished jurist and former chief justice Sir Owen Dixon described capital as a tree and income as the fruit which grew from the tree. Prior to the capital gains tax, only the fruit was taxed while the tree could grow and grow but was not taxed. This led to tax evasion as taxpayers converted taxable income into tax-free capital gains. Capital gains, no less than income, wages, interest, dividends and business profits, increase an individual's economic status and purchasing power. Given the fundamental tenet of our income tax system that tax should be based on the capacity to pay, capital gains should be taxed. The old system was quite unfair and inequitable as it meant that two people who earned the same amount, with the same purchasing power, would be taxed completely differently depending on whether their money was income or a capital gain. As the tax system was distorted the tax liability was more and more skewed towards middle Australia as the wealthy got away scot free on capital gains.
This, in turn, led to a reduction in compliance as middle Australia found the tax system more and more unfair. Over the years, this parliament has introduced a number of exemptions to the capital gains tax provisions. One of the most notable is the exclusion of compensation payments for personal injury and death. This exclusion, in fact, was a major reform and improvement for the insurance industry. Prior to this, compensation payments had to be artificially increased to take account of the significant amount of compensation payments that was taken by the Commonwealth in capital gains tax. This exclusion allowed for a significant reduction in the quantum of compensation payments. These German forced labour compensation program payments are another form of compensation payment, and therefore should not be subject to capital gains tax. They should not be subject to capital gains tax because capital gains tax was never meant to capture these types of payments and because it does not undermine any of the basic principles of the taxation system of fairness, simplicity and equality.
I particularly take this opportunity to pay tribute to the work of the previous speaker, the member for Blaxland, in arranging changes to the system that enabled the issue of these kinds of payments from individuals to be addressed. Just before I finish, I may ask the Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Vanstone, and her representative in this place, the Minister for Children and Youth Affairs, Mr Anthony, if these payments will also be excluded from consideration in Centrelink payments. These payments are exempted from social security considerations in most other countries. Other similar restitution payments for people who survived the Nazi extermination are exempted from social security considerations, including French payments to orphans of persons who died during the deportation as part of the persecutions during the German occupation of France during World War II and payments from the Dutch fund for needy survivors of the Nazi Final Solution, which are paid through the Executive Council of Australian Jewry. Also, periodic German restitution payments are exempted from the calculation of Australian pensions. I hope these payments will also be exempted. Otherwise, we are giving with one hand and taking away with another. I join members opposite in supporting this bill.

name: Slipper, Peter, MP
text:
—It will not come as any surprise to the opposition that the government does not accept the second reading amendment moved by the honourable member for Kingston.
—You don't like the amendment?
—I have something to say about the second reading amendment, my friend. What I have to say will point out quite accurately that what you claim in the second reading amendment is entirely untrue and simply entirely removed from the real facts of the situation. This bill, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) 2002, contains—(Quorum formed)
I thank my friend opposite for arranging for an audience at this time of the morning. I greatly appreciate the fact that so many people have been prepared to come in and enjoy the facilities of the chamber at this time of the morning. As I was saying before I was so rudely interrupted by the quorum called by the member for Franklin, this bill does contain four very different measures all of which should be welcomed. The government does appreciate the support offered by the opposition with respect to this bill.
Australia has considerable potential to gain a greater share of international financial services business. Australia has a number of advantages, including a stable financial system, a highly skilled work force and a time zone advantage over many other regional markets. In addition, tax reform has made Australia more internationally competitive. However, intense competition for regional financial services centre business means that Australia needs to pursue more actively its role as a centre for financial services. The changes will assist by removing disincentives in the interest withholding tax to the issuing of certain types of debt. There is a perceived risk that issues of debentures might accidentally breach the restrictions on the issuing of debentures to associates and thereby lose the exemption. This bill will remove a possible impediment to Australian companies issuing debentures in Australia and thereby help to further integrate the domestic and offshore corporate debt markets.
The second change will remove an anomaly that has hindered Australian companies raising finance offshore through issues of qualifying securities. The government has also decided to exempt from interest withholding tax interest on nostro or clearing accounts held by financial institutions with foreign banks. The compliance costs are disproportionately high for the small amount of tax collected and removing the tax will make it easier for Australian financial institutions to act as intermediaries between nonresidents. Care has been taken to ensure that the exemption will not be abused. Taken together, these changes should enhance Australia's development as a centre for financial services. 
Secondly, the bill contains measures to give effect to the new tax treatment for funeral policies, income bonds and scholarship plans offered by friendly societies as announced in the budget. These measures are essential to complete the process by which the tax treatment of friendly societies has been modernised in the wake of business tax reform.
The third measure changes the timing of the end of the special transitional provision in the GST law for providers of compulsory third party insurance. At the request of the states and territories, compulsory third party insurers were allowed until 1 July next year to get their systems ready for the GST. The current transitional period rules only cease to apply if a policy is paid for on or after 1 July 2003. This has disadvantages because it applies unevenly. An application provision based on the date the policy commenced will have a more consistent application and be easier for third party insurers to administer because their record-keeping systems always show a date a policy commenced but do not always record when it was paid for. State and territory insurers support this move. 
The last measure in the bill gives effect to the commitment of the government to exempt payments from the German forced labour compensation program from capital gains tax. It removes any confusion about the tax treatment of those payments. Payments from the program to victims for both personal wrongs or injuries and property loss or damage are exempt from capital gains tax but payments to the victims' heirs could have been taxable without this amendment.
I wanted to comment substantively on the points contained in the bill in the event that a succession of quorums was called as I was delivering the government's response to this debate. I did promise the honourable member for Kingston that I would address his second reading amendment and indicate to him why the government is not prepared to accept it. A lot of misleading information has been disseminated recently about the government's tax take as a share of GDP. Unfortunately, most of it has been just plain wrong—and I suspect those opposite are well aware of that fact.
The total income tax paid by Australians as a share of GDP is lower now than it was six years ago during the government's first year in office. This is despite the fact that more than one million new jobs have been created since this government was elected in March 1996. In the year 2000, this government introduced the largest cuts in personal income tax in Australian history, cutting it by $12,000 million—that is, $12 billion. To put that in context: if all this government had done when it came to office was to index tax brackets by the consumer price index, people would be paying more tax than they are today, because the income tax cuts introduced by this government were greater than all of the so-called bracket creep from 1996 to 2002. (Quorum formed)
I think it is unfortunate and fairly puerile that the opposition is doing this at this time of the night. You would not know that Christmas is just down the road. The member for Prospect ought to appreciate that it is not really in order to constantly call quorums just for the sake of disrupting the business of the House. Although it is within the standing orders, it is not appropriate that she should exercise those standing orders at this time of the morning. I suspect that it is something to do with the fact that there is an opposition Christmas party on, and those opposite do not want the parliament to be sitting.
I will continue with what I was saying before I was interrupted by the call for a quorum. As the Treasurer told the House the day before yesterday, Australians are actually paying $500 less than if there had been full indexation over the whole course of this government. Then we have the complaint that the level at which the top marginal rate cuts in is too low. I inform the House that the reason why it cuts in at that level is that the Labor Party opposed our increase. The government bill was to push out the top marginal tax threshold to $75,000 and the Labor Party opposed it.
—You ought not interject, my friend, because you were one of those who voted against what the government proposed. The Labor Party opposed not only the government's plan to lift the level at which the top marginal rate applies but also this government's income tax cuts generally. As the Treasurer also reminded us, the member for Hotham went so far as to refer to the fiscal profligacy of the government's planned personal tax cuts. 
In relation to general taxation receipts, Commonwealth general government sector cash taxation receipts as a proportion of GDP have declined from 23 per cent in 1995-96 to an estimated 20.9 per cent of GDP in 2002-03. In 2002-03 and the forward years, the estimate is that Commonwealth tax share as a proportion of GDP will remain below the levels of the past seven years. I know that Labor says the GST is a state tax but, under the Intergovernmental Agreement on the Reform of Commonwealth-State Financial Relations, all GST revenue is paid directly to the states and territories. GST revenue is not available for expenditure by the Commonwealth. This provides the states with a stable and growing source of revenue to fund important community services such as roads, schools, hospitals and police and allows the states to progressively abolish a range of narrow and growth-reducing taxes.  
The Australian National Audit Office has taken a technical view that the GST is a Commonwealth tax, as it is imposed under the Commonwealth legislation, and quantified the consolidated financial statements for 2000-01 on this basis. The Commonwealth discloses this difference of opinion in the budget papers as required by the Charter of Budget Honesty Act 1998. If the GST is to be added to the Commonwealth tax revenue, then the state taxes it replaces should be subtracted in calculating the overall tax share. In addition, if we are making comparisons over time, you have to compare apples with apples. Should we not factor in the wholesale sales tax and programs such as family tax benefits? This side of the House quite emphatically does not apologise for rejecting the second reading amendment.
In the minutes remaining to me I will comment briefly on a number of other points raised by members of the opposition in this debate. The member for Kingston, the shadow minister at the table, referred to the interest withholding tax amendment and claimed that the government acquiesced to the lobbying of the big end of town. The government did listen to businesses that would be affected by this bill. We are a consultative government—we talk widely and we listen. On further advice the government agreed to provide the interest withholding tax exemption for nostro accounts to all financial institutions that, it was informed, operated these accounts. That probably pre-empts the question that the shadow minister may well ask in the debate on government amendments a little later. The bill and the amendment will reduce costs of borrowing for financial institutions. 
The member for Kingston also claimed that the bill will deny input tax credits for policies that commence before 1 July 2003. Policies commencing before 1 July 2003 do not attract input tax credits under the current legislation if the premium is paid prior to that date. The implication of this bill is that policies which commence on or after 1 July 2003 will attract a credit for eligible businesses, irrespective of whether the payment is made prior to that date.
The member for Stirling referred to the significant Jewish community in her electorate of Stirling. The member for Blaxland also referred to the Jewish community and some of the appalling things that happened to that community in the Second World War. The member for Stirling welcomed the capital gains tax exemption for compensation payments to victims of the National Socialist regime. She also recognised that the bill extends the exemption to other European citizens who were victims of injustices suffered during the National Socialist period. The government recognises the suffering experienced during the National Socialist period and welcomes the support by the member for Stirling for the government's amendment.
The member for Stirling also referred to mass marketed schemes. I just want to say two things in response to her. Firstly, as the Prime Minister has said repeatedly in this place, there is not a shred of evidence to support allegations against the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer. Secondly, in relation to mass marketed schemes, the commissioner himself said that it would have been better if he had acted sooner. But, that said, the commissioner has gone a considerable way to address the balance with a settlement offer which clearly recognises the plight of the unsophisticated investor. Other cases are being pursued through the courts with a number of decisions clearly in favour of the commissioner. Tonight the government has been trying tonight to get passage of a bill to establish the position of inspector-general, a very useful avenue for scheme investors. Because of the quorums having been called, I do not have time to deal with other matters raised by honourable members. We reject the opposition amendment and I commend the bill to the House. 
—The original question was that this bill be now read a second time. To this the honourable member for Kingston has moved as an amendment that all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting other words. The immediate question is that the member for Kingston's amendment be agreed to.
Question negatived.
Original question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Administrator recommending appropriation for the bill and proposed amendments announced.

name: Cox, David, MP
text:
—I rise to speak on the Trade Practices Amendment (Small Business Protection) Bill 2002 [No. 2]. The bill proposes to amend section 87 of the Trade Practices Act 1974 enabling the ACCC to bring representative actions in respect of breaches of section 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act. Members will be well aware of the content of this bill. It is the same bill that Labor set aside on 19 August 2002. The Liberal government has an unflattering history of continually trying to slip into the Trade Practices Act powers that would enable the ACCC to become involved in what are really industrial relations matters. These are matters best heard and resolved through the industrial relations tribunal system. 
The only analytical evidence supporting this bill—evidence that the government appears to be totally reliant upon—is a report by the Australian Law Reform Commission produced in May 1994. Those recommendations are not only eight years old but, importantly, referred to a completely different legal situation to that which exists today. More recently, in August 1999, the Joint Select Committee on the Retailing Sector reported on widening the powers of the ACCC to undertake representative actions. However, that report made no reference to small businesses being disadvantaged as a result of secondary boycotts.
Labor holds firmly to the position that on matters other than industrial relations issues it supports the provision for the ACCC to conduct representative actions under the act. This is particularly in the circumstances where the costs of litigation and the associated legal complexity are beyond the ability of small business to seek legal redress. Therefore, Labor supports the ACCC undertaking representative action on behalf of small businesses for a breach of the Trade Practices Act under the areas where the ACCC currently has an enforcement power and which are properly matters of trade practices law.
However, Labor opposes this bill on the principle that secondary boycotts need to be considered and managed only as matters of industrial relations law. The simple consequences of operating industrial relations matters through the trade practices law would promote an aggressive and less conciliatory approach to the management of industrial disputation. Thus Labor opposes this bill. It does not serve small business well. What this bill really shows is that the Liberal government long ago ran out of good policy ideas on how to improve small business policy. Over the years, the Howard government has consistently and persistently ignored the issues and interests of small business. When it has taken action, it has unfairly added a relentless level of taxation compliance and a corresponding level of business red tape that has transformed one million small businesses into unpaid tax collectors and tax bookkeepers for the government. 
The Institute of Chartered Accountants have expressed concerns about inconsistent or incorrect advice from the ATO, an avalanche of unnecessary paperwork and ridiculous compliance requirements under threat of penalties, duplication of demands due to lack of integration of ATO systems and hours wasted on hold on the ATO help line hoping for a response. This has consequences for small business: they are either paying higher fees to their accountants or are themselves facing the same difficulties. In addition, the Howard government has unleashed hundreds of tax auditors on small businesses to check their compliance with the complex GST. The budget included an extra $804.3 million for the ATO over the next four years to enhance GST administration. Of that, some $190 million has been allocated to small business GST field services to raise an additional $130 million in GST revenue each year. The tax office hopes to raise an additional $3 in revenue for each extra dollar spent on tax administration. That will be a lot of additional GST audits.
The Yellow Pages®Business Index— Small and Medium Enterprises released last week shows that small businesses second most important criticism of the federal government was the GST and its associated paperwork. Labor, unlike the Liberal government, wants to assist small business, not hinder it. Labor has introduced into the House a private member's bill, the Taxation Laws Amendment (A Simpler Business Activity Statement) Bill 2002, which will enable a simpler method for small businesses to calculate their GST remittance. Under Labor's simpler BAS option, each registered business using the ratio method would be given a GST ratio based on its own trading circumstances. The GST liability would be calculated by multiplying business turnover by this ratio.
The simpler BAS option also provides a safe harbour from the potential costs arising from any tax audit. Currently, businesses being audited may have to justify every separate input tax credit claim and account for every separate taxable sale. That is what this self-proclaimed pro-small business government has done to small business—it has driven it to its knees, accounting for every transaction. But under the ratio method, all small business has to do is show that all turnover has been disclosed. This is an example of a simple change which would benefit small business enormously.
Another Labor private member's bill introduced into the parliament will ensure that insurance companies pass on to small business the savings achieved as a result of changes to public liability insurance arrangements instead of using them to boost their own profits. The crisis in public liability insurance has impacted most severely on small business. Small businesses are struggling to obtain public liability insurance at affordable prices, but the Howard government has consistently failed to act to protect small business, despite its clear constitutional responsibility. Most recently, copies of a draft private member's bill aiming to crack down on late payment by big business and government to their small business suppliers was circulated for consultation. Late payment continues to be a severe problem for the cash flow of small businesses. A Yellow Pages survey found that small business considered cash flow to be their second top business concern. This was second only to lack of work or sales. But the Howard government has rejected Labor's call to support this bill, calling the issue of late payments esoteric.
Small business also has other issues that the Howard government is failing to address. Those issues include the availability of skilled staff, access to business skills training and tenancy laws. The government's priorities are clearly wrong. This is proven by the same Yellow Pages survey released last week that found small businesses biggest criticism of the Howard government's policies was that they were too concerned with big business. 
The issues I have identified today are real issues facing small business. The Liberal government should be devoting resources to address these issues instead of playing wedge politics, as shown by this bill. The Howard government is planning to force more red tape on small business with its plan for so-called superannuation choice. Labor proposes to exempt small business from the choice regime to reduce an already overweight compliance burden. (Quorum formed)
If the government really wanted to take some action on trade practices, it would join with Labor in supporting the reforms to introduce criminal sanctions for the most extreme abuses of market power. Instead, the Liberal government prefers to attack the ACCC and Professor Fels. The ACCC is there to ensure strong competition and to protect consumers and small business. It should be supported in performing this function, not attacked and undermined by the Treasurer, the Prime Minister and other ministers.
Further, if the government were genuinely interested in helping small business, it would address the difficulties that small business encounters when dealing with big business. Instead, the Inside Canberra newsletter has reported that Mr Hockey told a meeting of the National Small Business Forum on 20 September 2002 that his department had agreed not to put in a submission to the Dawson inquiry at the urging of many small business groups. But in Senate estimates, in response to Senator Conroy's question, Mr Hockey's department admitted that not one small business group had contacted them to urge them not to respond to the Dawson inquiry.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I am listening attentively to this speech, because I have been called in here so frequently for quorums. I am trying to find a bill called the Joe Hockey bill on the Notice Paper, and I cannot find one. I wonder whether you could direct the member to address the bill, whatever it may be, so that those listening might know what on earth he is talking about.
—The member for Mackellar would make a more powerful point of order if she were aware of what the bill happens to be. The member for Kingston has the call. The bill is the Trade Practices Amendment (Small Business Protection) Bill 2002 [No. 2].
—I am applying the same standards—
—Same standards as whom?
—I won't go there. In February 2002, the New South Wales Chamber of Commerce released its local business and regional affairs survey. The results revealed that in regional New South Wales 61 per cent thought that large firms misused their market power and 67 per cent thought that the ACCC should have more power to halt anticompetitive conduct. However, the government remained silent on these findings.
As this bill clearly shows, the Howard government has lost touch with the concerns of small business. It has also been woefully recalcitrant in dealing with problems of tax administration, public liability insurance and late payment by big business, issues which go to the heart of running a small business. Labor are opposed to this bill and, when the time comes, we will be voting against it here and in the other place.

name: Hunt, Gregory, MP
text:
—I am thrilled to rise to speak on the Trade Practices Amendment (Small Business Protection) Bill 2002 [No. 2] because this bill deals with an issue of fundamental importance. It deals with an issue that cuts to the morality of what we are, who we are and how we live in our society because it addresses one of the great evils. That evil is not simply about trade practices; it is about the notion of bullying. Bullying is the use of force by a stronger actor against a weaker actor to intimidate for personal gain. This bill is about overcoming a problem of bullying within our society. It is about the abuse of power against the defenceless. In this particular case it is about overcoming the problem of secondary boycotts by collective labour against small businesses, which are often run by individuals or a small number of people who have no capacity to protect and defend themselves. 
—Name one!
—In my electorate of Flinders there are 6,000 fine small businesses. (Quorum formed) As I said, this bill is about overcoming the effects of pernicious acts of bullying—bullying that is rife within our industrial relations system. It is rife because collective labour is abusing its position. The member for Kingston asked me a challenging question. He asked me to identify a secondary boycott within my electorate. Let me start with one of the more prominent ones in the last few months. We had a major strike at BHP Steel. BHP Steel was subject to actions by the ETU, the CFMEU and a number of other unions. A series of small businesses and small to medium enterprises within the electorate are in the supply and support area for BHP Steel, and almost all of them went close to the wall. If this bill had been in place and they had been able to receive support from the ACCC, they would have been in a much stronger position and they would have been protected. So go ahead: ask me more questions; I could not be more delighted, my friend.
—The member for Flinders will address his remarks through the chair.
—I was referring to the chair when I said, `My friend.'
—The member for Flinders may continue.
—In continuation, this bill operates by providing the ACCC with the capacity to act as a protector and defender of small businesses which would otherwise not be capable of mustering the economic, legal or general administrative resources to take on a major national organisation.
I want to deal with three things in addressing the bill: the background, its importance and the core provisions. In looking at the background, we find that small business accounts for 95 per cent of all business in Australia's economy and that those 95 per cent collectively employ approximately 50 per cent of Australia's labour force. But that 50 per cent is largely un-unionised and largely subject to the dictates of the collective national organisations if they subsequently become victims of secondary boycotts. Small businesses in particular suffer substantially from restrictive trade practices. The reason is that most are self-funded and rely on narrow profit margins: they cannot afford costly legal disputes and disruptions to trade. Unnecessary union disruptions have adverse effects on producers and consumers and lead to inefficient outcomes.
—What about people, you dope?
—I respect the fundamental right of people to give or to withhold their labour. That is absolutely a core right within our society.
—What about talking to them?
—The member for Lilley! I expected courtesy to be extended to the member for Kingston, and I maintain that the same courtesy will be extended to the member for Flinders.
—It is not a right to take your dispute between one party and another and make a third party the intended or the unintentional victim. That is not the way we operate, that is not what we believe is acceptable and that is not something which we should be upholding or defending. The purpose of the bill, very simply, is to amend section 87 of the Trade Practices Act 1974 by allowing the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission to take representative action against the losses incurred by small businesses through secondary boycotts.
What is the importance of the bill? The bill achieves a number of objectives. It will ultimately provide increased protection to small businesses against disruptive and potentially harmful union action. It does this by allowing the ACCC to take representative actions against contraventions of sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act. Small businesses using this process can claim compensation for union disruptions aimed at causing significant losses—so there is a notion of intention. Small businesses can also claim compensation against union agreements with workers which affect the supply of goods and services. What could be simpler and fairer than to say that a party which is not directly engaged in a dispute should be protected from the harmful consequences of that dispute? That is unless we say that there is a new principle afoot here—that what we allow is an intended victimisation of third parties to achieve a political end. Is that the sort of collateral damage which is encouraged? We have had experience of that in this country over the last year—the notion that collateral damage is not an acceptable approach and not a way to carry out actions. 
Very simply, I believe that this is a bill of great importance. Essentially, its provisions are as follows. Item 1 of schedule 1 enables the ACCC to claim damages against union activities that contravene sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act. This increases the power of the ACCC to support small businesses. Item 2 of schedule 1 outlines the appropriate procedures the ACCC must satisfy prior to any representative action. The effect of this change is to allow the ACCC to initiate proceedings against any breaches under the relevant provisions of the Trade Practices Act.
Ultimately, this bill is about three things: supporting the small business sector; increasing the competitiveness and resilience of the small business sector; and, above all else, placing a stake in the ground and saying that there are certain fundamental principles about bullying which cannot stand. You cannot allow a position where a large national organisation intentionally takes action in order to achieve a particular end, whereby it will claim collateral damage and a victim along the way. If that is not their approach, if that is not their intention, then they have nothing to worry about. But this legislation provides protection for those who would otherwise not be able to protect themselves. There is nothing more fundamentally Australian than fighting against bullying, standing up for those who need protection and standing up for the rights of small businesses—people who go out there and do it for themselves, and work, struggle and sweat to build this country. I commend this bill with all my belief.

name: Fitzgibbon, Joel, MP
text:
—That was a rather repetitive contribution from the member for Flinders. I note that he had 20 minutes allocated to him to make a contribution to this bill. He took just 10, which I think—
—It's quality, not quantity.
—Are you serious? The member for Boothby cannot be serious. The member for Flinders had 20 minutes allocated to him and he took just 10, but he feigned commitment to the small business sector. I did not have the opportunity to do the calculation, but I suggest that he repeated at least one line 6,000 times. I give the member for Flinders some latitude as he has not been in this place for very long and he certainly was not here when the so-called Baird committee deliberated on these issues as they relate to the Trade Practices Act. 
The member for Flinders gave the impression that he might have worked for Peter Reith in the past. I thought he had worked for the current minister for foreign affairs, but one could form the view, based on his contribution tonight, that he might have worked for one Peter Reith, because he has this ideological obsession with the trade union movement. However, the point is that he has ignored all the facts.
It should be no surprise that I should rise to speak on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) 2002, because I am a former shadow minister for small business and have a very deep-seated interest in the small business community in this country. I acknowledge the contribution that the small business sector makes to the Australian economy. It is a growing contribution. We all acknowledge the changing nature of the Australian economy. Our workplaces are growing much smaller. We are working with much smaller business units in the modern economy. The Fordist regime is behind us. The small business sector will play an increasingly important role in the Australian economy.  
However, the member for Flinders misses the point in all of this. The key point is that this is a non-event; this is a red herring. I sat on the Baird committee, as did the member for Eden-Monaro, and this issue was not raised with the committee. The member for Scullin is in the House this morning and he also sat on the committee. This is an issue that was not raised with the Baird committee. I remind the House that the impetus for the establishment of the Baird committee was a Labor Party commitment prior to the 1998 election to hold an inquiry into market concentration in the retail sector. It was the Labor Party which first acknowledged that that market concentration was causing problems for the small business sector. They were having difficulty competing with the Woolworths and the Coles of this world. 
It was Labor who first committed to addressing those problems and, reluctantly, the Howard government was dragged screaming to match that commitment prior to the 1998 election. I remember it very well. I was surprised at the end of the day that they had committed themselves to doing so because, as we all know, the Howard government is not about markets; it is about big business. It is not about small business. It relies on big business for its patronage and for its political donations. So I was surprised but pleased that the Howard government matched Labor's commitment to hold an inquiry into market concentration in the retail sector. 
We got through the 1998 election and, unfortunately, the Labor Party lost—I can acknowledge that. The Howard government then had to turn its mind as it did. I note that the minister for small business is entering the chamber now. What an opportunity for him to make a contribution to this debate. Following the election, the Howard government had to make good on its commitment to hold this inquiry. Of course, there was a lot of jostling going on on the other side of the House at that point about positions on the front bench. The member for Cook was one of those lobbying hard for a guernsey but, alas, he missed out so he was given second prize—he was made the Chairman of the Joint Select Committee on the Retailing Sector. 
But the member for Cook did not realise at the time that he was being handed the poisoned chalice, because he was given a brief that the Howard government did not support. He was told to hold an inquiry but was told quite clearly not to expect to make any recommendations that would be supported by the government. In other words: `Go and do the inquiry, member for Cook, but don't go in too hard. Don't do too much for the small business sector. Don't make any effective recommendations to the government because, at the end of the day, the Howard government is for the big end of town. We feign interest in the small business sector, but at the end of the day we know where our bread is buttered—it is the big end of town. So don't expect to come back to us with recommendations that are going to help the small business sector at the expense of the big end of town.'
The member for Cook accepted the brief and away he went, and we held a fairly extensive inquiry. It was an informative inquiry. We heard all sorts of evidence about the impact of market concentration in the retail sector and the impact it had on the small business sector and its ability to compete in the marketplace. We heard some very sad stories about the misuse of that market power on behalf of the big end of town and the impact of that on the small business sector.
It was also effective in the sense that there was a bipartisan spirit—I know the member for Scullin will agree—and a bipartisan approach to the recommendations of that committee. We all agreed that part IV of the Trade Practices Act had to be strengthened because there were fines for misuse of market power of up to $10 million, if I remember correctly, but they were not of any assistance to the small business person who had been affected by the misuse of market power. So we agreed unanimously that part IV of the Trade Practices Act should be strengthened so that not only big business could be fined for misuse of market power but also, while the ACCC has the big end of town in the commission, they could also seek compensation for the small business that has been affected by that misuse of market power. 
We all agreed on that, but we had a minor disagreement on one point—that is, sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act. The Labor Party do not believe that 45D and 45E should be in the Trade Practices Act. We think they are best enshrined in industrial relations law, so why would the Labor Party seek to extend the representative action powers of the ACCC to 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act? It makes no sense. Yet what did the government do? The government held the opposition and the small business sector to ransom. Rather than accept there was no point in insisting that the additional representative action powers of the ACCC go to 45D and 45E, rather than just allow that to be carved out and got on with, the government dug in. Months went past, a period in which small business could have had access to these new provisions. But the government was not concerned about the small business sector; it was concerned about the politics of it because, at the end of the day, it is always about the trade union movement. We saw the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations earlier in the week waxing lyrical about New South Wales legislation which enshrined the role of the mine workers union in New South Wales to play its part in safety issues in the coalmining industry.
—At least you stood up for them.
—I did stick up for them. That is a practice that has been going on for decades. It has been enshrined in regulation for decades. All the New South Wales government was seeking to do was take that a step further and enshrine it in the legislation itself, but Minister Abbott had a problem with that. Why? Because he saw another opportunity to give the trade union movement a whack and, at the same time, give the Labor Party a whack by virtue of the close association between the trade union movement and the Australian Labor Party. This is just silly. This is a government that is not driven by an interest in the small business sector; it is driven by an ideological obsession with the trade union movement.
—The member for Hunter will understand that I have for the last five minutes or so been waiting for him to come back to the point he was making about the bill on small business protection. I am not denying him the call, I am inviting him to return to the bill.
—I am making a point about the bill, Mr Speaker. The point I am trying to make is that the government waxes lyrical about the need to extend the ACCC's power to take representative action under 45D and E of the Trade Practices Act, yet the member for Flinders, when challenged to give an example of where small business—
—I did give an example.
—You mentioned the BHP case. If I remember correctly, that was a case about market power and nothing to do with 45D and E of the Trade Practices Act. So the member for Flinders might want to go and check that, and the member for Eden-Monaro might want to as well. He was very confident about the proposition put forward by the member for Flinders but I do not hear him challenging me at the moment. The member for Flinders might want to check his facts about the BHP case. My memory is that it was not a case about secondary boycotts.
The member for Flinders has still failed to give us an example of where the small business sector has been disadvantaged by a secondary boycott. I thought former minister Reith up at the dispatch box day in and day out throughout the course of the MUA dispute would have been giving us examples of small businesses that had been affected by secondary boycotts throughout the course of that dispute. I do not remember him giving one example. I remember with very great clarity that, throughout the course of the Baird inquiry, not once did we receive a submission claiming that the small business sector needed an extension of the ACCC's power to take action under 45D and E of the Trade Practices Act. Nor at any point did we ever hear of a case where small business had been affected by a secondary boycott contrary to 45D and E of the Trade Practices Act. This is simply a non-event.
If the government were serious, they would have said, `Well, we accept that there were numerous submissions to the Baird inquiry that suggested that, under section 46 of the Trade Practices Act, misuse of market power, it is time to give the ACCC additional powers to take action for compensation for small business,' and forgot about 45D and E because it was not an issue. Rather than do that—and this is the point and why I transgressed a little—the government put their ideological obsession with the trade union movement ahead of the interests of small business. That is what it was all about. 
—I am happy to return to the bill. The bill is about extending powers to the ACCC to take representative action on behalf of small business. The Labor Party and the government agree wholeheartedly that under section 46, covering all those misuses of market power provisions, when the ACCC is in the court prosecuting the big end of town for doing the wrong thing, at the same time it should be able to take action to gain compensation for the small business that has been affected. But 45D and E are not an issue. When the Labor Party moved amendments in this place to carve out 45D and E, I would have been happy for the government to stick to their view on those sections. They should have said, `Look, we would prefer 45D and E to remain in the provisions. If we can't have that, for goodness sake, let's make sure the ACCC picks up these extra powers under section 46 of the Trade Practices Act.'
That would have been an eminently sensible thing for the government to do. But the government are not interested in small business. It is a bit like the ASIO bills. They feign concern about national security issues, but at the end of the day it is all about the wedge—not small business and not national security. They say, `Let's bring legislation in here that we know is unacceptable to the Labor Party and drive the wedge in.
