Let's hold national security to ransom; let's hold the small business sector to ransom. It doesn't matter whether the small business sector is going to be disadvantaged in the interim.' We had the Baird committee report a long time ago—the member for Scullin might assist me; he waves it around; I was confident he would have all his information before him—and we are still arguing the case. The ACCC still does not have additional powers to take representative action.
—I am sure it is not lack of information that prevents the member for Scullin from assisting but, I suspect, his understanding of the standing orders.
—The ACCC should have these additional powers now, but, no, the government just drive the wedge in all the time, feigning concern for the small business sector and feigning concern on national security. But at the end of the day it is just about the wedge.
—The member for Indi interjects. I have always got a great interest in the interjections of the member for Indi. She claims to represent the interests of the small business sector. I never hear her putting forward any sound propositions to assist the small business sector. I heard her very loud support for the GST. Isn't it funny? The Treasurer stands at the dispatch box each day in question time waxing lyrical about the GST, having us all believe that the transition has been just marvellous for the small business sector. He has closed his ears. Of course the small business sector is still struggling with the introduction of the GST. Of course it has increased their compliance costs burden. Yet all the government are interested in doing is driving the wedge in. We saw another example in the House yesterday during question time, by virtue of the contribution of the member for Werriwa, where a builder had given services to the minister—
—That's Bob the Builder!
—Bob the Builder; I will get to him in a minute. The Minister for Revenue owed $40,000.
—I can pass my folder across to him.
—The Minister for Small Business and Tourism does not have the call.
(Quorum formed)
—I was hoping Bob the Builder would come in— 
—The member for Hunter will return to the bill.
—because it seems the only interest the coalition has in small business in recent days is in ensuring that Bob the Builder in Port Stephens gets an opportunity to—(Time expired)

name: Jenkins, Harry, MP
text:
—As I indicated to you, Mr Speaker, this could be a heroic contribution to this debate. I will try, because I want to make one point about this debate—and I am pleased that there are at least a number of people in the chamber. This bill is a double dissolution trigger, a section 57 trigger. If those in the chamber look at the blue, they will see that the title of the bill is the Trade Practices Amendment (Small Business Protection) Bill 2002 [No. 2]. The square brackets mean that it is a section 57 trigger bill, and here we are at 3.45 a.m. on the last sitting day of this session discussing this bill. 
When the honourable member for Flinders gets on his feet and says he is thrilled to debate this bill, I just wonder why he does not have other colleagues supporting him on this bill. The minister knows that this bill was down for debate last week, and one of the reasons that he put it off is because he knows that he has difficulty getting it through the Senate. This is just a stunt—an absolute stunt. It is being set up for ideological reasons, and the honourable member for Hunter went through those. The government says it is fair dinkum about looking at the needs of small business. One thing on which I agree with the honourable member for Flinders is that small business needs to be protected from the actions of bullies—but have a look at the evidence that has been put before a number of inquiries and before the government about what type of action is the action of bullies.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The point of order is on relevance. This is not relevant to the bill.
—I will determine whether or not the member for Scullin is being relevant to the bill. The member for Scullin has the call.
—I am pleased the honourable member for Dawson has intervened, because I am shocked that she is not making a contribution to this bill about the future and the protection of small business. I have an article here from the Financial Review where the honourable member for Dawson, in talking about the need to protect small business, does not talk about sections 45D and 45E but about section 46 and related matters. She quite rightly, on the basis of evidence that was put to the Baird inquiry, said that the concern was about the larger retailers and the way in which they manipulated markets to ensure that suppliers were squeezed. The honourable member for Dawson knows that the people she represents in this place are the type of suppliers that are squeezed.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The point of order is on relevance. This bill does not refer to the Australian Financial Review. I would ask the member for Scullin to refer to the bill.
—The member for Dawson will resume her seat. The member for Scullin is being relevant to the bill.
—Slowly, and, if I can find the monosyllables, I will speak in monosyllables, I will read from the explanatory memorandum where the government, in justifying the reasons for this bill, under the heading `Consultation', says:
The proposed measures were considered by the Joint Select Committee on the Retailing Sector, in its August 1999 report, entitled Fair Market or Market Failure? The Committee consulted with peak business organisations, enforcement agencies and government departments.
That is true; that consultation went on. But I do not remember that evidence was put before the committee of small business concern, especially in the retailing sector, about actions under sections 45D and 45E.
In other literature about this legislation, the Reid committee is referred to. The Reid committee reported to this place in May 1997. That report, entitled Finding a balance: towards fair trading in Australia, went to issues about the actions of what the honourable member for Flinders might refer to as `bullies'.  
—I am pleased that a number of members of the class of 2001 want to talk about action. They suggest that, in talking about a report from 1997, we are living in the past. If you look at this report and at the actions of this government, nothing much has changed. I was willing to acknowledge that, at least in the area of franchising—much to my amazement, because it was a code installed by the sector itself—there has been some improvement. That was a classic sector where small business, because of the actions of people with market power, were bullied, and where the market did not have a level playing field. Action needed to be taken to ensure that small business had a chance of surviving people who could be described as bullies.
Those people who want to talk about the Reid inquiry as a piece of history might go down to their local shopping mall and ask the businesses there whether the issues about retail tenancies mentioned in that report have changed over five years. They might ask whether the imbalance has been corrected between those who run the shopping malls and the small businesses that try to operate there. Fortunately, through the actions of state and territory governments—and, I have to acknowledge, not just those of Labor Party persuasion but also those of coalition persuasion—improvements have been made in the way in which states and territories, who have responsibility for retail tenancy matters, are acting. The point is that these are the issues that are of the utmost concern to small business. The two inquiries of this parliament have indicated that.
As the honourable member for Hunter has indicated, the opposition continues to express the view that, if some sort of action is required, this is an industrial relations matter; it is not a matter of trade practices. The issues of imbalance in markets are to do with other sections of the Trade Practices Act. If we are to see representative actions being taken by the ACCC, as the honourable member for Hunter has indicated, section 46, `Misuse of market power', is one of the areas that needs to be looked at. They are the issues that the honourable member for Dawson, in taking up a debate with people like Roger Corbett, from Woolworths, should be looking at. We should be looking at that area to make sure that it is strengthened and to make sure that the ACCC is given the resources to take representative action.
I believe we are being diverted by this debate. If we want to spend the House's time debating small business issues, then we should look at the proper issues and not be diverted by section 45D and 45E matters. I think it is important that the imbalance of market power or the actions of bullies are discussed—but let us identify the bullies. If the concerns that led to the Baird inquiry were relevant then, we should look at the current statistics on the market share of the big retailers. Back in 1999, at the time of the Baird inquiry, Woolworths and the Coles group had a 68.3 per cent share of the retail market. In 2002, that has increased to 74.2 per cent. It was a problem back then, so the fact that it has now increased by another six per cent is the type of issue that we should be looking at in considering amendments to the Trade Practices Act. That is what this bill is about. It is proposing amendments to the Trade Practices Act. The opposition is saying that those amendments are misguided—that they are amendments to the wrong sections.
If we want to do the proper thing by small business, we should take on board these other issues that are important to the future of small business. What are the types of issues that an organisation such as NARGA, representing smaller retailers, are still championing in their literature? For one, they indicate that, under the review that is taking place of the Trade Practices Act, there should be a review of the way that section 46 operates. In their contribution to the Trade Practices Act review, they do not mention sections 45D and 45E but, much to the embarrassment of the government, they mention GST compliance and other matters that are not covered by this bill. That is the point that the opposition is making—that this is a misguided piece of legislation because it really does not go to the issues that small business are interested in. One can only conclude that this piece of legislation is driven by ideology more than any other reason. 
As I said from the outset, I am really concerned that we are having this type of debate over a bill that is a section 57 trigger. I am not sure that many people understood that, between the hours of three and four o'clock in the morning, on the last day of the parliamentary session, we would actually be discussing matters to do with a bill that could potentially be used as a double dissolution trigger. That is really the crux of the matter. The minister knows that he is not going to get this legislation through the Senate. He says the justification for the lack of government speakers on this piece of legislation is that it has been discussed before, on two occasions: the original bill this year and the 2000 amendment bill to the Trade Practices Act. I am sorry, but that is not good enough. If this is something that the government wants to put forward, we really should be having a full debate, on the basis that it is potentially a double dissolution trigger. It concerns me that, in the late, late phase of this session, this is the way the debate is being handled.
As I have said, there are other matters that we really should be looking at. If the honourable member for Dawson and Senator Boswell are putting pressure on their coalition partners to ensure that these other matters are investigated and discussed, they should tell me how that is progressing. One of the recommendations of the Baird inquiry was that there should be a review of the matters investigated in 1999. If 1999 is too far in the past, I am sorry. But those two inquiries are still relevant, because many of the issues that were put to those inquiries have still not been addressed, and are not addressed by this piece of legislation.
Having been a member of both inquiries, the reason I intervened in the debate was that both inquiries are used as justification for this bill. That is a distortion of what was discussed, what was investigated and what was presented to those inquiries. If we are going to have the debate, let us be fair dinkum about it. If people want to talk about bullies, let us identify the real bullies—the ones who are really giving small business concerns. If we had gone through the franchisees and through the policy, we would have done that. If we look at larger retailers—
—Who is the bully?
—If the minister does not know what the other ones are, he cannot be going around. He is up here lecturing us—
—When are you going to drink the water?
—Listen, Doc, you might have to prescribe something. I understand that.
—The member for Scullin will come back to the legislation. 
—I am not sure that the minister is concentrating more on other aspects of his portfolio than on small business. But let him go down to shopping malls and let him knock on the doors of businesses and ask them whether they think they have a fair relationship with the people who operate those malls, whether they really think they are getting a fair deal. Let us have the laughter about the May 1997 report, but those issues are still real. Remember that this was the report that brought the downfall of an earlier minister for small business in the honourable member for Forrest. These issues are still around, and they are the types of things the opposition is saying we should be concentrating on more. It is because those two reports were mentioned that I wished to make a contribution. As I said, it dismays me that we are having this debate at this hour, with little contribution from the other side—
—When do you want to have it?
—You could have had it last Monday, Joe.
—We've had it four times.
—You could have had it last Monday when you put it on the list, and you withdrew it—
—Order! The Minister for Small Business and Tourism and the member for Scullin will address their remarks through the chair.
—Yes, Mr Speaker. There is no excuse, even at four o'clock, for disorderly behaviour.
—The member for Scullin, on that note, has the call. 
—I am a bit worried about the advice I am getting from Dr Nelson! They are issues I hope the minister will have a look at. I hope that, from his interjections, he is not saying that we do not continue to have problems in those areas, because they are of continuing concern to small business. They are the types of issues that make it difficult for small businesses to compete, whether they are in the retail sector or are suppliers to the retail sector—the types of people the honourable member for Dawson and Senator Boswell continue to champion. They are the types of issues we should be spending time on debating. I suggested from the outset that this would be a heroic contribution and, perhaps as I need to move on to other duties in the chamber, I will leave it. Fundamentally, as we have this debate, nothing has changed. We know what the outcome will be as it goes through this House and the Senate. I continue to be in opposition to the provisions of this bill.

name: Ciobo, Steven, MP
text:
—I am delighted to rise to speak to the Trade Practices Amendment (Small Business Protection) Bill 2002 [No. 2]. This is a very important bill. I listened with great interest to what the member for Scullin had to say, for two reasons. The first was to hopefully decipher the occasional word or sentence he said, and the second was to hear what he had to say with respect to the Howard government introducing and implementing an ideology. It is most interesting that those who sit in opposition would be concerned that the Howard government are introducing an ideology. What else would we be doing? We go to the polls to introduce legislation; we go to the polls on a policy platform. It might all be new to those who sit on that side of the House, but we go with policy to an election. When we get elected, we come to this chamber and to the Senate to make sure that we introduce that legislation. What we have is the Howard government once again introducing and delivering on promises we made at an election. What we heard was union payback. The time has now come for the Labor Party union hacks who sit on that side of the chamber to repay their dues to the union movement.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. My point of order is on relevance, under standing order 145. You were pretty tough on me in terms of relevance.
—The member for Hunter will resume his seat.
—You pulled me into order and you should do the same with the member for Moncrieff.
—I have listened to the member for Moncrieff, whose early remarks have been entirely consistent with the latitude extended to the member for Scullin. 
—Can I draw the link for the opposition, who fail to be able to follow the link, between the union movement and the Labor Party and how this bill has direct application—
Opposition members interjecting—
—Throughout this entire debate, I have attempted to ensure that members were heard in relative silence, recognising the hour of the day. The same courtesy as was extended to the  member for Scullin will be extended to the member for Moncrieff.
—To draw the link for those in opposition who are unable to make the connection, the fact is that this bill goes directly to the way the union movement operates. This is the reason we hear the howls and screams from those opposite. Why? Because they are trying to repay their union dues.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. My point of order is on relevance, under standing order 145. Let us be fair about this. The member for Moncrieff has not mentioned the bill yet—
—The member for Hunter will resume his seat. 
—When I went on to ideological links you called me to order, and you should do the same to the member for Moncrieff.
—The member for Hunter will resume his seat. 
—That is a valid point of order. 
—Any reflection on the chair will be sternly dealt with. The member for Moncrieff will return to the bill. 
—This bill deals directly with ways in which the union movement will no longer be able to prosecute small businesses in this country. Through the introduction of secondary boycott provisions within the Trade Practices Act, this government will effectively ensure that small businesses will no longer be held to ransom by union movements. There have been far too many examples of the trade union movement blockading wharves and doing things like that, the direct consequence being third parties adversely affected by union thuggery. So, when other members in the government stand up to speak about the ways in which this bill directly prevents thuggery, they do so because they recognise that it is the union movement and their protectors in this House, the Labor Party, who cause this type of thing. With respect to other comments that the member for Scullin made—
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The member for Moncrieff entirely misunderstands—
—The member for Hunter will resume his seat. I have the bill in front of me and I have been listening closely to the member for Moncrieff. He has linked his remarks to the provisions for secondary boycotts which are covered in the bill. In this case, I would suggest the member for Hunter acquaint himself with the bill, because if he continues to challenge the chair I will deal with him.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I have been in this chamber for some time now this morning and I would like you to draw the attention of the member for Hunter to standing order 303—
—The member for Dickson will resume his seat, or I will draw his attention to standing order 303. The member for Moncrieff has the call.
—It is very clear that those opposite do not have the ability to understand—
—Mr Speaker, I believe that the member for Moncrieff, perhaps inadvertently, perhaps on purpose—
—Does the member for Grayndler have a point of order?
—Yes. My point of order is that he used unparliamentary language in that he accused collectively of thuggery the group of people who sit on this side of the chamber.
—The member for Grayndler will resume his seat. He is aware there is no point of order. The member for Moncrieff has the call.
—So he is welcome to say what he likes.
—The member for Grayndler is welcome at any stage to check House of Representatives Practice or the standing orders and come back to me after the House has risen, indicating where there is any—note `any'—inconsistency with that ruling.
—With respect to other comments made by the member for Scullin, I was interested to hear the criticism put forward that this was, in fact, a double dissolution trigger and that the government perhaps should have brought it on some weeks ago. What I find most interesting about these comments, with respect to the Trade Practices Amendment (Small Business Protection) Bill 2002 [No. 2], is that we have put forward this proposition on a number of occasions previously. Tonight, when the opposition claims to be so concerned about the ways in which small businesses are going to be affected and says, `No, this isn't a restrictive trade practices issue; this is an industrial relations issue,' its benches are completely empty! Yet a number of government members have been here throughout this entire debate.
—You run the program, you dope!
—I will deal equally with the member for Lilley! The member for Moncrieff has the call. The member for Lilley, as the Manager of Opposition Business in the House, expects me to protect members on my left, which I have done all night. I am now extending precisely the same courtesy to members on my right. I would expect, in that exercise, the endorsement of the Manager of Opposition Business. 
—Mr Speaker, I cannot help but notice that your role, in my view, would be somewhat akin to the enforcement role that the ACCC will have to undertake when this legislation goes through. I thank you for that support.  I hope it demonstrates in some way an analogy to the opposition members about why this legislation is so important and why this legislation should be introduced.
I would particularly like to address a point that was raised by the opposition about whether it is an industrial relations issue or whether it is a restrictive trade practices issue. The Trade Practices Act is a cornerstone of Liberal Party philosophy in the sense that it is about promoting free market competition and competition in the marketplace that ensures good outcomes for all. It ensures dynamic and temporal efficiencies, it ensures that the consumers benefit and it ensures that, in the marketplace, there is a continued development and proactivity with respect to research and development and all of the things that are by-products of a competitive marketplace. Far too often, it is the union movement that resorts to thuggery to achieve an outcome—as has been demonstrated when they have blockaded wharves and this government stood up to them, when they blockaded other businesses or when they charged in and destroyed premises, as was demonstrated by the royal commission into building practices. Far too often, the consequences of this thuggery is that it is small businesses, the mums and dads, the people who work 60- or 70-hour weeks to generate and operate a profitable small business, who are adversely affected by those who are quite happy to skim off the union fees that are paid, not having to actually be accountable for their wages. For those people to make the decision, `Let's go and blockade this wharf and, if the consequences of that are that many small businesses go bankrupt, so be it'—
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. This time are you going to accept my proposition under 145?
—The member for Hunter has been in this House for long enough to know that standing order 145 relates to questions.
—I see that the member for Hunter is as confused about standing orders as he is about the impact of this bill. In the interests of brevity and the efficiency of the House at this time of the evening, I will conclude my remarks on the following points. This bill is a direct way in which the Howard government delivers on a promise that it made. This bill, if passed, is a direct way in which the Howard government demonstrates once again its genuine commitment to helping thousands of small businesses. On that point, I have a vested interest because Moncrieff is the small business capital of the country and, from my perspective, it is fundamentally important. (Quorum formed) I am delighted that the opposition has brought in government members so they can hear about the way in which this bill will directly assist small businesses—by stopping union thugs, union members, who will resort to anything in order to get their way. As the representative for Moncrieff, the small business capital of the country, I am delighted that the Howard government and the Minister for Small Business and Tourism, the Hon. Joe Hockey, is doing a fantastic job in delivering this legislation which directly benefits thousands of small businesses.
—I refer to House of Representatives Parliamentary Practice, page 158. The second last paragraph refers to how, in 1977, the Speaker indicated that it was `acceptable for members to wear tailored safari suits without a tie'. As far as I am concerned, the member for Flinders is not wearing a safari suit and is therefore wearing inappropriate dress.
—If the member for Grayndler was alert to the forms of the House he would be aware that earlier this evening—and not that much earlier because it is not a convenient hour—I had required the member for Blair to excuse himself from the House. All other members are dressed as is frequently allowed for quorums and divisions; however, the quorum having been formed, I invite those who are not attired as they normally would be to excuse themselves from the House. The action of members has been entirely consistent with what has been the practice in the House for as long as I have been in the House. 
—I will certainly be publicising in my electorate the way the Labor Party treats the operation of this House, even if it is 4.20 in the morning. Fundamentally, all we have had from the Labor Party this morning is obfuscation. We have had quorum after frivolous and spurious quorum, and now they are resorting to references to safari suits and those types of things. It all comes down to one point: it is not the Labor Party that cares about small business; it is in fact the Howard government that delivers for small business, looks after small business, and treats this House and this process with the respect they deserve.

name: Hatton, Michael, MP
text:
—In coming to this bill, the last one I will be speaking on this year, I say at the outset that this is not a weighty bill. The Trade Practices Amendment (Small Business Protection) Bill 2002 [No. 2] is the flimsiest, most insubstantial and most unconcerted bill you could find. The short title hardly makes one-third of the page. On page 2, there are 1½ lines. Amendments to schedule 1 of the Trade Practices Act 1974, which this bill seeks to change, consist of three paragraphs: paragraph 87(1A)(b), paragraph 87(1B)(a). All this bill actually says—
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. When the standing orders were framed I think they endeavoured to have members talk about the content of a bill, not what it looks like or the logistics of it.
—The member for Blaxland's opening remarks were consistent with the latitude extended to the member for Moncrieff, whose remarks were also leading up to what the bill contained. I do not consider that the member for Blaxland is outside the standing orders.
—I hardly think I could be outside the standing orders if I am reading the provisions of the bill. Paragraph 87(1A)(b) says:
Omit “(other than section 45D or 45E)”.
This is not just a question of relevance. This is what you do not get from ministers answering questions: contextual relevance. Item 2 is paragraph 87(1B)(a):
Omit “(other than section 45D or 45E)”.
Paragraph 3, `Application', states:
The amendments made by this Schedule apply only to conduct engaged in after the commencement of this Schedule.
That is relatively simple, you would think, but there is actually no more to the bill. So we could finish there, but I am sorry to say that we will not. There is a little bit more to this in terms of its design and intent. There have been very few speakers on this bill on the coalition side. Perhaps they were not drawn to it, because of the flimsy nature of this bill and the fact that it had been through the House. I was delighted by the superb speech made by the member for Scullin—rather than the member for Scullion—Deputy Speaker Jenkins, who is now in the chair. Not only was he on fire but he put the arguments very well and dealt with the Baird committee report that dealt with the trade practices matters relevant to this bill today and with the Reid report. I remember Bruce Reid and his report into shopping centres, I think it was: the operation of shopping centres, market power and the fact that Woolworths and Coles dominate the market.
As the member for Hunter pointed out, these reports were generated by the concerns of the Labor government before they lost government in 1996. The core of what the current government has argued—not particularly well, I would advert—is that, while the Labor Party does not really understand what they are about here, in making these changes to the Trade Practices Act 1974, they are about looking after small business. They have that concern at the very core of what they deal with in all of their government practices, and that is the one key thing they have been committed to. Well, if you believe that line you are readily taken in. The argument they put was that Labor does not understand—speaking contextually relevantly to the bill—that, when they say this was in the industrial relations area and that this is the area it should be in, they are mixing things up. 
That is part of the key to our reaction to this bill. This is not about secondary boycotts, but that is all that the government members can talk about. Sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act are an utter obsession and an utter fixation for this coalition. That has been the case for the Prime Minister since 1974 when he walked out of a suburban solicitors' practice and into parliament. It is an obsession that the coalition cannot get away from, and one that totally fixates and transfixes them. I am sorry; the argument just does not wash. Secondary boycotts are illegal under this coalition government. That is not news. What may be news to the government, and certainly to the members who have spoken in this debate, is that secondary boycotts were illegal under the Keating and Hawke Labor governments. The core point of the coalition's argument has no foundation in fact. This is not about secondary boycotts. What we have argued is simply that the illegality of the prohibition of secondary boycotts lies in the industrial relations area.
If this legislation is passed in the House tonight, despite what I have said and will say, despite what the distinguished Deputy Speaker Jenkins argued so cogently—and, indeed, at 3.45 in the morning, coherently—and despite what the member for Hunter argued, it will be a half step away from becoming a trigger for a double dissolution. That will be sometime next year, if the government get around to putting it up to the Senate and if it gets knocked over again. The core point is: knowing that secondary boycotts are illegal and were prohibited not only by them but by us, why have the government taken a certain range of actions to stop us talking about this bill? The minister at the table is seeking advice on doing that now. The reason is that there has been a bit of contracting out and a bit of consultation. We know that there have been a few consultants to this government. We know that the former minister for industrial relations, former member for Flinders Peter Reith, hired a consultant to look at this area—to look at what the problems were and at how to make a transition from the Industrial Relations Commission. We know that the Industrial Relations Commission was founded in 1904 and I think the Harvester decision was its most significant early decision in 1905. Although industrial relations have worked so successfully in this country, the government wanted to obliterate the Industrial Relations Commission. When former Minister Reith got Des Moore to take up an appointment as a consultant to look into this area, he knew that secondary boycotts were illegal. But the brief to Des Moore was: `Get us out of the industrial relations area and take us into trade practices. Tell us how we can move from one area to the other. Tell us how we can give power to the ACCC'—as the government are attempting to do with this bill—`to unleash their investigative dogs onto single unions, in pursuit of denying them their right to organise within workplaces.' We have seen it on the waterfront, with the MUA. We have seen the attempt, time and time again, to unleash those forces against individual unions.
Let me go to a particular point. Having established that secondary boycotts are not illegal and, therefore, that they should be kept within the jurisdiction of the Industrial Relations Act and the industrial relations powers, let us look at one of those key areas. I have already alluded to part 1 of this flimsy bill, which deals with the kind of action that can be taken take under the Trade Practices Act, and what might be permitted. I will simply state the case in terms of what the Bills Digest has said about ACCC representative action. It says:
Section 87 of the Trade Practices Act 1974 (TPA) permits the ACCC to bring a representative action seeking compensation and other remedies on behalf of people who have suffered, or are likely to suffer loss or damage as a result of another person's contravention of specified provisions of the TPA.
Normally when we are dealing with the Trade Practices Act we expect that we are dealing with people involved in a particular industry in a competitive situation and that we are attempting to ensure that non-competitive activity does not occur. It can happen that very large and substantial companies today were once small businesses. It is possible to argue—and I think there are a number of cases in which it can be substantiated—that very large companies can sometimes have practices that are extremely uncompetitive. It could be the case that when they were generated and started out they might have had uncompetitive practices as well. Even given the effluxion of time, there may be action that could be taken by the ACCC in relation to competitors. 
It just so happens that I know a bit about this. Although I told the House about my mother's family small business background, I have not talked about the most significant small business background in my family history, and that is H. Hatton and Sons of Bankstown. In 1921, when the Torch opened, they were greengrocers and confectioners, but as Bankstown changed and grew my grandfather built a business in construction. Because of the nature of Bankstown, his business covered the whole range of activities—they carted sand and wheat, delivered coal to people throughout the Bankstown area and also advised people on how to build concrete steps, houses, housing extensions and so on. They were renowned in the area and, in Greenacre, which is part of my electorate and the City of Bankstown, they had an ice run. As you would expect with any small company in those days, which my grandfather's company was—based in Allum Street in Bankstown—an ice run was pretty hard work. They bought large blocks of ice from the Punchbowl ice company, paid good money for them and then delivered them to people's doorsteps.
—It is 25 minutes to five in the morning. I implore the member for Blaxland not to talk about ice runs and to the keep the House going. If there is a way in which this debate can be shortened, it would be appreciated because there are a number of divisions to come.
—There is a point of utter and complete contextual relevance in this story. It is not just relevant to the Trade Practices Act but also to the very point that the ACCC is being asked to intervene on in relation to this bill. Normally, you would run up and down the street, get people their ice with the tongs, whack it on their doorsteps and take their money. One day, my grandfather and one of my uncles, who were doing the work, went from one end of the street to the other and there was no money at all, yet those people paid for the services they received. They did the next street and the next street and when they found the perpetrators—the people who had broken competitive practice and had knocked off the money in the first, second and third streets—my grandfather pulled the bloke out of the truck, advised him that it would not be sensible in future to be anticompetitive. He advised him to stop stealing the money that had been left there and to go about his business in another way.
I suppose if you are going to be honest about the way you run your business at the start—and that leads to what the company is going to be later—maybe you will not actually do as well as other people. My family and my father's family did not succeed, did not become multimillionaires and did not build national companies, but the Fox family certainly did. The Fox family, which started in Bankstown and knocked off the money from my grandfather's ice run, ended up running one of the most significant transport companies in this country; but the basis of it, the building of it, started right in Bankstown, in Greenacre, knocking off a competitor's money. So I am wondering whether, if the provisions of this bill which this minister wants to see go through this House were operative, I or members of my family wouldn't have a claim against the Fox group for the uncompetitive behaviour that they undertook. I am wondering whether, even given the effluxion of time, I wouldn't be able to say to the ACCC, `This should be taken into account, you should be pressing this, rather than being the government's lapdog in terms of secondary boycott action and attempting to belt the daylights out of what the government see as the big problem: the unions.' It might also be the fact that, while the government are saying that they are standing up for small business, they have battered the daylights out of business in Blaxland and they have belted them with the BAS—the Australia card for Australian business. The effect that they have had on the business people in Blaxland—
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. It is getting even later: 23 minutes to five in the morning. I ask the member for Blaxland to come back to the subject of this bill. The BAS, the new tax system and the economic performance of businesses in Blaxland are not directly related to the content of this bill. 
 (Mr Jenkins)—The honourable member for Blaxland will relate his remarks to the bill.
—I am delighted that the minister, the member for North Sydney, has no imagination whatsoever so that he cannot see that what the government has done to small business in my electorate is directly related to what it has put on the table in this parliament. It was this government that brought in the GST. It was this government that brought in the BAS. This is about this government and its rhetoric in relation to the ACCC and what it wants to achieve in this trade practices bill to bring secondary boycott measures and enforcement out of the industrial relations area and into trade practices. It is this government that needs to take responsibility for what has happened to small business and for the position they are in.
The government also needs to take account of its own backbenchers. When the Baird committee looked into this—and we have had an attestation to this from two people from our side who were on the committee: the member for Hunter and the member for Scullin, who is in the chair at the moment—not only our members but also the government members on that committee heard a range of concerns from small business, yet there was no government action to redress those concerns. Fundamentally what they heard was that there was very little concern in relation to sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act. No calls were heard from small business in Blaxland or North Sydney or anywhere else for this change in the act to empower the ACCC to take action that they have never been able to take before—that is, to become the government's chief tracker of its key targets: the unions that it sees as being responsible from time to time for secondary boycotts.
I reiterate the point: if you want a double dissolution out of this, go ahead and try and get it. We will see you when you have it, either on this or anything else, and we will deal with the core issues that are presented to the electorate at that time—whenever it is. The latest time you have got is around October 2004, Joe—just to let you know. What we are doing tonight in refusing to accept this bill we have done before. This is not about the Industrial Relations Commission, except for this: that the other key fixation of this government, the one that they cannot simply get over, is that the Industrial Relations Commission has existed, going back almost to the foundation of the Commonwealth—it is only three years shy of it—and it has successfully arbitrated and conciliated industrial disputes. They want to smash it to smithereens, to fragment it to its elemental condition and in fact wipe it off the table. That is what this bill would seek to do. That is the government's agenda with this; that is what they hope to achieve. 
This bill may pass here shortly when we vote on it but I do not expect that it will pass the Senate. Its flimsiness cannot cover up the fact that the government's position is not only ideological but driven and fanatical in this regard. To those who before pressed it, like the former Minister for Industrial Relations, the former member for Flinders and the Prime Minister, so fixated and obsessed, and indeed other members of this government, I say that you cannot run industrial relations by whacking the ACCC on your individual unions. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Mr Hockey) adjourned.

name: Anthony, Larry, MP
text:
—I move:
That Senate amendments Nos 1, 6, 66, 67 and 68 be agreed to.
While I would like to be as brief as I can—and perhaps it gives an opportunity for the opposition to have their say a bit later—I would reject some of these amendments from the Senate. The government will be moving our own amendments. The disagreement now with this AWT legislation is predominantly with regard to the breaching regime. We believe it is important that that breaching regime is maintained. Indeed, when you compare it to the breaching regime when Labor was last in government—if you look at the dollar equivalents in 2002 compared to, let us say, the early nineties—the actual level of breach is substantially higher. In the interests of brevity, I might come back to that subject. I commend these amendments so far to the House.
Question agreed to.

name: Swan, Wayne, MP
text:
—This bill was introduced in May 2002. Seven months later, at almost 5 a.m. on 13 December, we are here dealing with it. That is pretty tragic when you consider the importance of the bill, but it is also pretty tragic when you consider where this bill commenced, which was with former Minister Newman in 1999. That is pretty tragic when you consider we had the McClure report in 2000. I think it says something about the priority that this government has for welfare reform, which is virtually nil. Every time something comes forward, we virtually go backwards. I want to deal with that at some length now. 
Until five minutes ago, I was led to believe by this government that there was some acceptance of some of the amendments that we successfully moved in the Senate—amendments to do with protecting parents and amendments to do with the mature age unemployed. We had a raft of amendments moved in the Senate. They were accepted in the Senate. We had been led to believe privately by this government that it was going to accept them. Yet we have just arrived here with the minister and have suddenly found out that it is not accepting those amendments; it has moved a whole raft of new amendments which we have not even had the privilege of examining. That is real dirty pool at five in the morning on 13 December—
—Friday the 13th!
—That is right: Friday the 13th. It is real dirty pool to get those sorts of dirty tricks at this hour of the morning. We had been led to believe by this government that it was accepting those amendments and it has come in here with its own amendments. We have not had the opportunity to compare them to our amendments and to make a considered judgment in this important area of public policy affecting parents and affecting the mature age unemployed. All I can say is that I am just completely disgusted by the behaviour of the ministers. This is in an area where we thought we had some agreement. God knows what will happen in the areas where we do not have agreement. This area is pretty important. This is the government that says it believes in family values. How can it have possibly disagreed with the amendments that we moved when it came to sole parents, amendments which said that the new requirements of reciprocal obligation should not conflict with their parenting responsibilities, and other amendments that we have moved in relation to the mature age unemployed? Parents are the best judge of their parenting responsibilities, not governments. We are certainly satisfied with our amendments, but we now do not know what the government is proposing and have not had an opportunity to study what the government has said.
The minister is right in one respect: there is a battleground out there, in that Labor has moved a comprehensive set of amendments advocating fairness in the penalty system right across the social security system. We have; we have made no secret of it—we have campaigned on this issue for years. We have been disgusted by the attitude of Senator Vanstone, who has had a `shoot first, ask questions later' breaching policy. Lots of people out there have been hurt. Huge financial penalties have hit them. They have suffered. The agencies that are at the front line and have had to deal with the consequences of this can testify to how immense the impact of that has been—too many Australians have been unfairly penalised and they have paid a very high price. They have suffered, and they have suffered severe financial disadvantage.
Our amendments in this area are fair and are based on the independent report of the Pearce committee. We think we have put forward in this area of the penalty system across the social security system a balanced package, a package that enhances compliance and increases participation. These amendments ensure good behaviour is rewarded while retaining significant penalties for those who do not play by the rules. We on this side of the House have no time for those who want to rort the system, none at all, but we have a lot of time for those who need the system and we believe in the integrity of the system. This government has no choice but to accept that some change is required and, if need be, we will debate this at length and we will debate it as long as the government wants to—under any circumstances. (Time expired)
debate_title: <title>FAMILY AND COMMUNITY SERVICES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (AUSTRALIANS WORKING TOGETHER AND OTHER 2001 BUDGET MEASURES) BILL 2002</title>

name: Anthony, Larry, MP
text: —I would like to give some clarification which might be of benefit to the Manager of Opposition Business. I have just been informed by the Clerk that there might be some confusion in that the agreement, from my understanding, that was reached with the opposition was that these amendments that have come back had to come back to the House, had to be rejected and reaccepted because they had to come from the House of Representatives to make them valid constitutionally. So I suspect that a lot of the debate tonight may be unnecessary because on those areas we have agreed. Of course, there are some areas on which we will continue to disagree, and I am sure they will be the subject of a division shortly. That may assist the Manager of Opposition Business. While he briefs himself, I further clarify that the government is very keen to continue with Australians Working Together. It was the next phase following the McClure report. Today the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations launched the second phase of AWT. We believe that the measures that we are putting forward are worth while. Perhaps I will now give the member for Lilley the chance to continue the debate with this newfound knowledge.

name: Swan, Wayne, MP
text:
—It is not newfound knowledge; it is knowledge delivered at an hour which is simply unacceptable, in a way which is unacceptable, in a procedure which is unacceptable, in circumstances which are unacceptable. But I am delighted to hear unequivocally that you have accepted our amendments in the area of sole parents and mature age unemployed, because you should have and I am pleased you have. That brings us to the area which is of contention, the battleground, as you described. I guess that battleground comes down to really four areas or possibly five, and I want to talk about them briefly.
The first one is the area of the reduction in breach penalty periods from a maximum of 26 weeks to eight weeks. The second one relates to that as well, because we have to balance the reduction in breach penalty periods, with an increase in penalties that would apply each fortnight: from 16 per cent to 20 per cent for a administrative breaches, from 18 per cent to 20 per cent for a first activity breach and from 24 to 25 per cent for a second breach.
The third area relates to restoration of payments on compliance—that is, when they remedy their error their payments are restored. This measure is particularly important. This is a measure which encourages participation and rewards people who do the right thing. The fourth area relates to the reduction of the accumulation period, where breach penalties may compound, from two years to one year.
We have put forward what we regard as a fair and balanced package. It has its origins in the independent report by Professor Pearce. It is a package of changes that are certainly more than affordable in a $50 billion welfare system. They are changes that encourage participation, they are changes that encourage compliance and they are changes that in many ways, along with the working credit, reward work over welfare. It should not be forgotten that involved in this bill is the working credit, already delayed by this government by nine months—a measure which Labor had as its policy when it was in government and which was abolished by this government seven years ago. It is absolutely essential to encouraging people to move from welfare to work by rewarding that effort, in contrast to the situation at the moment where unemployed people who work part time, casually, are taxed 80c in every additional dollar earned over the threshold. If that was the tax rate applying at the top end of town or in middle Australia there would be a riot. Six years ago the government put that in place. I will not go into the detail of that—we have debated it on many occasions. But all of these measures need to be set in that context.
We are pretty keen to pursue the amendments that I have outlined in those four areas. But, having said that, Labor is mindful of the need for progress on this bill. We do not want to see a situation where this bill is stalled or there is a deadlock. So, in the Senate, Labor will not necessarily be insisting on every single amendment that we have moved. We do have a core package which will deliver fairness to the people who really deserve it: those who are being unfairly penalised, breached and punished by this government. We will not be party to insisting upon Democrat amendments relating to Austudy, numbered 44, 46, 48, 51, 53 and 55, as these amendments are not consistent with the package which Labor is pursuing. Labor will not pursue amendments relating to the accumulation period. (Extension of time granted) This leaves the remainder of the amendments which, unless there is a breakthrough, we will insist upon in the Senate when the bill returns to that place shortly. They seek to have a reduction in the breach period from 26 weeks to eight weeks, coupled with an increase in the breach rate from 16 per cent to 20 per cent, 18 per cent to 20 per cent and 24 per cent to 25 per cent for those various periods that I described before. The other key group of amendments relate to the waiver of the remaining portion of the breach periods when a job seeker remedies their error. 
In summary, the amendments we will be insisting upon are (22), (24), (39), (40), (63), (64), (18), (43), (61), (65), (75), (77), (74), (76), (37) and (42). We believe that these measures are essential—essential to encourage participation, essential to reward work over welfare, essential to integrity and essential to protect people who should not be unnecessarily punished in this system which is meant to be a safety net. Unfortunately, the safety net for too many people has had huge holes cut in it in recent times. We are keen for the government to keep this bill alive, to see whether we can reach agreement on some component of the Pearce amendments and to progress the working credit. The ball is now in the government's court.
Question put:
That the Senate amendments be disagreed to.

name: Hockey, Joe, MP
text:
—In summary of a fairly extensive debate, the government is very committed to continue with the Trade Practices Amendment (Small Business Protection) Bill 2002 [No. 2] and we are determined to push it through the parliament because, no matter what the hour might be, no matter what the day might be, we are in the business of protecting small business.
Opposition members interjecting—
—The Labor Party does not like it, and I specifically address the concerns of the member for Scullin, who said that this matter should not be debated at this hour. Can I say to the member for Scullin that this bill has been debated on numerous occasions in this place and on each occasion the coalition has stood up for small business and the Labor Party has not. As far as we are concerned, we are in the business of protecting small business and we are in the business of doing it any time of the day any day of the year.
Question put:
That this bill be now read a second time.

name: McClelland, Robert, MP
text:
—On the basis of the information communicated by the Leader of the House, I should indicate that I will be most content indeed if my speech on the Sex Discrimination Amendment (Pregnancy and Work) Bill 2002 is interrupted for the purpose of considering the message from Senate. This bill amends the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 to partially implement recommendations made by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission in its August 2000 report called Pregnant and productive: it's a right not a privilege to work while pregnant. Yesterday—in fact, it is two days ago now—the Prime Minister confirmed just how little interest he has in work and family issues. There was a deafening silence from the Prime Minister's office in response to the release of report of the Sex Discrimination Commissioner, Pru Goward, on paid maternity leave. In case we needed it, this bill is further evidence of the government's abysmal track record on work and family issues. It is long overdue and it goes only part way to addressing the matters raised in the report to which I have referred. The bill shows just how limited and belated the government's work and family approach is.
Over two years ago, in March 2000, the member for Jagajaga introduced into this House a private member's bill with the same title as this bill. That private member's bill amended the Sex Discrimination Act and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act to make sure that pregnant, potentially pregnant and breastfeeding women are not discriminated against in the workplace.
The bill was in response to a clear need for legislative changes, highlighted in the Pregnant and productive report. That report was presented to the Attorney-General in June 1999—over three years ago. The bill before us today implements only some of those recommendations. It has taken three years for the government to introduce a legislative response to that report. Not only is the bill abysmally overdue; it is also totally inadequate. It implements only three out of the 12 recommendations in the report calling for amendments to the Sex Discrimination Act.
Non-discrimination in the workplace is, in fact, like being pregnant. There is no halfway: you cannot be a little bit pregnant and you cannot have only a bit of non-discrimination. A workplace is either free of discrimination or it is not. There is no point settling for half measures. This bill shows that the government is willing to do exactly that: settle for half measures by implementing, three years late, only three recommendations from the pregnancy report for amendments to the Sex Discrimination Act.
When the report was publicly released, Susan Halliday said that the report had uncovered horror stories such as women miscarrying because they were not allowed to sit down at work, men being sacked for attending the births of their babies and women being harassed about their appearance and removed from the front desk where they were visible to the public. In one case documented by the commissioner, a woman working in a car factory was denied a chair, despite bleeding and severe pain. She collapsed at work when seven months pregnant and her baby was born prematurely with an undeveloped heart. Ms Halliday said:
Something has to be done. It is fair to say that there are lives at stake here.
In the face of such truly shocking stories, it is appalling that it has taken the government so long to implement any of the commission's recommendations. It is willing to settle for only half measures, in fact, only quarter measures, considering three out of the 12 recommendations. For 3½ years—that is more than four pregnancies—how many pregnant women or new mothers have had to combat a form of discrimination because of the government's inaction?
Whilst discrimination and harassment on the grounds of pregnancy and potential pregnancy are grounds for complaint under the Sex Discrimination Act, the Pregnant and productive report found that workplace discrimination and harassment on these grounds remain real issues for many women, and that clarification of the act is needed in a number of areas. The commission reported that some employees concealed their pregnancy for as long as possible because they feared pregnancy discrimination and that some senior professional women took accrued annual leave, long service leave and the like so that they would not have to reveal and have recorded on their employment records the fact that they had taken maternity leave.
Amendments to the Sex Discrimination Act were overdue three years ago and now the government has introduced a bill of half measures and only half measures. The bill in its current form just does not go far enough. The bill only covers the three areas of the act identified in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report that relate to, firstly, whether discrimination against breastfeeding women is grounds for sex discrimination; secondly, the asking of questions about pregnancy or potential pregnancy during job interviews; and, thirdly, the use of information obtained in medical examinations. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission recommended that the act be amended to make the law in these areas clearer for the benefit of employers and employees, in particular. The report found:
Erroneous tactics and exploitative practices are, to this day, being utilised to remove pregnant women from the workplace or deny pregnant, and potentially pregnant women, equal employment opportunity. 
The bill we are debating redrafts the part of the act that prohibits requests for information that are connected to acts of unlawful discrimination and provides clarification by adding an example of a prohibited question. The bill also adds an explanatory note to make it clear that the exception that allows requests for pregnancy related medical information to be made does not override those provisions of the act which prohibit discrimination on the basis of sex or pregnancy. The operation of the act is expanded by the amendments but they eliminate confusion identified in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report about the meaning and operation of the act regarding pregnancy and pregnancy related issues.
Unfortunately, the bill does not address a number of other legislative changes recommended in the HREOC report. These changes are significant and worthy of noting specifically, and they include: empowering HREOC to publish enforceable standards in relation to pregnancy and potential pregnancy; allowing referrals by the Sex Discrimination Commissioner to the Industrial Relations Commission of discriminatory awards or agreements without the need for receipt of a written complaint; enabling the award of punitive damages as well as compensatory damages; removing the exemption for educational institutions established for religious purposes in relation to pregnancy and potential pregnancy; ensuring coverage of unpaid workers; and removing the exemption of employment by an instrumentality of a state.
The amendments the Labor Party propose, in contrast, address 10 of the Pregnant and productive report's 46 recommendations. Our proposals will enhance the rights of pregnant and potentially pregnant women by empowering the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to publish enforceable standards in relation to pregnancy and potential pregnancy; ensuring unpaid workers are covered by the Sex Discrimination Act; removing the exemption for employment by an instrumentality of a state from the Sex Discrimination Act; removing the exemption for educational institutions established for religious purposes in relation to pregnancy and potential pregnancy; allowing punitive damages to be awarded, specifically including breastfeeding as grounds for unlawful discrimination; allowing the Sex Discrimination Commissioner to refer discriminatory awards or agreements to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission without the requirement to receive a written complaint; clarifying that a complaint about a discriminatory advertisement may be made by any person; clarifying that the asking of questions to elicit information about whether and when a woman intends to become pregnant and/or her intentions in relation to meeting her current or pending family responsibilities is unlawful; and, finally, clarifying that it is unlawful to discriminate in medical examinations of pregnant women during the recruitment process. They also extend the antidiscrimination provisions to employees who are in the process of adopting a child.
Improving the protections for pregnant women is important, but it is just the tip of the iceberg. A lot more in terms of policy change is needed. Australia needs a sea change in policies and attitudes that are hindering the capacity of women to take on and survive the complex responsibilities of work on the one hand and family commitments on the other. It is time women, particularly women who are thinking about starting a family and women who have young families, are supported by policies that will make a difference to their lives and assist them to balance those competing responsibilities. I am not referring to how women who are corporate high-flyers with nannies, housekeepers and the like cope with the challenges they confront but to the millions of Australian mothers whose jobs are the safety net for their family's economic survival. They literally work to pay bills; they work to support their families. With the dramatic increase in real estate prices and dramatic increase in credit card indebtedness, it is becoming more the norm for families to require two incomes to survive—and certainly to survive in the capital cities in Australia, where most families reside.
But the Howard government refuses to recognise that most families just cannot afford to have one parent at home full-time for five years and that most women who leave work to have a baby return to work at some stage after the birth. The proof is in the statistics. Well over 60 per cent of Australian women spend their baby's first year out of the paid work force, but more than half of new mothers in two-parent families are back at work before their babies are two years old. By the time their children have turned three, nearly 70 per cent of mothers these days are back in the work force, usually, as I indicated, as a result of those economic pressures. Mothers understand the importance of staying attached to the work force during these early child-rearing years. Their preference is for part-time work. Among parents of dependent children, in June 2000 57 per cent of employed partnered mothers and five per cent of employed partnered fathers worked part time.  
What the statistics do not show are the difficulties, the pressures and the anxieties experienced by parents as they negotiate the demands of their double lives. Research is increasingly showing the anxieties and pressures and the effect of those pressures faced by children in circumstances where their parents are trying to balance the challenges of both work and family responsibilities. Now it seems many young women think it is all too hard and are in fact deciding not to have children. The evidence is indisputable. Australian women are having fewer babies. The birthrate fell dramatically from 3.5 babies per woman in the early 1960s to just 1.7 in 2001. That is the lowest rate on record. It is down from 1.75 children on average in the year 2000 and much worse than the previous lows of 1.86 and 1.94 recorded in 1991 and 1981, when those figures were last taken. We are in very real danger of becoming a baby-free society, a place where children are a private responsibility that must never impinge on a parent's working life. If that culture becomes our culture, we will see that birthrate declining even more rapidly. 
The Prime Minister's policies are creating this baby-free society. The Prime Minister's ideological preference is a world where men are breadwinners, women are full-time homemakers and children are at home with their mothers until they start school. The government's tax and welfare policies clearly favour single-income families. For example, the government's family tax benefit B is only available to single-income families. The election conceived baby bonus offends all notions of equity. It provides the greatest financial help to those who need it least and it is quickly eroded if the stay-at-home parent earns any part-time money. The everyday reality is that it just does not work according to the Prime Minister's view of life. The Howard government's policies reflect a narrow, conservative ideology, not the reality of most families, where both parents work because of the financial pressures that they face these days. That is why Labor is pushing for a sea change in policy and attitude and why it is committed to catching up with the rest of the world and introducing a system of paid maternity leave. 
The difference between the government and the opposition is clear on this critical issue. The day before yesterday, when the Sex Discrimination Commissioner released her paid maternity leave report, the opposition were crystal clear about our position: we are committed to introducing paid maternity leave. There is absolutely no ambiguity about where we stand. We had a barbecue to welcome the report because where the Prime Minister says that work and family issues are barbecue stoppers, we think they should be a barbecue starter. We believe that a good barbecue must have two ingredients. Firstly, it needs a family and, secondly, it needs some time for people to get together. Without work and family policies like paid maternity leave, people will be less willing to start families and will have less time for activities such as barbecues and simply spending time with the kids. As I said before, not only is that a stress and a strain for parents; it is detrimental to the interests of children.
The fact that the government does not support work and family provisions like paid maternity leave makes them, literally, a barbecue stopper. Australia is just one of the two developed countries that does not yet have a paid maternity leave scheme. Countries we are lagging behind include Japan, Canada, Austria, Italy, the United Kingdom, Norway, the Slovak Republic and New Zealand. Countries which have suitable family friendly policies have a higher birthrate where assistance is provided to families to have children. I seek leave to continue my remarks. 
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

name: McClelland, Robert, MP
text:
—Australia is just one of two developed countries that does not yet have a maternity leave scheme. As I indicated, a number of countries—Japan, Canada, Austria, Italy, the United Kingdom, Norway, the Slovak Republic and New Zealand—have maternity leave schemes. The Howard government is determined to fight Australia's progress on the issue. I understand that the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations is reported to have said that the government would never introduce a paid maternity leave scheme. I think his words were to the effect of `over this government's dead body'. 
—You want to read the fine print.
—We will have a look at the totality of the wording, but they were certainly the sentiments as I recall them. I believe the Minister for Finance and Administration, the Minister for Small Business and Tourism and the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer have expressed similar sentiments. They all say that they do not support paid maternity leave for all working women. They prefer a system where only middle-class professionals who work for large organisations have access to paid maternity leave and women in low-income jobs and small businesses do not.
The day before yesterday the government's response to the Goward report consisted of a terse, five-line statement from the Minister for Family and Community Services thanking the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and still refusing to commit to introducing statutory paid maternity leave. A more detailed response came from the chief executive of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, Mr Peter Hendy, who was the education minister's chief of staff as well as a senior advisor to former defence minister Peter Reith. Mr Hendy's response was unequivocal: he did not support a system of paid maternity leave for all working women even if the government funded it. We find it difficult to accept that ACCI would not accept a system of paid maternity leave even if the government funded it.
It is clear that the Howard government will not introduce paid maternity leave. What is more, if the length of time the government has taken to introduce the bill we are now debating is an indication, it will be many long years before we get even some response to the Goward report. But a Crean government will introduce paid maternity leave in a form that does not burden small business, because we believe it is a fundamental part of Labor's strategy for working families. Paid maternity leave means that mothers who work will be financially able to take time out of the work force to recover from childbirth. It provides relief and respite while ensuring that women do not lose connection with the workplace and that, in the meantime, bills can be paid and mortgage commitments can be satisfied.
The aim of paid maternity leave is to make a contribution towards the income a woman forgoes when she leaves work to have a baby, and during the subsequent necessary period of leave needed for the health and welfare of both the mother and the newborn baby. But paid maternity leave is not the beginning and end of work and family issues. We understand and fully appreciate that. Paid maternity leave is a fundamental part of the work and family balance, but in itself it is not sufficient to help families meet the challenges and joys that a new child brings. Families confronting that life-changing event need one thing above all else: more options to suit their particular circumstances—more options for striking the balance between work, family and other activities, such as study, that best suit their needs and those of their children.
There is no `one size fits all' solution for families because no two families are alike; no two families need the same solution. Parents need a range of possible options so that they develop a solution that suits their needs. Parents want the flexibility to choose different solutions at different stages of their lives. Some parents may want to stay at home with their children, others will return to full-time work as soon as possible, others may want to return to part-time work. We need to support and encourage this diversity between families by giving parents a range of viable alternatives—at least for the first five years of a child's life, when clearly children are heavily dependent on the support and nurturing of their parents. Parents need to be able to construct their own long-term parenting plan from a number of options. Discrimination against pregnant women in the workplace must become a thing of the past. That is what a genuinely family friendly environment, we believe, looks like. I urge the government to accept the opposition's amendment to the bill to help realise that environment. I move the following second reading amendment: 
That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
“whilst supporting the particular amendments proposed in the bill, the House calls on the Government to support all the legislative amendments and other actions necessary to give effect to the recommendations of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission in its report Pregnant and productive: It's a right not a privilege to work while pregnant”.
—Is the amendment seconded?
—I second that amendment and reserve my right to speak.
—The original question was that this bill be now read a second time. To this the honourable member for Barton has moved as an amendment that all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting other words. The question now is that the words proposed to be omitted stand part of the question.

name: Gambaro, Teresa, MP
text:
—I rise to speak to the Sex Discrimination Amendment (Pregnancy and Work) Bill 2002. I am honoured today to stand in this parliament and to be a part of the coalition team. The coalition government during the last six years of leadership have worked tirelessly for the rights of women. Through this parliament we have successfully passed many pieces of legislation that have sought to improve the working conditions and the working environment for women and to reduce discrimination against us. Today we are implementing legislation that will provide greater clarity and address evolving attitudes towards women in the workplace. The implementation of the Equal Opportunity for Women in the Workplace Act 1999 heralded better equal opportunity outcomes for women by allowing employers to focus on actions and achievements. In conjunction with the Workplace Relations Act 1996, which contained provisions relating to equal remuneration for work of equal value amongst men and women, the economic status of working women improved and is continuing to improve.
One of the principal objectives of the Workplace Relations Act 1996 is to assist employees to balance their work and family responsibilities. Under this act, we as the government have taken action to remove arbitrary restrictions on part-time employment and to also encourage increased award provisions for part-time employment. In addition, there has been an overall increase in the number of family friendly provisions in collective agreements, with approximately 76 per cent of agreements in 1999 containing at least one family friendly measure, including flexible hours provisions. There is no doubt that there has been a huge increase in the participation rate of women in the work force. At the moment that participation rate is at 55 per cent. That is one of the highest in history. It is important that we note that it is striking a balance between work and family—and work and family issues are more important than ever before.
The participation rate, which I am sure my colleagues opposite would welcome, is a result of a number of factors, including very strong economic conditions, greater flexibility in the work force, and a child-care sector that is flexible and enables more women to combine work and family. There are over four million women in the Australian paid work force at the moment. As a single mother in the past who has had to raise children, I know all too well the difficulties of balancing family and work life. I see the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister is sitting at the table. I know that she has an interesting time, as do many mothers on the opposite side of the chamber and on our side of the House. Also, being a small business owner operator, I understand the issues we face and the need to have effective government policy to coordinate our involvement in the work force and our commitment to family life.
More women today are doing well in the business and the public sector. In fact, women hold 27 per cent of private sector senior managerial positions, which is an increase of just under 10 per cent since 1990. More women are going into small business. I saw some statistics recently that said that three times as many women go into small business these days. The greater involvement of women in business, particularly in small to medium type enterprises, is interesting to see. It is largely because they can combine family life and have the flexibility which perhaps would not have been available to them had they been working in a more rigid work environment. This government is committed to policies that help women achieve a balance between maintaining a positive work and family life. 
Australian women have access to record levels of child care, including more flexible child care for families in shiftwork, particularly when children are ill. This government has been a very strong proponent of those sorts of policies and has provided much greater flexibility in the child-care sector and greater choice for Australian families. Those choices include the extension of in-home and sick care and also the entry of other operators, including private operators and family day care schemes and after school care.
