The coalition government has also been encouraging the debate on paid maternity leave. Those on the other side would have us believe that a decision has already been made. It is important that we look at the pros and cons of this particular issue. We do not want nor should we encourage paid maternity leave to take women back to the dark days of restrictive work practices. That is something I would be totally against. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission issues paper `Valuing parenthood: options for paid maternity leave' made two interesting points. Firstly, the forward of the interim paper states:
It should be emphasised that most of those consulted in the preparation of this paper were concerned that an individual employer funded scheme would prove disadvantageous to women in employment and to commercial competitiveness generally.
Later in the report, it states:
For those companies, in particular small businesses, with a high component of operating costs tied up in wages and operating on narrow profit margins, employer-provided paid maternity leave may disproportionately affect wage costs and in some cases be unaffordable. Organisations unable to afford paid maternity leave will be more likely to have women resign or not return to work following maternity leave. It may also make it more difficult for them to recruit women.
Speakers opposite have indicated their preference for maternity leave. I think it is not just maternity leave that we need to consider, but flexibility in the workplace. I have said before on many occasions that, while it is good to give women 12 weeks maternity leave, it is no good if they have to go back to a workplace environment that is just as restrictive. There is a place for maternity leave to be balanced with more flexible work practices in the market. It is important that we look at all those factors when we consider balancing work and family life.
The maternity leave debate has been very emotional so far, and it will continue to be so. Providing a policy that will work for women and not against them is something that we need to look at. As I stated in my introduction, the coalition government has made some significant inroads towards improving workplace environments for women. Many years ago at one of my first job interviews, I was asked if, as a young woman, I was currently taking the pill. It was one of the most shocking moments of my employment history. Those were certainly the dark days when employees had to front up and speak to an employer who asked, as one of their first questions, whether a person was taking a contraceptive pill or whether the employee would get pregnant. It was a harrowing experience, and not just for me—a lot of women went through this. I was quite young at the time, and I recall being absolutely astonished that such a personal remark would be made.
I also remember going back to work when I had young children, and the problem then was: who was going to look after my baby? What child-care arrangements was I going to have made? It is a despondent time when you are trying to go back to work, and in those days there was incredible discrimination, particularly against women who had small children or women who were newly married or did not have children. It was a terrible period that I hope we will never see repeated. This legislation we have here today is commendable in ensuring that there is transparency in rules regarding questions that can be put to possible employees regarding pregnancy and potential pregnancy. I know that I am not alone in this experience; there are many women in Australia who have experienced this in the past. I am sure that many women in the past experienced much worse treatment than this. 
Yesterday in the Courier Mail there was an article that said that in the past year nearly 50 Queensland women claimed that after they had become pregnant, employers or work colleagues had discriminated against them. The article, on page 10, also said that 59 women claimed that they had suffered from discrimination because of their marital status and another four had experienced discrimination because they were breastfeeding. It is absolutely amazing. One of the provisions of this legislation clarifies that a question regarding pregnancy or potential pregnancy should not be put unless it falls within the category of a general question that is asked of everyone. The Courier Mail article also gave some examples of sexual harassment in the workplace and I will quote one of them in particular:
A WOMAN complained to her employer a colleague had sexually harassed her by making inappropriate comments and touching her shoulders. The company subsequently transferred her out of the section but left the alleged harasser in his position. She complained that her new position meant she was unable to claim overtime and requested to be transferred back. She was told this could not happen until she withdrew her complaint. The Anti-Discrimination Commissioner intervened, resolving the complaint and the woman was transferred back to her original job.
That is an appalling example of the sort of discrimination that occurs out there in the workplace.
It is important that we look at the provisions in this legislation. We need to have caution here and also when we implement clarification. I would like to support the insertion of new subsection 27(1) to provide the necessary clarity. By that, it is important that it is not discrimination if an employer seeks a response on a question about a potential employee's future plans. I would regard this as pretty much a standard question in any job interview to assess the motivation and the future career aspirations of a candidate. I have been asked on many occasions, when I have undertaken an interview, what my future plans were in terms of career aspirations and motivational factors, so I think that that is fairly in order. If the interviewee willingly provides information on future family plans, then that is not discrimination. It becomes discrimination, however, if the employer directly makes reference to the pregnancy plans or uses that sort of information when determining who to give the job to. The message for employers and potential employees is to use caution when asking such questions.
I know that, from running my own small business, it was always in the back of my mind when I framed questions to potential employees. I was always very conscious of the fact that I did not create the wrong impression and that I did not cause some sort of indirect discrimination or discomfort to people that I was employing. I was always very conscious, during the interview stage, that I did not repeat the terrible mistakes that my earlier potential employer made when asking me about my future plans regarding starting a family. It is not discriminatory when an employer or a potential employer asks a question about a person's medical condition or pregnancy in a legitimate way. That is exactly the sort of clarification that we are needing in subsection 27(2). 
It is really important that employers and employees do use discretion. I understand that many people want to maintain confidentiality, particularly in areas of medical and pregnancy issues, and that is their right. As Australians, we all have the need to respect this right. I would argue that, in fact, a good management practice is for the employer to act with sensitivity and discretion, particularly when discussing with individual employees their medical condition or their pregnancy, so that that can be safely handled in the workplace. I must say that I have also worked in very large and small corporations that have been very sensitive at the time that I wanted to start a family. In terms of re-rostering work, rescheduling, providing safety strategies or dealing with occupational health issues, I think it is very important that employers have that information so that they can assist employees and provide a suitable work environment. Everyone wins from that situation. It is a win-win situation for both the employees and the employers, and it does encourage women to return to the workplace. There are many companies in Queensland that have implemented strong family-friendly policies, and they are to be commended. It is also necessary for employers to ask about someone's medical or pregnancy status in a manner that distinguishes between the sexes, because it may also assist in the enforcement of appropriate precautionary measures. 
This bill before us today makes sure that there is clarity to both employers and employees in the area of sex discrimination. The coalition has had an excellent report card in advancing women in the workplace and ensuring equality for all women. This bill that we are discussing here is another chapter in what is already a well-regarded volume. I would like to say that those past measures that we have implemented have been very good measures. The 2002 budget demonstrates the government's strong and continuing commitment to women in this special year, the Centenary of Australian Women's Suffrage. It has been 100 years since the Commonwealth Franchise Act 1902 came into effect, allowing most Australian women the right to vote and to stand for federal election. 
The coalition government fosters a partnership approach to social policy, delivered in partnership with businesses, communities and individuals. The social coalition aims to develop opportunities for families and communities over and above those delivered by economic growth. We need to ensure that those opportunities continue in the workplace, particularly that women have safe and non-discriminatory workplaces that give them flexibility. The opportunities that I mentioned, particularly government support services, mean that women more than ever have those choices—whether they decide to be full-time parents or carers, whether they want to participate in the paid work force, or whether they wish to combine paid work with parenting or caring. I think that what is really important in this debate is that women have the opportunity to participate in whatever level of work arrangements they wish.
I supposed you could compare a working life to a product's life cycle. Women in the early stages of child rearing may want to work part time; as their children get older, they may then venture into the full-time work force; consequently, when their families have moved on, they may decide that they want to return to part-time work. We need to encourage that flexibility and ensure that we have non-discriminatory policies that will allow women to achieve their full potential. It is good to see that more and more women are going into managerial positions and that more businesses out there have family friendly workplace practices. I will comment on one particular business, Tamawood, which is a building company in Queensland that has provided exceptional working conditions for women, such as on-site child-care arrangements. They are to be commended. I commend the bill to the House. (Time expired)

name: Roxon, Nicola, MP
text:
—It is a pleasure to follow the member for Petrie in speaking on the Sex Discrimination Amendment (Pregnancy and Work) Bill 2002. I think I share most of her comments. Obviously, many of us have sought employment in different ways and experienced some odd reactions to seeking that employment, which means that we share an understanding of how important this debate is.
The fact that we are moving some amendments and would like to see some of the other options that are put forward in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission's report adopted does not mean that we are not supportive of the steps that are being taken. I think there has been quite a change, even in the four years that I have been here, when I see how much more often we debate issues that affect working women in particular but also the balance between work and family, whether it is for men or women. Some of us would like some of these issues to move a bit faster.
I think that there is room for us to also try to have a debate—perhaps not always in this House—about the way that all these different areas overlap and interact. We cannot really talk about discrimination in the workplace and not talk about the sorts of family payments that the member for Petrie was talking about. We cannot ignore child care or paid maternity leave—all of these issues are ones that, increasingly, the public wants us to tie together. We need to look at how we can provide proper options for women who choose to work or go in and out of the work force at the same time as having and caring for young children. It is a pleasure to see that there is so much agreement about the range of issues that need to be covered. 
 I think a number of us on both sides of the House have been in circumstances where pretty terrible acts of discrimination have occurred. One of the things that surprises me most in the pregnancy discrimination area is just how absolutely unnecessary the reactions of employers often are. Mr Speaker, when you take the opportunity to read the report—I do not know if you have had the opportunity—that was prepared by the Human Rights Commission, Pregnant and productive, which was the basis for the legislation before us today, you will see it contains a lot of information. The most common theme of the report is how little information people had about their own rights and how unaware many women, particularly young women, were that they did not have to put up with the sort of treatment they received. The changes that the government has adopted are really to clarify what could have already been covered by the act. There were many challenges and many instances that the report found had been ignored because the act was not as clear as it could be.
We would have liked to have gone a step further and to have instigated or adopted some new heads of discrimination as were recommended in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission's report, such as prohibiting discrimination on the grounds of breastfeeding and others. These have been picked up in the terms of the debate. I think everybody understands that we are moving in the right direction. At some point, it may be necessary for us to look at a way to introduce that into the legislation. I guess that will be tested through the sorts of actions that employers take and, if necessary, through some test cases as well.
This bill has been listed a number of times without coming on for debate. Several months ago when the bill was listed, and I thought we were about to speak on it, I had been at a local nursing mothers' group. A couple of the mothers talked to me about their experiences in the workplace when they sought to return to work having, in most instances, been treated very well during their pregnancies. They were quite happy with their various maternity leave arrangements. A number of them had had paid maternity leave and certainly that was a hot topic for discussion and it has turned out to be a topic in the week that this has come before the House.
One woman's example really stuck in my mind. She worked as a relatively middle-ranking clerical officer. She had her own office in a building with many other employees. She worked quite long hours and was paid a salary. She did not have to be there at particular hours; she could make up time at either end of the day if she chose or if the employer wanted her to. She asked her employer if she would be able to get a lock for the door of her office so that, when she needed to express milk, she could ensure that no-one would walk in on her during that time. She ended up having an all-out brawl with her employer who thought that it was an outrageous request to have a lock on the door. There could be many awkward situations in trying to accommodate the needs of breastfeeding mothers. If we have a situation where it is very easy to accommodate those needs but we have employers arguing against it, we have a long way to go to educate the community. People might need to think more flexibly. This would not have started some dreadful trend in the business. It was suggested that everyone would suddenly have locks on the doors and you would not be able to go in and talk to the various staff. Obviously, that was not what was being proposed. These examples abound in the workplace and we all need to work towards to change.
In debating this bill, we need to make a fairly basic point: working women are still fighting for fairness in the workplace. Equality has not yet been achieved in all aspects. Getting the right balance between work and family is very difficult, particularly at the time of pregnancy. If it is a first pregnancy, it should be a time of great excitement for the family. A lot of change goes on in people's lives. More and more we see examples of that happy time being spoilt by very difficult negotiations or reactions in workplaces. This bill will help move that forward. It helps clarify what is appropriate and what is inappropriate. I hope employers will take note. We will be moving some amendments in the consideration in detail stage to take that a little further and to make clear what we believe employers should and should not be able to do in this situation. 
I might briefly give an example, because I am probably sounding as though I am being very prescriptive about what employers should do. There are guidelines suggested either in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission's report or in other booklets—and I notice one has recently been produced by the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations about pregnancy in the workplace and the sorts of discussions that should be had between employer and employee. Mostly they are pretty straightforward, sensible proposals, but it seems that we need to work a little more on the education side of things so that employees are confident they can raise these issues and employers are capable and confident of having the discussions as well.
I am keeping an eye out for a hopeful intervention of some news from the other place, but it seems that that is not going to happen quite yet. So I will read briefly from a booklet called Balancing Breastfeeding and Work, which is prepared jointly by the Department of Health and Aged Care at the Commonwealth level, the University of Adelaide and the South Australian Employers Chamber of Commerce and Industry. As well as explaining a whole lot of circumstances that might be of assistance to both women in the work force and employers, there is a section which sets out some guidelines to employers and workplaces and what they can do to support breastfeeding. Some of the things are very practical: making sure there is access somewhere in the workplace to a clean and private room, that there is some storage area, that there is a chair for the woman to use if they need to sit down while expressing or breastfeeding, washing facilities, and even things as basic as having access to a power point to be able to use an electric breast pump.
It seems to me that all of this moves the debate forward a little bit about whether or not this is something that is practical in a workplace—in many it will not be. The changes that are being proposed and being introduced into the legislation do not seek to put an unreasonable burden on employers. Obviously each workplace is different, and sensible negotiations need to be had. But we need to be able to encourage women that they can have a proper balance and that they can make choices about how they want to continue to care for their children. This is a very important change, particularly in circumstances where they may need to return to work in a short time.
As I said, it is quite an interesting week for us to be discussing this bill because the Sex Discrimination Commissioner has released her next big report. This one from several years ago was a very important report at its time. Unfortunately, it has taken this length of time to now turn into legislation. The Labor Party, in supporting paid maternity leave, would be very keen to see that the current report that has been tabled this week will not be acted upon so slowly by the government. But, given comments made by other speakers already and what is well known on the public record, there seems to be no agreement at all on the government side about whether or not they even support paid maternity leave as an idea. So there is a lot of debate we still have to have in that area. I hope that we will be able to move forward because it is a vast jigsaw puzzle and it seems to me we are only putting a few pieces together pretty slowly. We need to eventually get them to all fit together so that families do have the options that we all want them to be able to have.
I hope that the government will take those recommendations and that report seriously. The full detail of the human rights commission's Pregnant and productive report from 1999 has not been adopted by this legislation that is before us. There is a lot more that should be looked at and should be done. The clarification of what falls within or constitutes sex discrimination is certainly going to be useful; it will help both employers and employees to know what their rights are, but it does not quite take up the recommendations and the points made by the commissioner's report. People need to be clear what their rights are, and employers need to be encouraged to make sure they can introduce those sorts of standards within the workplace and that that would make a significant difference to preparedness to stay at work. 
I commend the bill to the House. I flag my support, of course, for the amendment moved by the member for Barton and that I seconded. We do need to make sure that we are actually going to balance this sort of legislation with a proper paid maternity leave package with accessible child care and with a whole range of other family-friendly provisions which need to be put in place in the workplace relations system. I trust that we will be able to debate all of those issues in the coming year.
Debate interrupted.

name: Hunt, Gregory, MP
text:
—I am very pleased to rise to speak on the Sex Discrimination Amendment (Pregnancy and Work) Bill 2002. In particular, I am delighted to follow my colleague the member for Gellibrand whom I have known for many years and who I know has had a longstanding commitment and interest in this area. I am also delighted that my friend and colleague the member for Berowra is in the chamber specifically to hear this discussion take place.
This debate occurs at the end of an interesting century, a century of movement and change, and evolution in the rights of women. It occurs at the end of a century which has seen the evolution of those rights across political, economic and social fronts. This bill represents an additional step along that path towards true and genuine equality. One hundred years ago, the Commonwealth Franchise Act 1902 came into effect. It allowed most Australian women the right to vote and to stand for federal election. Over time, through the success of Dame Enid Lyons and others, women have developed a political voice in the country. Similarly, they have developed a social voice through a range of authors, contributors, activists— many people on different fronts—and, significantly and perhaps of most importance, they have developed an independent economic freedom. One of the key reasons why we have seen a significant and continuing increase in the participation rate of women in this country over a period of decades is their increasing involvement in the workplace. That is where this bill fits in.
That process of evolution and of ever greater involvement of women in the workplace has meant a number of things. One, it has meant an increase in their participation; two, it has meant a gradual equalisation of the pay scales—there is more to be done, but there has been significant and quite dramatic progress over the course of the last century; and three—and this is specifically where this bill falls—it addresses some of the rights, conditions and terms of women within the workplace. 
I wish to address three particular things in relation to the Sex Discrimination Amendment (Pregnancy and Work) Bill 2002. First, the background; second, the provisions of the bill; and third, its importance within the context of today. Looking at the background, in 1998 the Attorney-General requested the first investigation into matters relating to pregnancy and work. The report of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, entitled Pregnant and Productive: it is a right not a privilege to work while pregnant, which subsequently flowed, recommended the need for clarification in relation to three matters in particular. They were, firstly, the asking of questions about pregnancy or potential pregnancy; secondly, the use of pregnancy related medical information; and, thirdly, whether breastfeeding constituted legitimate grounds for discrimination or whether discrimination on the grounds of breastfeeding was improper, inappropriate and unfair. That represents the background.
The provisions of this bill amend the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 in accordance with recommendations 36, 37 and 43 of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report. The bill was prepared in consultation with the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry and groups that represent employees whether at the organised level or at the social level.
Significantly, the amendments clarify three things. Firstly, questions regarding pregnancy or potential pregnancy may not be asked during the recruitment process. Secondly, medical information collected from pregnant women may only be used for legitimate health and safety reasons. In effect, that means that medical information gathered for one purpose—such as for determining and protecting the health of a woman or a mother or a potential mother—cannot be used in the workplace for work related purposes. Thirdly, the bill clarifies that discrimination against women on the basis of breastfeeding is illegal. It is an important social step forward. What it says is that, as a matter of law, a woman has a right to breastfeed within the workplace.
What is at the third level? The importance of the bill. The bill has no financial impact, but it does ensure that the original act is clear. In very simple terms, it is illegal to discriminate against women on the basis of pregnancy, potential pregnancy or because they are breastfeeding. In order to implement this, the government will compile a pamphlet on pregnancy and work in order to increase awareness of this issue amongst employers and employees. Indeed, this bill is just one part of a broader social framework that shows a commitment in relation to the status of women.
The government's achievements and initiatives include, firstly, workplace equality. Since 1996 there has been a 14 per cent increase in the number of women in employment. That is an extraordinary advance in terms of the proportion of women in employment in a six-year period. Secondly, 52 per cent of the over one million jobs created since 1996—it has increased from 971,800 jobs—when I first prepared these notes, have been filled by women. Thirdly, the Workplace Relations Act includes a provision for equal remuneration for men and women when they have undertaken work of equal value—a simple, clear, absolute and fundamental principle. That is the question about workplace equality.
The second principal area of achievement is in balancing family and work—and this is a process which is in evolution. Significantly, the government introduced a $24.2 million return to work program that assists people re-entering the work force after a two-year or more break  as carers or parents. In addition, under the category of balancing family and work, the government has committed $8 billion to child care in the four years up to 2004-05, counting the full range of child support and child-care benefits.
Very briefly, there are more challenges. This bill is a step along the path which has progressed over 100 years and which has gradually led not to a perfect situation but to a significant improvement in the economic, political and social fields. In particular, the Sex Discrimination Amendment (Pregnancy and Work) Bill 2002 addresses the economic capacity of women by ensuring that they are protected when carrying out those duties associated with the normal practice of their lives, which comes from facing motherhood in and during their working lives. It is an important step and I am delighted to commend this legislation to the House.

name: Irwin, Julia, MP
text:
—Good morning, Mr Speaker. The Sex Discrimination Amendment (Pregnancy and Work) Bill 2002 is probably the best example of a Clayton's amendment that this House has ever seen. It is the amendment you have when you are not having an amendment. The bill is the government's response to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission report Pregnant and productive: it is a right not a privilege to work while pregnant. The report was commissioned by the Attorney-General in August 1998 and the report was required nine months later, in June 1999. As it was, the report was overdue and was finally delivered in August 1999. After a pregnant pause of nearly three years, mother and baby are not doing well.
The report made a total of 46 recommendations, and 11 of those called on the Attorney-General to amend the Sex Discrimination Act in various ways. Out of the 11 recommendations only three are covered by this bill, and those three changes are largely cosmetic. They are only intended to make the act clearer to employers and employees. You might say that they are like the cream to hide the stretch marks, rather than dealing with the health and wellbeing of mother and baby. I should add that the three areas addressed in this bill are ones where there is a great deal of misunderstanding. Any attempt to clarify these issues is welcome. But the remaining eight recommendations that the Attorney-General has chosen to ignore cover issues which actually extend the rights of pregnant women and adoptive parents. I will come back to those issues later.
Firstly, looking at the recommendations addressed by this bill, I should begin by saying that many cases of discrimination arise out of well-intentioned acts of employers and service providers. They may have acted in what they thought would be in the best interests of the mother—and that in itself would appear to be the cause of many examples of misunderstanding of the act. Making provisions of the Sex Discrimination Act crystal clear to employers and service providers is a welcome and much needed measure.
In the report of the national pregnancy and work inquiry, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission exposed some alarming figures for employer awareness of equity and discrimination issues. It found in a survey of private sector employers in the Perth area that, while 81.2 per cent of employers of large businesses knew that discrimination on the grounds of pregnancy was unlawful, only 62 per cent of small business employers were aware of that; and in the retail sector—the largest employer of women—only 59.4 per cent of employers were aware. It is quite alarming to think that at the time that survey was conducted in 1998 only three out of five employers were aware that discrimination on the grounds of pregnancy is unlawful. Some 14 years after the Sex Discrimination Act was passed, only three out of five employers were aware of their responsibilities under the act. And the report also indicates that while those three out of five were aware of the overall requirements, there was considerable misunderstanding of how they should be applied.
The report suggests a total of 41 guidelines in plain English and with case studies in order to allow better understanding of the act as it applies to pregnancy. You should not have to be a lawyer to have a basic understanding of how to avoid discriminatory practices in your workplace, but I do not want to suggest that, if it is all too hard, then let us do away with it altogether—let us not throw the baby out with the bath water. Rather, it is better to clarify the act to ensure that it is more likely to be complied with. An understanding on the part of employees is essential if they are to exercise their rights.
Looking at the changes proposed in this bill, item 1 in schedule 1 of the bill changes the definition of sex discrimination to include breastfeeding and the act of expressing milk. This change is in response to recommendation 43 of the report, which calls on the Attorney-General to make sure that breastfeeding is a ground of unlawful discrimination. I would have thought that this was covered in the original act, but now it is clearly stated and leaves no doubt that matters relating to breastfeeding are included as unlawful discrimination. This is an important provision of the act and an issue which over time has seen community attitudes evolve from recognition to acceptance. The development of practices and facilities to allow nursing mothers to enjoy the full range of employment and social activities is a welcome change. The days when nursing mothers were sent off to the ladies toilet to feed an infant are thankfully rare now. But that does not apply everywhere. I have always thought it strange that people who thought you should feed a baby in a toilet would never consider eating their lunch in one. I realise that there is much more to the issue of discrimination when it comes to breastfeeding and that smaller employers and service providers face challenges when meeting their responsibilities in this area. But with the benefit of a clearer understanding of their responsibilities, I believe that a commonsense approach can satisfy all parties. 
The second area covered in this bill again seeks to provide a clearer statement of the requirements of the act. Recommendation 36 of the report of the National Pregnancy and Work Inquiry recommends:
That the Attorney-General clarify section 27 of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 (Cth) by the insertion of a specific provision that prohibits the asking of questions (whether orally or in writing) which might reasonably be understood as intended to elicit information about whether or when a women intends to become pregnant and/or her intentions in relation to meeting her current or pending family responsibilities.
The explanatory memorandum to the bill points out that this is most commonly applicable in employment recruitment situations. However, it is not limited to employment. The examples given in the explanatory memorandum describe situations of applying to lease rental property and an applicant for a bank loan. With the changes, it should be crystal clear that anyone responsible for recruitment, letting property or handling loan applications—and I would think many other similar transactions—is prohibited from asking questions that may be used to discriminate against a person on the basis of their sex, pregnancy or potential pregnancy or marital status. There are no ifs or buts; asking the question breaches the act. It is not a matter of saying, `I wasn't going to use the information.' Why would you ask in the first place if you were not going to use the information?
I hope that this amending legislation makes it crystal clear—and, short of drawing a picture, it could hardly be made clearer—that this part of the Sex Discrimination Act needs to be widely understood and enforced. But, before I go on to the third change, it is worth going back to the figures I mentioned earlier in relation to the awareness of the requirements of the Sex Discrimination Act. When two out of five employers do not even have a basic understanding of the act and for those who have a basic understanding it is necessary to clarify many issues, you have to ask whether greater effort needs to be put into getting across to businesses their responsibilities under the act. Clarifying parts of the act is one thing, but getting the message through to all parties is even more important.
The third change is to subsection 27(2) of the act. There is in the act an exception to the prohibition on requesting information that allows the provision of medical information concerning pregnancy. This is included for occupational health and safety reasons. I have noted that under the recommended guidelines No. 26 in the report states:
... while it is appropriate to ask a pregnant job applicant to undergo a medical examination, any such medical examination should be undertaken with a view to addressing occupational health and safety concerns and should not in itself lead to, or exacerbate, discrimination on the grounds of pregnancy.
It occurred to me that perhaps an additional guideline might be to restrict access to the results of medical testing where the result has no bearing on any occupational health and safety issue that may otherwise influence the employment decision. This would ensure that the employer did not discriminate against the applicant, as the decision to inform the employer of the condition would be made by the medical practitioner on the basis of occupational health and safety concerns. I would also point out that in the explanatory memorandum, in paragraph 4 of page 4, the example refers to a pregnant employer, which I take it should be a pregnant employee. 
So much for what is in the bill. As I said earlier, out of 46 recommendations of the report, only three are acted upon by way of this amendment and they are Clayton's changes: they do not change the act, they only clarify sections of it. Referring only to the 11 recommendations which are the responsibility of the Attorney-General, where is the amendment to empower the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to publish enforceable standards in relation to pregnancy and potential pregnancy as stated in recommendation 1? Where is the amendment to extend the coverage of the act to federal statutory employees, judicial office holders and members of parliament? Where is the amendment to ensure coverage of unpaid workers? Where is the amendment to remove the exemption of employment by an instrumentality of a state? Where is the amendment to remove the exemption contained in section 38 for educational institutions established for religious purposes in relation to pregnancy and potential pregnancy? I am happy to see the Attorney-General in the chamber now. I ask the Attorney-General: where is the amendment to the provisions in relation to the award of compensatory damages to enable the award of punitive damages?
All of these recommended amendments referring to the Attorney-General are still in limbo, sitting in the too-hard basket, waiting for another year or another Attorney-General. While we are dealing with a bill whose purpose is to clarify rather than change the act, why is it that recommendation 35 was not taken on board? In that recommendation, the report of the inquiry asked:
That Attorney-General amend the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 ... to make clear that a complaint about a discriminatory advertisement may be made under section 14(1)(a) of the Act notwithstanding that the complainant is not a person directly affected by the advertisement. 
While we are in the process of making amendments to clarify the act, why was that left out? This is a Clayton's amendment—it is the amendment you have when you are not having an amendment. When you need to be seen to be doing something, this is the very least you can do. Out of 46 recommendations of the report of the National Pregnancy and Work Inquiry, the Attorney-General takes action on only three. By contrast, Labor is moving amendments to this bill which will address 10 of the recommendations which fall within the responsibility of the Attorney-General. That seems to indicate that the Attorney-General has absolutely no idea of the extent of the problem of discrimination against pregnant and potentially pregnant women.
As a crude measure of the issue we should note that in 1998 there were 249,000 live births in Australia. In that year, there were 3.73 million women in the work force. When you compare these figures with those of five years earlier in 1993, a clear picture emerges of the relationship between pregnancy and work. In 1993 there were 260,000 live births—that is 11,000 more than in 1998—but there were 3.26 million women in the work force—that is half a million less than in 1998. Today women make up more than 44 per cent of the work force. The images of the male as the breadwinner and the female as the homemaker have long since passed their use-by date. The average age at which a woman has her first child has increased from 26.3 years in 1985 to 28.6 years in 1995. Clearly something is happening to fertility rates and to the make-up of the work force and the two are related. The report of the National Pregnancy and Work inquiry quotes the Australian demographer Professor McDonald as saying:
... if women are provided with opportunities near to equivalent to those of men in education and market employment, but these opportunities are severely curtailed by having children, then, on average, women will restrict the number of children that they have to an extent which leaves fertility at a precariously low long-term level.
The report concluded that:
The low fertility rate indicates a growing trend by women actually making a choice between work and family rather than seeking both. 
The report also quoted from a comparison of male and female managers, finding that in high technology companies two-thirds of female managers did not have children while two-thirds of male managers did. While I have drawn on this example, it is worth noting that workers in manufacturing, retail and personal services can expect the least family-friendly working conditions. All this paints a dismal background for pregnant and potentially pregnant women in the workplace. Women are showing their concern by choosing work ahead of family in increasing numbers.
I would have thought that one important thing that could be done would be to assist women to choose both family and work. One of the more obvious steps would be to address the widespread discrimination against pregnant women. For many women the answer to discrimination is: don't get pregnant. That is their choice, but it need not be. It is not by accident that Scandinavian countries have higher fertility rates than other developed nations. It takes more than the baby bonuses paid to parents who stay at home—it takes a change of attitude in the workplace. When women are protected from discrimination they are free to choose both family and work. It will take the enforcement of standards of conduct and the education of employers and employees as well as service providers to end discrimination. This bill goes just a very short part of the way towards achieving that. Only with the adoption of the remaining recommendations of the report of the National Pregnancy and Work inquiry will we come close to achieving fairness for pregnant and potentially pregnant women. Only then can we expect the issue of declining birth rates to be addressed. Only when women can confidently plan for both a family and a career will we have reached the level of equality that women for such a long time have fought so hard to achieve.
Debate (on motion by Mrs Moylan) adjourned.

name: Williams, Daryl, MP
text:
—I move:
That the amendments Nos 1, 5 and 7 insisted on by the Senate be agreed to.
There have been some pretty extraordinary claims made by the opposition in this place about the government's position on this bill. Over the course of this year, while the government has been focusing on getting the bill passed, the opposition has shifted and changed its position and engaged in an exercise of rewriting history which has been second to none. In contrast to that of the opposition, the government's position on this bill has always been clear and consistent. We introduced this legislation because we believe and have always firmly believed that we need this legislation to give our intelligence agencies vital tools to deter and prevent terrorism. We have not wavered from this position and we continue to stand by it.
By contrast, the opposition has had as many different positions on the bill as there are days of the week. First they would not support the powers in the bill, despite the extensive amendments made by the government at the behest of the parliamentary joint committee, which included senior members from their own ranks. Then they sought to defer the debate on the bill to avoid taking a position, because there were significant divisions within their ranks. But, worse still, they then decided the power should be given to the police, despite the fact that the bill has nothing to do with law enforcement and everything to do with collecting intelligence. Then, sensing no doubt that the public had little time for their attempts to frustrate essential functions of the bill, they conceded that these powers should go to ASIO.
But what they propose to give ASIO is powers in a form that we say make them completely unworkable. Not only did all this toing-and-froing put the community at risk by delaying the passage of the bill but the opposition continued to seek to turn the bill into something that would not deliver the protection it was designed to achieve. I am patient, but even I reach a point at which I have to say enough is enough. For me, that point is where the bill no longer does what we have undertaken to the public that it will do, where it can no longer deliver on the promise of clearer powers to our intelligence services to gather intelligence to stop terrorist acts in circumstances where there is no acceptable alternative and where community safety is at risk.
The members opposite have preached long and hard about the things that the Labor Party will not wear. Apparently, they will not wear a system that would permit intelligence agencies to hold and question a person believed to have information about potential terrorist acts. They will not wear such intelligence gathering under a warrant issued by the Attorney-General, who is accountable to the people and the parliament and whose actions may be challenged in the courts. They will not wear a system where that warrant is approved by a federal judge or a retired judge and where the person is questioned in the presence of a senior member of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal or a retired judge. They will not wear a system where the person questioned has the right to a security-cleared lawyer, paid for by the Commonwealth. They will not wear a system where the person can complain to the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security, who can sit in on the questioning. And more extraordinary still, they will not wear a coercive questioning regime with detention in the strictly controlled circumstances that we propose. Yet the parliamentary joint committee had no problems with that and the member for Brand, Mr Beazley, and Senator Ray appeared to accept our position. They quite eloquently made out the case for the government's regime last night and this morning.  
Let us not forget another level of inconsistency: the Labor Party's New South Wales counterparts have given the New South Wales Police the power to strip-search children between the age of 10 and 18 without a warrant where there is the threat of a terrorist act. The New South Wales Police will be able to search a person's premises and vehicles without a warrant—I repeat, no warrant. There is also no judicial oversight as exists in the government's legislation, just the authorisation of the police minister. Federal Labor has been willing to wear this without a murmur. The government can wear the bill but not the opposition's amendments. 
The opposition's amendments go to matters of fundamental principle that we cannot accept. The government will not pretend to the community that what has come out of the Senate will provide the kind of protection against terrorism that we know we need. We will not do that when we know the opposition's package of amendments effectively renders it useless in the emergency situations it is designed to address and open to challenge. The opposition has exposed itself as being hopelessly divided on this bill. The government has demonstrated time and time again our commitment to community safety, but we will not accept amendments that fundamentally change the nature of the bill. However, the government wants this vital legislation passed before Christmas. In the interests of getting the legislation through and giving the community the benefit of this protection now, we are prepared to accept two of the opposition's amendments. We do not do so lightly. The opposition has made much of the need for the inclusion of state judges as prescribed authorities. Legal advice on this point differs. However, on the basis that the opposition's advice maintains that, in the event the provision with regard to state judges is found to be unconstitutional, it would be excisable and thus would not render the entire bill unconstitutional, we are prepared to accept that provision. (Extension of time granted)
In addition, while we are firmly of the belief that the security environment we are living in is unlikely to change in the foreseeable future and that these powers will be needed for some time to come, we are prepared to accept the opposition's sunset clause on the bill. This will enable this parliament to give the community the protection it needs in the current heightened security environment, secure in the knowledge that these extraordinary powers will necessarily be revisited by the parliament in three years. These are concessions which we are prepared to make because we are committed to getting this legislation passed. We have demonstrated that commitment since the legislation was introduced. We have never wavered from that commitment. Now is the opportunity for the opposition to display a commitment to the security of the Australian people, to accept the government's offer and to support the bill.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN SECURITY INTELLIGENCE ORGANISATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (TERRORISM) BILL 2002</title>

name: Melham, Daryl, MP
text:
—It was appropriate that the last time the Attorney spoke in the House on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Legislation Amendment (Terrorism) Bill 2002 the lights went off, we went into darkness and the House had to adjourn for a short while. And I think it is indicative of the attitude in terms of some of the discussions that have taken place between this side and the government—they seem not to get what we are saying; they seem to still be in the dark. It is good to see that, as the new light is dawning on this day, the government has moved some way, but they have to move a lot more. But talk about rewriting history: last night, the opposition, through the Leader of the Opposition, tabled legal advice from Dr Gavan Griffith QC, the former Solicitor-General, which showed that the amendments we proposed in relation to prescribed authority were constitutional. The government was running around saying, `We can't accept this amendment on a prescribed authority because of the danger of the constitutional problems.'
We are still waiting to see the advice of Mr Orr. We saw a letter that was sent to Senator Faulkner, after Senator Faulkner contacted the Attorney's office and not at the time it was said to have been received, and the Attorney has a letter from Senator Faulkner, whose advice, and he said so in the Senate, was that that correspondence only arrived at approximately 1 p.m. after a phone call was made. There might have been some miscommunication, but, notwithstanding that, a letter went to the Attorney which said, `Show us the advice.' We still have not seen Mr Orr's advice, but at least the government has done the right thing and capitulated. Why has it capitulated? Because we have tabled the advice of Mr Gavan Griffith QC, and it is impeccable advice. 
All the way through, with the terrorism bills and these bills, the opposition have acted responsibly. We have sought proper advice. We have a sound basis and sound principles for what we are putting to the government. What we are putting to the government, if it is accepted, will see cross-party support for these bills, as there should be. So do not talk about rewriting history. In relation to the sunset clause, the position was made very clear by the Joint Standing Committee on ASIO, ASIS and DSD, which unanimously recommended a sunset clause, and the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee. So the government has bowed to the inevitable on that. I will talk about the other amendments when we deal with them shortly.
The government continues to go on with this nonsense. It is the government that is jeopardising the national interest. We say on this side that a workable bill has come out of the Senate. The government has come some way, but it has to keep walking. There is a long way for it to go yet before this side of the House will support an amended bill. It is absurd to suggest that the government has not known our position from day one. I have been involved in confidential discussions, and for the Attorney to say that there has been a shift in position is disingenuous. We have shown that the Senate process and the joint committee process have worked. We have involved lawyers and we have kept an open mind on this.
What we have sought to do—and so has the government, in some instances, but only in a minor way—is to put submissions and, in the light of evidence from experts that came before the Senate committee, to move forward in our position in relation to a number of things, and the government has picked them up. I note that, in the Senate, the government has picked up a number of amendments arising out of the Senate. You cannot say that is technical and a bit of a maze, as the Attorney seeks to do in some of his press conferences and speeches, and that we are being nit-picking and pedantic. If that is the case, Michelle Grattan fingered you; you should be accepting all of the amendments. But in relation to detention as against a questioning regime, that is fundamental. I will deal with that in the next round of amendments.
We welcome the government's capitulation on these two matters. The reason we expanded the prescribed authority was that the government said it did not have enough retired judges. We were not going to have a situation where, in relation to that, the government could say that there were not enough people to serve on the prescribed authority. So we welcome the government caving in on these amendments—so it should. We would welcome that in relation to the other amendments, because it will give you a workable bill that has broad support across the parliament. You know it. (Extension of time granted) In relation to this set of amendments, we have great pleasure in supporting this position. It has been our position for some time, and the Attorney knows that.
The Attorney knows that there is no division on this side of the House in relation to the sunset clause or the prescribed authority. If anything, he should have a look at the Senate committee and joint committee reports. Members of the government, judging on the merits and not bound by their caucus room, voted for the sensible proposals in the report. So do not come in here and talk about rewriting history. I know who is rewriting history. It was not six hours ago that you were standing up and saying that, in relation to these aspects, they were non-negotiable, you were not going to move on them—that the sky would fall in if you gave in on a sunset clause and there would be constitutional problems in relation to the prescribed authority. We nailed that pretty quickly. The other arguments are straw man arguments. I will deal with them in the near future.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN SECURITY INTELLIGENCE ORGANISATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (TERRORISM) BILL 2002</title>

name: Crean, Simon, MP
text:
—I indicated last night when I was speaking on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Legislation Amendment (Terrorism) Bill 2002 that the Labor Party support tough legislation to counter terrorism in this country. We have always supported that and we have said so from the beginning. We have been prepared to enter the debate, consider the advice and make judgments based around it—and that is what the bill, which is continuing to come back from the Senate, is doing. I cannot understand why the government are not prepared to adopt all the amendments. There has been an indication this morning that the government are prepared to move on two amendments—one after we tabled advice from the former Solicitor-General, which the government now accepts. We still have not seen the government's advice as to why they were arguing unconstitutionality before. Now we have them tapping the mat on unconstitutionality.  
Why do the government keep going to the brink but then only want to play politics? They do not want a solution; they just want to play politics. Also, we have now got them acknowledging that they will accept a sunset clause. What has taken them so long? If they are prepared to accept that this should be a bill that we trial, if you like, for the next three years, why do they not support the other amendments? It is because the other amendments go to fundamental principles. The first is that people who are being detained for questioning have access to lawyers. What is wrong with society having access to lawyers from a panel of lawyers that was recommended by a Senate committee, which members of the government agreed with? The Attorney-General is ignoring the advice coming from members of his own party, let alone the Labor Party. Why should people not be allowed to have access to lawyers if they are being detained? We accept that they should not be able to play around with the system and use it to delay. That principle has been attempted to be accommodated. It is a fundamental principle that they should have access to lawyers. Why will this government not accept that?
The second issue goes to the age at which people can be detained. Why should people aged 14 years be involved in this bill? As the member for Brand indicated, if it is a suicide bomber aged 17, you do not need this legislation; you use other legislation. Under this legislation we are talking about circumstances in which people can be taken in for questioning at the age of 14 and detained for up to seven days—and for 48 hours they do not have access to a lawyer. How could anyone in those circumstances accept that this government is serious about dealing with principle as distinct from playing politics?
Then we have the questioning regime which they insist should enable them to question for up to seven days. Under the amendments that we have put forward, there is the ability to question for up to 20 hours. That does not mean less than a day; it means 20 hours of questioning—eight hours more than is currently provided for under the Crimes Act. We recognise that the special circumstances of this case go beyond the provisions that pertain under the Crimes Act, but that is not good enough for the government. Do not tell me that the authorities, the questioning agency and intelligence-gathering agency, ASIO, cannot get an understanding after 20 hours of questioning.
We are saying that the government has the capacity to get the bill through today. That is the challenge to the Attorney-General. Instead of coming into this place and trying to explain away his guilt in this—he could not even explain it at a press conference yesterday afternoon—we say to the Attorney-General, `Change your mind and accept the amendments now' and we can have the bill through today.
That is the opportunity that faces you, Attorney. We can have this bill through before Christmas—a bill which is not just advanced by the Labor Party but supported by members of your own party. One can only assume that, if you reject this opportunity, you want to play politics with it. (Extension of time granted) We can only assume that, if the Attorney persists with the stance he is taking now, he is playing politics with it. He is denying the opportunity for his government to give strength and power to ASIO to deal with the threat of terrorism in this country. This is a unique opportunity, as I indicated before. These are powers that do not exist in other democratic countries in the world. These are significantly enhanced powers for ASIO, which we accept in the context of the war on terror. But we are not going to compromise on the fundamental principles, and we are not going to ignore the advice that was determined by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee on all the evidence that came before it. 
Attorney, why is it that you think you are the one who is right on this when you have been proven wrong on the unconstitutionality? The fact of the matter is that you do not have the courage to stand up to people in your own party who want to play politics with this. The people who consider the issues understand why these amendments are important. We urge you again, given that you have made the concessions on two of the points we have been arguing at length for some time, to go the extra step. Concede the extra three points, because you will have a bill before Christmas—a bill that strengthens the hand of ASIO; a bill that looks after the interests of the Australian citizens but that does not put some in jeopardy. Your legislation does. It takes away their rights. It is not fair in these circumstances.
If you think the Australian public is going to accept a position in which you deny people the right to lawyers and in which you say you need to be able to detain them for up to seven days, it will not wear it. The Australian public does want tough new powers, but it also wants the rights of its citizens protected. That is where you have to get the balance right, and the bill that has come back from the Senate gets the balance right. You want to distort the balance, and you are not doing your role or the country any service. I urge you to consider again these amendments in the interests of better powers and the protection of our citizens. Have the capacity and the decency to get the balance right rather than just play grubby politics with this bill.
Question agreed to.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN SECURITY INTELLIGENCE ORGANISATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (TERRORISM) BILL 2002</title>

name: Williams, Daryl, MP
text:
—I move:
That the House insists on disagreeing to amendments Nos 2, 4, 6, 8, 9, 10, 12, 13, 16 to 28, 30, 32 to 37, 40 to 47, 51 and 54 to 56 insisted on by the Senate.
If I were to speak in support of this motion, I would simply be repeating what I have previously said. I will not detain the House on that account.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN SECURITY INTELLIGENCE ORGANISATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (TERRORISM) BILL 2002</title>

name: Melham, Daryl, MP
text:
—I can understand why the Attorney did not want to speak for long; he would be repeating what he said earlier. What he said earlier was defending the indefensible. That is the truth of it, and that is why he could not get up this time and speak for another five minutes. The government's opposition to what are reasonable amendments to the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Legislation Amendment (Terrorism) Bill 2002 is indefensible. If the government accept the Senate amendments, we will have legislation that ASIO can work with. What will it give them? It will give them additional powers. What have the opposition said they will do in return for bringing in a questioning regime? We have said, `Let's introduce penalties in terms of secrecy provisions.' The main thrust of the government's proposal is: we want to question for intelligence gathering. That is what they are saying. But, when you question the government further, they do not want to release people on the suspicion that they might talk to someone.
We have come up with secrecy provisions that say, `If people leave the prescribed authority and disclose, they are liable to penalty.' That makes them no longer nonsuspects; that makes them accused who can be prosecuted, brought back in and kept in custody. We are told by the Attorney-General that he has problems with the drafting of these provisions. We have drafted them, but he says that he is not happy with them. There are number of precedents that this government can look at. The Australian Crime Commission—the former National Crime Authority—and ICAC have the same provisions. That is our trade-off in relation to a questioning of the detention regime.
This is a fundamental matter of principle. As I said earlier, this is not Pinochet's Chile; this is Australia 2002. We do not pinch our citizens off the street, keep them incommunicado with no lawyers, and try to crush them by keeping them incommunicado for seven days—that is what you want to do. This is more than an intelligence-gathering exercise. The government say one thing but the reality is another. They want to treat people who are not accused of offences—nonsuspects—worse than people accused of the most heinous of crimes. Under the Crimes Act, you can only keep suspects for 12 hours—four hours and then a further eight hours. You have to charge them or release them. Under our amendments, you can keep them for four hours plus another eight plus another eight—that is 20 hours of pure questioning, which is more than adequate. 
These powers are not available in America, the subject of a heinous terrorist attack, because their constitution prohibits it. The UK has had a bit of experience with terrorism, but these powers are not available in the UK for nonsuspects. Yet this government insists on these powers of detention for seven days. We say, `Yes, bring them in for questioning.' Neither I nor the Labor Party have any objection to people being brought in for questioning with lawyers. Our statute books have plenty of examples of that: if you are subpoenaed, you are required to attend. We also say, `If you attend under this legislation and tell lies, you are subject to five years imprisonment.'
It is absolutely indefensible for this government to maintain its opposition to what are reasonable amendments. Our track record on this is spot-on. We negotiated the terrorism bills that were first introduced into this parliament by this Attorney and this government, and we got them to a state where they were consistent with the values and the principles that we seek to defend from terrorists. You do not surrender to terrorists by, in effect, throwing out the values that we are defending—the presumption of innocence, the rule of law and access to a lawyer. This is not a dictatorship; this is not a fascist regime that we are defending. (Extension of time granted) The Labor Party will not support a police state, which is what this government basically want in persisting with their amendments. Judge them not on their rhetoric but on the quality of their legislation. The Intelligence Services Bill went through a committee prior to September 11, giving ASIO and the other authorities broad powers in intelligence gathering.
In relation to the incident in Bali, what happened to the terrorism bills? Proscription occurred through the UN. Those laws worked. More importantly, what the terrorists saw was a united response from our parliament. What the Labor Party are offering this government is a united response to an amended bill from the Senate. But we will not offer to surrender liberties that people went to war and died for. When my parents came to this country, they came under the Aliens Act. They were photographed, their addresses were taken and they were not allowed to move around this country, not because they were guilty of anything but because of the suspicion that people were non-white where they came from. Haven't we learnt from the mistakes of the past not to judge people on the basis of race or religion? We want to go after terrorists, not innocent citizens. What worries me is that the government says in relation to this: `We want intelligence-gathering powers, not punitive powers.' We are offering that through the amendments and the amended bill from the Senate. We are offering additional powers.
This Attorney says the bill does not go far enough. Attorney, there is an old saying: a bird in the hand is worth two in the bush. In this instance, the parliament is about to rise. The Labor Party will not retreat or surrender on fundamental principles in relation to this bill. We are united; we have shown that. You are defending the indefensible. It is in the national interest that you go the rest of the way with these Senate amendments, because they are offering additional powers. But what you want are repressive powers. They are not in the national interest. It is my view that you will not be able to sustain this in the public domain. Why? Because it is unreasonable. On the basic test, it is unreasonable. 
I urge the government, even though it is late in the day—it is early in the morning, but late in the day in terms of the debate on this bill—to consider and reconsider what I think is a crazy position on their behalf. As has been said, and, I anticipate, will be said again in this debate, these are additional powers. The Labor Party have come a long way. I will not have it said that we have shifted and changed. We have maintained a principled position. We have sought to accommodate the reasonable requests of the government. We have listened to the experts that have come before the parliamentary committee. If you look at what we have done, you will see that we have been willing to move, because we do not want to take purely technical points. We are not taking technical points; they are fundamental. We say: after 20 hours of investigation, let them go or charge them. I commend our position to the government. Do not surrender what we are fighting for—our liberties, our values. Go forth with a bill that both sides of this parliament can agree with. I commend the amendments from the Senate. I commend members of the government who sat on the committees, who judged the terrorism bills on their merit and who support, in their reports and in what they have signed off on, all the amendments that the Labor Party is insisting on.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN SECURITY INTELLIGENCE ORGANISATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (TERRORISM) BILL 2002</title>

name: Beazley, Kim, MP
text:
—This country needs the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Legislation Amendment (Terrorism) Bill 2002. It needs a bill that will ensure that we have in the coming weeks and months the capacity to allow our intelligence agencies to do the very best they can in securing information from people in the community who may have a vague understanding, or even a more substantial understanding, of actions intended here or elsewhere that will take the lives of our citizens or the citizens of other countries. The bill is needed. It will not be a satisfactory outcome if we walk away at the conclusion of these proceedings without such an act.
The Attorney-General got one thing right when he said that the Labor Party had shifted ground. Yes, we have. Many of us started off with an assumption that if these powers were to reside anywhere, they ought to reside in respect of the fully accountable and known—in terms of the names and positions—particular individuals concerned in the police force. Those powers ought properly to reside with them, just as some equivalent of them resides with the New South Wales Police force, which has other strands of accountability attached to it.
We took the view that ASIO was a different sort of body and that the powers of detention, the powers of compulsory questioning and the powers, ultimately, to charge people with a failure to answer those questions and be jailed ought not properly reside within an organisation devised for different purposes. We have changed on that. We have attempted to move to the government's position so that we can get an outcome for the Australian people. That is why we have moved on this—not because we have been confused in our objectives. Our objectives all along have been to achieve an outcome that ensures that there is some questioning of those who may have knowledge of possible terrorist acts in order that those acts may be prevented or we get the best possible particulars and information about them. That is why we have shifted. It is a reasonable thing for us to see you shift as well.
I think it is the profound conviction on this side of the House that the government do not move because they see a political advantage in not doing so. If that is the government's motive, their judgment in those areas is beginning to be shaky. Their judgment in political terms may well have been excellent in the latter parts of last year, but there is recent evidence around that if that is the motive—a willingness to sacrifice Australian interests for political interest—it is no longer paying off as it has in the past. We witnessed that terribly last week when statements were made by the Prime Minister in regard to pre-emptive strikes, which had a major damaging effect on our capacity to mobilise the coalition we need to mobilise. Amongst the Muslim states or states with substantial Muslim minorities in our immediate region it was an ill-judged statement. I do not think that it did the Prime Minister any good, I do not think that it did the Liberal Party any good and we know for sure that it did not do the country any good. The same applies here.
Frankly, Minister, the public will not understand the differences between us. We stand here for a regime that will ensure that people can be questioned for 20 hours. In the way in which that is framed, that effectively means two to three days detention while that questioning is done. We have put forward amendments to the bill which have been carried by the Senate which ensure legal representation. You say that yours ensures legal representation as well. They will not understand the difference between us. I could go through virtually every single item of the regime. You can say the same: `Look, we do that.' We say, `We do it this way.' Frankly, there is going to be no political advantage to any particular side in the collapse of this legislation at the end of the day, though some may think there will be. There will be none. But I tell you what there will be if this bill does not go through. If this bill does not go through, an opportunity which is available to Australian security services, but not to those of our principal ally, will be lost. An essential additional component of the powers of ASIO will disappear. There will be plenty of blame to go around when that occurs, but the essence of what is needed will not take place. That essential protection will not be put in place. There will be no political gains, but there will be major security losses for the ordinary Australian. (Extension of time granted)
There is a negotiator—that is, Senator Faulkner—who is authorised by the Leader of the Opposition to negotiate on the part of the Labor Party. We have had conversations. I do not want to go into the internal detail of those conversations; that would be improper. We are still interested in arriving at a position that is sensible on one particular item, as the Attorney-General knows. He has expressed concern about disallowable instruments. Senator Faulkner has indicated to him that, if something else appropriate can be put in place, he is prepared to give consideration to that. That is the bottom line. If the Attorney-General accepts that, he may not necessarily have the unanimous support of the parliament, because there are parties that do not agree with this proposition, but he will have the support of the opposition. He will have the combined support of the government and the opposition to see that this legislation goes through and gets put in place.
I appeal to the Attorney-General to rethink his position, to comprehend the extent to which we have made substantial compromises on matters of principle and direction. But there are some fundamental principles that will not be compromised. We have some fundamental concerns that we will not budge on, and they relate to the detention of children who are not suspects. That is not acceptable. As far as we are concerned, we cannot approach that situation. As for the rest of it, frankly, the regime that we put forward has additional protections that the government's does not. Those protections do not render it ineffective—not at all. If the Attorney-General remains convinced that they do, there is no harm, because the original legislation which was before us will not get through. 
At least give this a chance to work. The Australian people need it. The Australian people are owed it. Our contemporary circumstances require it. There will in the end be no particular political advantage in us ripping each other up on this issue on the hustings. The public will see us basically in `screaming agreement' and wonder what the heck we are talking about. In those circumstances, I ask you, Attorney-General, to go away and think again. You have about half an hour before this gets back into the Senate. You have already had that conversation, as I suggested, with Senator Faulkner. I suggest that you have another one and see what you can come up with.
Question put:
That the motion (Mr Williams's) be agreed to.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN SECURITY INTELLIGENCE ORGANISATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (TERRORISM) BILL 2002</title>

name: Williams, Daryl, MP
text:
—I move:
That the House insists on amendments Nos 8, 11, 12, 13 and 14 made by the House in place of Senate amendments disagreed to, and does not insist on amendments Nos 1 to 7, 9 and 10 made by the House in place of Senate amendments disagreed to.
Again, I do not propose to detain the House by repeating what I have already said on the subject. Our position is quite clear; it has been laid on the record in my previous statements.
Honourable members interjecting—
—I remind members who have been watching the debate that the debate to date has been a credit to the House and ought to continue as such.
Question put:
That the motion (Mr Williams's) be agreed to.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN SECURITY INTELLIGENCE ORGANISATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (TERRORISM) BILL 2002</title>

name: Moylan, Judi, MP
text:
—I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak on this amendment to the Sex Discrimination Amendment (Pregnancy and Work) Bill 2002 today. Every day, when I walk through the front door of my office here in Parliament House, I look at a very large photograph, which takes up most of the wall in the foyer of my office. The caption underneath it says, `Feel the power'. It is a very special and memorable photo because in 1996 the largest number of women ever were elected to the parliament on the coalition side. They numbered 25, and 25 of those women are featured in this photo. When you examine it carefully, you see that most of those women are still in the parliament and that three-quarters of them are or have been senior office holders.
